PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the Chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Boswell (from 48 citizens), Senator Childs (from 30 citizens) and Senator Parer (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 17 citizens) and Senator Parer (from 6 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Chapman (from 29 citizens) and Senator Newman (from 616 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Powell (from 120 citizens) and Senator Reid (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1) Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
2) Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
3) Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

(b) urges Soviet leaders to continue the reform process which will give freedom and democracy to the Soviet people and a market economy which can maximise the economic potential of the Soviet Union to the benefit of all its people;
(c) recognises the pain and stress involved in restructuring the Soviet political and economic systems and urges the West to actively support such changes; and

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw the notice of motion standing in my name for three sitting days hence for the disallowance of Fisheries Notices Nos NPF 9 to 14 and No. ORF 15, made under section 8 of the Fisheries Act 1952. Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that I reported on 6 June about the concerns of the Committee with these instruments which related to defects in drafting. These defects were so serious as to affect the validity of all seven Fisheries Notices. Such drafting flaws are a breach of parliamentary propriety. In addition, they affect the personal right of those engaged in the fishing industry to have their duties and obligations clearly set out in any relevant legislation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has now undertaken to redraft the defective parts of the instruments. Mr President, as usual I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the correspondence of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
7 June 1991
The Hon Simon Crean MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Simon
I refer to Fisheries Notices Nos. NPF 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 and No. ORF 15, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 6 June 1991.
The Explanatory Statement for Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9 advises that ``Paragraph 7 prohibits the use of specified equipment for taking prawns''. Relevant parts of paragraph 7 state as follows:

``7. Pursuant to paragraphs 8(1) (c) and 8(1) (e) of the Act prohibit the taking of prawns in the area of proclaimed water specified in paragraph 11 of this notice with the use from a boat of . . . [specified equipment] that is not stowed and secured by being unshackled from the warps and brought on deck''.

The drafting of this paragraph does not appear to effect the purposes of s.8(1) (e) of the Act. It appears that some words have been omitted. This is important because not only does paragraph 9 of the present Notice refer back to paragraph 7, but paragraph 6 of No. NPF 10, paragraph 6 of No. NPF 11 and paragraph 6 of No. NPF 12 refer to paragraph 7. In addition, paragraph 7 of No. NPF 13 and paragraph 7 of No. NPF 14 both refer to ``equipment as defined in Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9''.
There is a small typographical error in paragraph 3.

Fisheries Notice NPF 11 refers in one provision to ``proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5''. There is no apparent reference to proclaimed waters in paragraph 4, which appears to refer to paragraphs 5 and 6.

Fisheries Notice NPF 12 refers in one provision to ``activities prohibited by paragraph 4''. There are no activities prohibited by paragraph 4. It appears that the provision should have referred to paragraphs 5 or 6 or both. NPF 12 refers in another provision to ``periods specified in paragraph 4''. There are no periods specified in paragraph 4, which should refer to paragraph 5.

Fisheries Notices NPF 13 and 14 refer to ``equipment as defined in Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9', without further qualification. Most of the substantive provisions of NPF 9 define equipment, as does the interpretation provision and a schedule. It is assumed that paragraph 7 of NPF 9 is meant, but as described earlier that provision is defective. In any event, the cross-reference should be made specific.

In NPF 14 a provision refers to ``proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 6''. There are no references to proclaimed waters in either of these paragraphs but there are such references in paragraphs 5 and 7.

Fisheries Notice No. ORF 15, one of 12 Fisheries Notices tabled on 16 May 1991, was not signed. All of the other Notices tabled on that day, and the other 10 Fisheries Notices and Plans of Management made this year, all carry facsimiles of separate individual hand written signatures by the Minister, together with a hand written date. In ORF 15 there is a blank space where the facsimile signature usually appears, although the date is hand written as usual. Therefore, there is at least a presumption that the instrument was never signed and is of no effect.
All of the Northern Prawn Fishery Notices were made on 19 March 1991, but not tabled in the Senate until 16 May 1991, or 14 sitting days later. Therefore, your early advice would be appreciated.
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
MINISTER FOR PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY
PARLIAMENT HOUSE
CANBERRA 2600
21 August 1991
Senator Patricia Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Pat
I refer to your letter of 7 June 1991 concerning Fisheries Notices Nos. NPF 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 and No. ORF 15.
Paragraph 7 of Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9 will be split into two paragraphs.
A new paragraph 7 will be drafted to prohibit, under subsections 8(1)(c) and 8(1)(f) of the Fisheries Act 1952 (the Act), the use of fishing gear other than of a specified kind or quantity.
Paragraph 6a will then be inserted to prohibit, under paragraph 8(1)(e) of the Act, the carrying of specified fishing gear otherwise than in a specified manner.
The reference in Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9 to ``paragraph 7'' in paragraph 9 (first occurring) and paragraph 11 will be amended to include paragraph 6a.
The word ``apply'' will be changed to ``applies'' in paragraph 3 of Fisheries Notices Nos. NPF 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14.
The words ``Area of proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 5'' in Schedule 1 of Fisheries Notice No. NPF 11 will be amended so that the reference is to paragraphs 5 and 6.

The reference to paragraph 4 in paragraph 6 of Fisheries Notice No. NPF 12 will be amended to refer to paragraph 5, and the reference to paragraph 4 in paragraph 9 will be amended to refer to paragraphs 5 and 6.

The reference in paragraph 7 of Fisheries Notice Nos. NPF 13 and 14 to equipment defined in Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9 will be made more specific by giving paragraph 7 of Fisheries Notice No. NPF 9 as the paragraph in which the equipment is defined.
The words ``Area of proclaimed waters referred to in paragraphs 4 and 6'' in Schedule 1 of Fisheries Notice No. NPF 14 will be amended so that the reference is to paragraphs 5 and 7.
ORF 15 has now been revoked by Fisheries Notice No. ORF 16.
The Northern Prawn Fishery Notices were tabled within the statutory time limit of 15 sitting days.
Yours sincerely
SIMON CREAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 201 and made under the Migration Act 1958, and the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 148 and made under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987, be disallowed.
Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement about the concerns of the Committee with these instruments.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present set of migration regulations provides for applicants for certain visas for entry into Australia to be assessed, not on their own individual merits, but upon the basis of prescribed classes. Among these classes are sex, nationality and age. The Committee considered that to grant or deny people a visa on these grounds was such an important step that it may be appropriate for an Act to approve such a course. It is unusual for the Committee to question an instrument on the ground that it may be more appropriate for parliamentary enactment, but this is such a case.

SPEECH.PARA: The present set of occupational superannuation standards regulations provides, among other things, nine detailed tables which set out the valuation factor for superannuation pensions. This, obviously, has important financial consequences for the millions of Australian workers in such schemes. However, there appear to be serious flaws in the tables which make it impossible for an individual to determine his or her entitlements. Mr President, as usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of the concerns.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Migration Regulations (Amendment)
Statutory Rules 1991 No.201

At present the Minister is engaged in a major review of the Migration Regulations. The Committee understands that the review will be completed later this year. It would be appropriate to complete the review at that time as the parent Migration Act 1958 provides that, unless saved by the regulation itself, regulations prescribing criteria for visas and entry permits shall be taken to be repealed 2 years after the day on which the regulation takes effect. The present Principal Regulations took effect on 19 December 1989.

There have been many amendments since then of the Principal Regulations and of the associated Migration (Review) Regulations. The Committee has carefully scrutinised all of these instruments and has written to the Minister about any concerns it has raised. The Minister has undertaken to take these concerns into account in the final review. The Minister has also responded promptly when the Committee has asked for advice on issues which appeared to require immediate replies, such as those connected with migration regulations effecting Australian sanctions against Iraq. The present Regulations are such a case.

The present Regulations provide for a ``risk factor'' as an element in the grant of 5 different types of visa. The risk factor firstly relates to whether a particular individual has applied for a permanent residence visa in the last 5 years. The Committee has no difficulties with this provision. However, the second aspect of the risk factor does not relate to the applicant himself or herself. Rather the risk factor applies if the applicant has only one characteristic in common with classes of persons who tend to overstay their visas or entry permits. These characteristics are expressed to be-
(a) nationality
(b) marital status
(c) age
(d) sex
(e) occupation
(f) class of visa
(g) place of application

These characteristics appear to be sensitive. Here classes are being used to judge a person rather than judging that person individually on their own merits. Persons are judged for entry into Australia not upon personal conduct but, among other things, upon nationality and sex.

This is such an important change in the law that the Committee considers that it may be more appropriate for the parent Act expressly to authorise such a provision. It is only rarely that the Committee raises this as a ground for concern about an instrument. However, on the face of it the present instrument is such a case. The Committee has sought early advice from the Minister.
Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations (Amendment)
Statutory Rules 1991 No.148

These Regulations amend the administration of reasonable benefit limits for occupational superannuation. The Explanatory Statement advises that the amendments are technical in nature and are intended to remove practical difficulties in the administration of these limits.

The Committee's concerns with this instrument relate to the clarity and certainty of its provisions. The Committee scrutinises all disallowable instruments of delegated legislation to ensure that they comply with appropriate levels of parliamentary propriety and personal liberty. It is a breach of both of these principles if provisions are drafted in such a way that it is not possible to ascertain the state of the law. In this case the Committee was particularly vigilant as the Regulations in question affect the savings and retirement income of millions of working Australians. As such, it is essential that they be drafted to a standard equal to that of Acts of Parliament.

The present Regulations insert 9 new Tables which set out the valuation factor for superannuation pensions indexed at particular percentage rates. The Tables are all expressed to be based on the ``Age last birthday of recipient on commencement date of pension''. Each table sets out blocks of ages to which particular factors apply depending on which indexation rate is used.

However, all the Tables appear to duplicate numbers of ages, such ages being the basis upon which the whole scheme is based. It is thus not possible for an individual to know to which group he or she belongs. Each Table commences ``(age) 20 or less'' and then continues ``(age) 21 to 25'' which appears correct and appropriate. Similarly, each of the 9 Tables ends with ``(age) 75 to 80'' and then ``(age) 81 or more'' which again seems correct. But each of the other 10 blocks duplicates ages, reading ``(age) 25 to 30, 30 to 35, 35 to 40, 40 to 45 . . . ''. In all, 11 ages in each of the 9 Tables are duplicated. On the face of the instrument there are therefore two sets of laws applicable to every person of these ages upon retirement.

Parliamentary propriety dictates that drafting of delegated legislation should be precise and clear. Conversely, those who are affected by such legislation must not be burdened by ambiguous provisions.

ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT, AND TOURISM LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991
The original draft of the Arts, Sport, Environment and Tourism Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 amends 15 Acts administered in the ASETT Portfolio.
The amendments are mainly to make the administration of various Government programs more efficient and cost effective.

One measure affects a range of programs. The Bill implements for 13 statutory authorities in the portfolio the Government's decision that the Remuneration Tribunal should have jurisdiction over the recreation leave entitlements of fulltime officeholders. Authorities in other portfolios have already been covered by the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Act 1991.
The other amendments in the Bill cover specific programs:

Five statutory authorities will have the value limit beyond which they need to obtain Ministerial approval for contracts and other transactions increased, generally to $250,000: the Australia Council; Australian Film, Television and Radio School; Australian National Maritime Museum; Australian National Gallery; and National Museum of Australia.

An officer of the Navy will be an ex officio member of the Council of the Australia National Maritime Museum, and section 49 of the Museum Act, which exempts the Museum from taxation, will be clarified.

The 3 representatives of the Convocation of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School on the Council of the School will be appointed by the Council, rather than elected by the Convocation. It is becoming increasingly difficult to conduct an effective election among the more than one thousand members of Convocation.
The Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Committee will be made able to hold meetings by conference telephone and similar methods.

The maximum fee that can be levied under the regulations for an export or import permit under the Hazardous Wastes (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 will be increased from $4,000 to $8,000. The $4,000 limit introduced in July 1990 was intended to enable full cost recovery but experience has shown it is insufficient.

Further changes were made to the Bill in the House of Representatives during the Debate on 20 August 1991. The first of these is to the recreation leave amendments. A transitional provision will ensure that the rights to recreation leave that the member had prior to commencement are preserved as at the time of commencement, and the unintended omission of the National Capital Planning Authority from the Bill is rectified.

Addition of the NCPA Amendment, an Australian Capital Territory matter, means that the name of the Bill needs to be changed to the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. Honourable Senators will recall that the first Portfolio Bill of the Department was passed in the Autumn 1991 Sittings of Parliament.

Mr President, the Government has now decided on the removal of age limit restrictions as regards the appointment, and the continuation of appointment, of non-executive statutory officeholders in the ASETT portfolio. Under a majority of the legislation governing these statutory authorities, a mandatory retirement age of 65 or 70 is currently provided for all members of Boards, Councils, etc., of these authorities. The amendments will remove the mandatory retirement age provision for all nonexecutive members of the governing bodies of the Department's statutory authorities.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum, as well as the two supplementary explanatory memoranda relating to the additional changes I have just described.
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO 2) 1991

This Bill makes amendments to the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991, aspects of the Primary Industries and Energy R& Act 1989 concerning the Wool Research and Development Corporation and the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Act 1991 to correct omissions and drafting errors. All of these Acts were passed in the last session of Parliament.

With regard to the amendments to the wool legislation, the Senate will recall that a package of urgent legislation putting in place new arrangements for the wool industry to apply from 1 July 1991 was passed in the last hours of the Autumn Sittings.

On further examination of the legislation and consultations with Attorney-General's Department, it has become apparent that some minor additional transitional provisions are needed. Attorney-General's has advised that the wording of the existing legislation is such that it is not possible to appropriate and transfer to the wool statutory authorities wool tax imposed on wool sold prior to 1 July 1991 but received by the Commonwealth after that date. Clearly, the situation needs to be rectified and the provisions of this Bill do that.
The provisions of the existing legislation regarding wool tax on wool sold after 1 July 1991 are adequate and do not need amending.

It is recognised that, as a result of the defect in the legislation, the wool statutory authorities have not had, since early July, access to the flow of wool tax funds which they should have had. They would therefore have incurred additional expense either through interest forgone or through additional interest costs on borrowed funds. The Government considers that the statutory authorities, and through them the woolgrowers, should not have to bear the additional expense caused by the drafting omission. Therefore the Government will pay interest for the period of the delay in the wool tax payments. The Bill provides that the Minister will determine the interest rate to apply and I envisage that the rate will be based on that which the Commonwealth earns on investment of its surplus funds.

The Bill also proposes that interest will be payable by the Commonwealth on the delay in payment to the wool statutory authorities of wool tax money received by the Commonwealth immediately before 30 June 1991 but not paid out until after that date, while the legal questions were being resolved. The Commonwealth passed to the Realisation Commission wool tax in this category in late July and early August and relevant portions have, under the regulations, since been passed on to the Wool Corporation and Wool R& Corporation.

There is also an amendment to carry over into the new legislation for wool research and development, provisions to reflect the existing Commonwealth policy of matching R& funds raised by primary industries up to a ceiling of 0.5% of the gross value of production or the amount of levy collected.

The Bill provides additional transitional arrangements in relation to the establishment of the Australian Dried Fruits Board. The Board commenced operations on 1 July 1991 as a Product Board within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. It was established under provisions contained in the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Act 1991 as part of the reform of Government assistance arrangements for the dried vine fruits industry. Other measures covered changes to dried vine fruits statutory equalisation and sultana underwriting.
The Board took on the dried vine fruit export marketing and promotion functions of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. It is funded by an export charge imposed on exports of dried fruit.

The Dried Fruits Export Charges Act 1924, which was repealed on 1 July 1991, provided the funds for the former Dried Fruits Corporation. However, a problem has arisen in making payments to the new Board of funds raised under that Act but collected by the Commonwealth after the date of repeal. The Bill will provide for amounts equal to those collected by the Commonwealth to be appropriated to the Board from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Provision is also to be made for interest accruing on these amounts outstanding to be payable to the Board.

The Government has introduced this Bill at the first opportunity to rectify omissions in complex legislation passed at the end of the last Sittings. I appreciate the co-operation given by the Opposition in according this Bill speedy passage to enable the funds to flow to the organisations concerned.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is to provide transitional arrangements following the package of wool Bills and the establishment of the Australian Dried Fruits Board. When the recent wool Bills were drafted, provision was not made for wool tax due before 30 June but actually paid after 1 July. As a result, about $90m is frozen and cannot be paid to the Wool Realisation Commission, the Australian Wool Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The Government has been able to transfer about $30m through regulation, but needs this legislation to transfer the other $60m. The same problem has arisen with levies collected after the date of repeal of the old Australian Dried Fruit Corporation, which was replaced by the Dried Fruits Board under the wing of the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am most concerned that legislation such as this has been so shoddily drafted and has led to a situation where the Commonwealth Government has felt it necessary to pay compensation for the losses incurred due to the late payment. The compensation will be an amount equal to interest received by the Government while the money has been waiting to be transferred. The shoddy drafting of legislation affecting important Australian industries is becoming a far too common occurrence.

This piece of legislation is not the only issue relating to wool before the Parliament at present. There are regulations that flow from the wool debate and the wool legislation that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will recall were considered in the dying stages of the last session of Parliament. The Opposition parties strongly believe, from the way in which the opening of wool auctions has gone on since we were here in June, that a maximum of 10 per cent total tax to be paid by woolgrowers is more than enough. This is a very conservative figure.

For this reason, I moved this morning a notice of motion to disallow the regulation that the Government has proposed on a 12 per cent tax on wool. This follows the final agreement in the wool legislation between the Government and the Australian Democrats-and you might recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, the debate in June when that issue yoyoed back and forth between the Government and the Democrats for quite some time-that the tax remain at a maximum of 15 per cent. The operative level for this year, which will be set by regulation, will be 12 per cent.

By looking at the falling projection figures for production for this coming season, there will be an ability for the price to remain firm above all the projections that were made a couple of months ago. There will be an ability to sell significant amounts from the stockpile later in the season; therefore, 10 per cent is a realistic figure, given the current financial plight of wool growers.

During the wool debate, Minister Crean told Parliament that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics believed that a lower levy would result in lower wool prices and, therefore, lower returns to growers. But just four days after this speech by Minister Crean, ABARE issued a new set of figures to show that by reducing the wool tax from 15 per cent to 12 per cent wool growers would be $600 better off for the year. ABARE then claimed that not only would wool growers' returns be up as a result of the lower tax but also farmers involved in all broad acre industries would average an extra $300 a year. Of course, they would be even better off with a 10 per cent tax.

We should not be supporting a 12 per cent tax when farmers are financially troubled and have problems feeding and educating their children. I hope that the Government will respond to the notice for disallowance that I have given today and that we will see that regulation in fact disallowed, and that the Government will come forward with a regulation far more appropriately set at the figure of 10 per cent.

I also wish to talk briefly on the Government's alteration of the 3.5 per cent figure for promotion, replacing it completely with regulation. There was no notice or recognition given of that during the dying stages of debate in June. Therefore, the level of wool promotion, which is a significant part of the recovery of wool as a desired world fibre, is at the whim of the Government. That is an unsatisfactory basis for what is a very significant industry promotion activity. We are talking of about $180m a year, based on the reduced International Wool Secretariat budget for this coming year.

I am concerned about having an adequate financial base for promotion and the figure of 2.5 per cent that is to be allocated by the Government through regulation. We will not be attempting to alter that because, with no legislative basis behind the regulation, it is difficult to have an actual allocation for promotion on a stable and secure basis. I also believe that there is a case to be made for some outside evaluation of wool promotion and its effectiveness, particularly in these times of financial difficulty for wool growers.

In conclusion, the Opposition supports this legislation, However, we are concerned with the sloppy drafting, the inadequate promotion levy and, finally, we strongly object to the regulation of a 12 per cent tax on wool growers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the second reading speech on the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) delivered by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), we were told that it is recognised that as a result of the defect in the original legislation the wool statutory authorities have not had access since early July to the flow of wool tax funds which they should have had. Essentially, that is the reason for this legislation appearing before us today.

SPEECH.PARA: I do share the concern expressed by the coalition regarding the need for this legislation. However, I do not share the coalition's naive belief that the tax rates can be disallowed and that all will be wonderful after that. By disallowing the 12 per cent rate, we would be left in a situation which would not have the figure of 10 per cent sitting there prettily but, rather, the existing tax level under legislation of 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can re-regulate at 10 per cent.

—In response to Senator Tambling's interjection, of course they can re-regulate. It should be recognised that arriving at the 12 per cent level was a difficulty which has resounded around the wool industry for some months now. This level is recognised by all pragmatic people as being the only one which could be obtained. To disallow that would be naive in the extreme. We do not share that position with the coalition. That was all as a matter of aside.

SPEECH.PARA: What we do share is the understanding that this legislation has to be passed as soon as possible to clear up the mess which has been recognised by both the Government and the coalition. We do not dispute that recognition. We support this legislation and hope that it can be passed as expeditiously as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, I would like to support the comments of my colleague Senator Tambling and add some of my own. Where we are at now is tidying up the sad throes of what happened in the last hours of the autumn sitting. Once again, in primary industry legislation, as in other legislation, sloppy and careless drafting has created a situation where we need to have this Bill back before us. It certainly does no credit to those people responsible for it. For a period, once again this situation has disadvantaged the industry although, as other speakers have noted, I note that the Government is going to pick up the interest cost for this period.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to spend some of time with regard to the tax levels and the position which we arrived at in the last sitting. What we arrived at in the legislation was not a tax of 12 per cent, which is what many people interpreted and tried to sell it as, but a 15 per cent tax with the promise by the Government that in the first year it would be set at 12 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —One year only.

—Yes, 12 per cent for the one year. I also reiterate, in supporting Senator Tambling in terms of the regulations, that the position we adopted at that particular time is being vindicated day by day as we move into the wool selling season. I put on the public record that figures from the Wool Realisation Commission, show that which are available on a weekly basis, show that in the six weeks from 1 July just over 100,000 bales of wool have been sold at a value of $66,452,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The position that the coalition adopted at that time-in terms of the package that we put before the House of Representatives and the Senate, that is, in terms of meeting a 10 per cent tax regime-was that there was a necessity for $76m worth of wool to be released by the Commission, from the stockpile, to the trade at a minimum price of 475c per kilogram clean. Since that time we have seen a price significantly above that, and it remains significantly above that. There is no logical reason to believe that it is not going to remain significantly above that. I would also point out that the outlook in the medium and longer term, with the developments that are occurring elsewhere in the world, vindicates our particular position. The futures market also vindicates our particular position.

It is not necessary to put a greater tax impost on the industry than is required to do the job. I again ask the Government why, when it set a seven-year realisation program, when the first two years' requirements have already been met, it is now necessary at a time of extreme recession, if not depression, in much of rural Australia, to continue with a high taxing regime in the wool industry. It is having a dramatic impact on the ability of wool producers and the businesses that supply the infrastructure to survive. It can only mean one thing, in terms of our current position, that the Government wishes to get as many people as possible out of the wool industry in the near future.

If we recalculate the figures now in light of what has happened and make some further projections in terms of the realisation of wool and the wool price, we see that it is not necessary even to maintain a 10 per cent tax to do the job that is required. One must question the motives of the Government in terms of the future of individuals within the wool industry. When we come to our replies to the Budget, I shall delve into that a little more. The other point I want to raise is the decision of the Minister to fiddle around with the promotion levy percentage. No indication was given in this chamber or the other place, nor were discussions held about it with the wool industry. It was an arbitrary, unnecessary decision announced out of the blue. Once again, one must question the motives of the Government in taking this step.

One thing that I have been critical of about the Wool Corporation in the past is our effort in marketing and promoting our wool. Not only was it unnecessary to take this arbitrary decision when it was taken but it also indicated a lack of confidence in the Government's position on the wool industry. It seems that the Government is hell-bent on getting the stockpile down and reducing the debt regardless of the medium and long term consequences for the industry. It is necessary to analyse our promotion and marketing efforts. It is necessary to have a very close look at the operations of the International Wool Secretariat. However, that does not mean that we should fiddle around with the promotion levy percentage, which has been an industry standard and agreed by the industry for many years.

I know that other people will get up in this place and say, `They have reserves. They will top up from those particular reserves'. That is not the point. The point is, firstly, that it was not necessary in terms of what is required to do the job in regard to realisation from the stockpile and, secondly, that it indicates a lack of confidence by the Government in terms of the promotion and marketing of Australian wool.

Today good news has come out of the Soviet Union. It certainly appears, at least at this stage, to be back on track in moving to become a much freer place and a democratic society. I would suggest very strongly that Australia should be making an all-out effort to get our wool and other products moving back into the Soviet Union and to get the wheels of industry turning again. The Soviets have been and will continue to be a very important trading partner, particularly in terms of wool and wheat.

I believe that it is not necessary in the wool industry to have a 12 per cent tax to do what has to be done; it is not necessary to put that additional pressure on individual woolgrowers around the country, and in particular in my State of Western Australia where the level of farm debt on an average farm is significantly higher than it is in other States. One must question the long term and medium term motives of the Government's position on the wool industry by having this level of tax over the heads of woolgrowers at this time in a free market. One must also question the Government's motives in fiddling around with the promotion levies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is the third wool Bill that we have had before us this year. People were aware that the legislation was about to be introduced. Certainly it was advised that this would be taking place when we had the last debate on this topic.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to move on to look at some of the comments made by Opposition senators. This week we have seen in our second largest wool purchaser a coup and a counter-coup, and we do not know what will happen in the USSR. We all sincerely hope that democracy will reign in that country, that it will be able to modernise its industry and to find the money to pay the $391m that it has already used in credits to buy the wool in relation to which both our countries have entered into an arrangement. We had a credit arrangement for some $400m; the Russians have already used an amount of $391m this year, and the year has not yet passed.

We have to ask the question: what effect will the coup have on their ability to continue manufacturing in future and on the stability of the USSR? We must also ask what effect it will have on some of the other countries in the European bloc. Furthermore, we must ask what effect the coup-and the successful overcoming of that coup by those seeking democracy-will have on China. That question has not been answered or discussed by the Opposition, yet Opposition senators are now saying that we should be lowering the tax on farmers.

I am very aware, as is every member of this Government, that people in the agricultural industry, especially those involved in wheat and wool, are having hard times. One does not have to be very bright to understand that, and we certainly do understand it. I remind Opposition members that they are basing their calculations on a particular set of figures. I recall from the previous debate in June that the figure of 600c a kilo was the basis of their calculations. I remind them that the figure, based on the sale of wool on the floor at this stage, is some 12 per cent less than the calculations used by the Opposition. This leads to a reduction in the amount of revenue that will be gained by the tax, but Opposition senators are not telling us how they will finance this yet again. I await with great interest the statement to be made by Dr Hewson at 3 o'clock this afternoon on his plans for an alternative Budget and how he will assist the wool industry and the wool sector. I doubt that we will hear anything from him on that matter.

At present, wool sales are softer. The pass-in rate for wool has increased this week; we only have to listen to the ABC to know that. We have been told-and it is a fact-that 100,000 bales in the stockpile have been sold. However, I add that this is the slow time of year for wool sales. Not much shearing has been undertaken in June and July, although it is starting in areas around here. We will see the big sales of wool taking place in October. What will be sold from the stockpile in October when there will be a lot more wool on the auction floor to be disposed of? We must dispose of the wool on the auction floor and not flood the market with wool from the stockpile because that will only make the price softer, the market more vulnerable and reduce the income of primary producers. It is very important for people to realise that the wool industry fluctuates and has peaks and troughs. We are only now coming out of a low shearing time in Australia.

I do not intend to speak for very long, but I think it is important that we do not raise false expectations for wool growers and that we set a tax figure that can be lived up to and that does not have to be justified or tampered with at short notice. Setting lower figures for the wool tax might be all right for five minutes, but what will happen in the longer term? Those opposite are basing their assessments on a whole set of assumptions. They are being typical economists. Economists have three assumptions as the basis for the two figures they wish to arrive at.

Let us not have this attempt to raise and lower the expectations of wool growers. Let us give wool growers some stability in their industry so that they know the market will not be flooded with wool from the stockpile and they will be able to sell their wool at the best price on the market floor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. I did not expect a primary industries Bill to be back so soon in the Budget session. As Senator West also pointed out, this is the third debate on this subject that we have had in a short time.

SPEECH.PARA: Why does the Government only ever have Senator West to speak on rural matters? I admire her fortitude in carrying the whole load of the Government in speaking on these matters. She must be an aspirant for the front bench. A most important industry for Australia in earning export income is agriculture, along with our mining industry, but some of the statements that Senator West made makes me wonder whether she will ever get to the front bench. The figures she gave for shearing dates and the supply of wool must have come from the Orange workers' club. She should understand that, especially in Western Australia and South Australia, most shearing is done in late August and early September. She is wrong when she says that no shearing is being undertaken at present.
It is no wonder that we are back here. I refer to the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) when he said:
. . . the Senate will recall that a package of urgent legislation . . . was passed in the last hours of the Autumn Sittings.

We all remember the end of the autumn session quite clearly because it was a shambles. After the legislation had been defeated, I think for the second time, the Government front bench was in disorder: the Manager of Government Business (Senator McMullan) did not know what to do and Senator Cook was all at sea until Mr Crean came up and reorganised them. I do not manage business on our side, but I would have shut the Senate down at that time and sent the Government away to really work out what it wanted to do. The wool tax that is collected after but deducted before 1 July cannot flow through to the right account, and that is the reason we are back here.

While we are discussing this Bill and harking back to those days, I point out that the Government, in dealings with the Australian Democrats and the Wool Council of Australia on the evening leading up to that debate, did not mention that there would be a reduction in wool promotion from 3 1/2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent. The Government was aware of it; I do not know whether the Democrats were aware of it; and the Australian Wool Council told me that it was partly aware of it, but we were not informed. That was a ridiculous situation that kept vital information away from all the Parliament. The Government's adviser can smile, but it is a fact that we were not aware of that situation. It proved that what Senator Bell thought he had gained that night was just one big fiddle. The Government gave to us with one hand and took with the other. So I am annoyed with the Minister and the Government. The Democrats were probably not aware either, so they should be looking at the reasons why we were not told. I will give them the benefit of the doubt that they were completely in the dark.

The reduction in the long term might not be such a bad idea because I believe that there has been a certain amount of wastage in promotion. Senator Tambling mentioned earlier that some outside private enterprise firm of consultants should look into the amount allocated for promotional activities and see whether it has been spent in the right direction. However, we will debate that issue again at another time.

I now believe that we can look forward to more competence in the wool industry. In the two months since we were debating this legislation there has been a big change in the clearances on the floor. The price has eased back but not by a large amount. As has already been pointed out by Senator Crane, the stockpile is moving faster than expected.

I was in Eastern Europe with a delegation during the parliamentary break. We had a look at the woollen mills of Poland while we were there and saw that they were vastly out of date. But the Polish are very keen to put in new machinery if other nations can help them and they are very keen for Australia to set up bilateral arrangements in the wool trade. I can see that there will be a great demand for woollen products in Eastern Europe if wool can be processed in a suitable way there. But with the factories those countries have at present, they certainly will not be able to do it. They hope to compete with Italy, Germany and Japan in the short term. I believe that they cannot. I told them when I was there that they should concentrate on manufacturing products that would be suitable for those colder climates.

Confidence has returned to the wool industry. Senator West said a little earlier that we should not be increasing or decreasing the hopes of wool growers. Wool growers have shown confidence in the industry and that is proven when we look at the prices being paid in the saleyards. One and a half year-old bare shorn wethers in April, May or even as early as February were fetching about $3. Last week in Merredin they fetched nearly $20. Old ewes are now selling for around $7 or $8 whereas only a few months ago they were in the shooting category. I believe that the growers have their confidence back. They do not rely on what we say or do not say about their confidence in their industry.

I know that we will have another debate on the regulations a little later, so I will reserve my opinions and arguments as to why we could have done with the 10 per cent levy for which we argued so forcibly when the debate centred on that point. I believe that the passage of time in the two months since that debate has proven that we were right, but we will debate that issue when the regulations come before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are debating the correct levy for the wool growers. Senator West, in her contribution, mentioned that the Opposition's figures referred to 600c per kilo for clean wool. I categorically deny that, and Hansard will show that when we put down our figures, which were never doubted by anyone, our figure was 475c a kilo for clean wool. Our second important figure was that we believed $76m worth of wool should be sold from the stockpile.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at those two figures under the current situation, we find that the present price is 540c for clean wool. We have already sold 100,000 bales from the stockpile to the value of $66m this season, so we are far ahead of what we put up as very conservative figures. Our very conservative figures resulted in a 9.1 per cent levy, which is not even 10 per cent. We had 0.9 per cent cushion effect.

Senator West also spoke of the coup in the USSR and said that because of that coup, which has already been reversed, the Government saw it as necessary to have a 12 per cent levy. If, because of a coup, the Government saw it necessary to put up tax and every other levy imposed on people in the community, we would have chaos in this country. There is no need for growers to have to pay any more levy on their wool than what we set originally at 10 per cent. We know that wool production, even on our own estimation, is down further for the next season. Senator West did not mention that.

The position of wool growers and the agricultural community generally is so dreadful at the moment that the Government saw fit to introduce in its Budget special welfare conditions for growers. That is because the Government taxes them so heavily and has put the levy up unnecessarily high. The Government takes with one hand and gives back as welfare with the other. It is high time this Government got off people's backs, let them work and produce and not tax them out of existence. The Government should not continue with that additional, unnecessary 2 per cent levy, after very obvious figures have been brought to its attention.

Senator Tate, who is taking responsibility for this Bill, is well aware that we have heavy drought conditions in Tasmania. The farmers are presently unable to get wheat from the Wheat Board to feed their sheep. They are paying more than $185 a tonne for wheat plus delivery to feed their sheep-not to make bread for human consumption, but to feed their sheep.

Senator Tate knows that, he should be aware of that situation, yet he is taking responsibility for this Bill and telling those farmers that they will have to pay an additional 2 per cent levy, which is totally unnecessary, in order to foot the bill of the stockpile. The wool has been selling far better than we had anticipated. Our original figures were very conservative and they produced a 9.1 per cent levy. Those figures have now proved to have been too conservative. We are doing far better than we had anticipated and, as a result, the levy should be 10 per cent.

If the situation deteriorates, as Senator West says it could, with a worldwide collapse, the Government would be able to increase the levy. But the Government has chosen to get rid of the small farmers that it believes should be got rid of. Because the Government will not survive, it has chosen the easiest way to get rid of the farmers and give them a special welfare handout. Honourable senators on that side of the chamber may well believe a handout is the best way to keep the people under control; we believe that a hand-up, not a handout, is essential.

I have just been given the new figures for feed wheat in Tasmania. As I have said, last June it cost $185 per tonne. Does Senator Tate know what we are presently paying in Tasmania for wheat to feed the sheep? We are now paying $230 per tonne plus freight. If the Minister believes the small wool growers can survive paying that in a situation of drought, while the Government is levying 2 per cent more than is necessary, all I can say is that he is trying desperately to get rid of the small wool grower and trying to create just a group of large wool growers which would continue to be happy paying the higher levy in the short term because it knows that it would survive anyway.
I intend to speak only very briefly now because we will have an opportunity later next week to talk more fully about this legislation and the regulation that is to come before the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is really a major embarrassment to the Government because, in essence, the draftsmen, those in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) have allowed, through very sloppy drafting, burdens to be put on the wool industry which simply should not have occurred. The legislation was rushed through last session and has now prevented the new wool bodies from collecting some $90m worth of wool tax. The result has been an additional cost to the Government in the form of extra expenses associated with forgone interest and additional interest costs on borrowed funds. The Government also has to pay interest for the period of delay in the wool tax payments.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is only fair that those who made the mistake should now bear the brunt of the costs of rectifying it. It is an indictment on a government which, from the beginning to the end, has bungled the wool industry debate. Its entire approach to the wool industry, going right back to the first rumblings of a lowering of the floor price, has been sloppy, careless and costly. The wool industry is Australia's premier industry and this is how this Government treats its premier industry. As I have said, it is an indictment on the Government. As Senator Crane has said, it does no credit at all to the Government in these very tough times.

The wool industry is still in crisis. We have uncertainty in wool sales, major problems in the disposal of old ewes, and a major crisis in the income levels for thousands of growers. Some growers will have income drops of 50, 60, 70 and 80 per cent compared with last year. The Government's attitude is to say, `Well, tough luck'. The Government has provided nothing in the Budget which it brought down a couple of days ago other than an admission of failure.

Look what the Government did in that Budget: a 24 per cent reduction in funding for primary industries and energy from $2.32 billion down to $1.76 billion; a reduction in road funding of $36m in real terms on top of the 30 per cent reduction by the Hawke Government in the last seven years; and a 7.2 per cent increase in fuel tax collection this year, following on from the 90 per cent increase in the last seven years. All of these things slug the wool growers. There is a reduction in the tax zone rebate in real terms for the fifth year in a row; a 34.4 per cent increase in primary industry charges for people who can ill afford to pay many of the charges which are not even competitive; and an increase in fringe benefits tax to 48.5 per cent, which will further discourage people from moving to remote areas of Australia to work. There are no incentives in the health area; there is an assets test on family allowance; and a predicted increase of about 100,000 people on the unemployment heap.

Despite all the help that the Government could have given to the people of Australia and all of the things it could have done to get the macro situation right in Australia, it has done nothing to get incentive back into the rural areas. The Government has no answers for the wool growers; I believe it has given up trying. All that it has offered is more money to help wool growers get out of primary production-in other words, more money for rural assistance. That is really admitting failure rather than giving money up front and giving incentive and help to people so that they do not need rural assistance at the end of the day. The Government has offered no incentives, no direction and no alternatives.

The former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, bungled the industry. He was very well liked-he is one of the most personable and likeable people around-but as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he presided over what was once a great industry and let it fall gradually into decay.

This week the Government has once again demonstrated very clearly what it thinks of rural Australia. I believe this Government thinks that the people who live in country areas just do not count. We have diminishing numbers of farmers and those diminishing numbers are obviously of little consequence to this Government at the moment. It does not care about the children who have been forced to pull out of school because their parents cannot afford to send them to school any more. It has no answers to what happens to them. I believe incomplete education will create difficulties when they are seeking jobs. We talk about the clever country, yet we will have a shrinking rural economy which will be unlikely to have room to employ people. This Government is building a problem of massive proportions in the bush. For those people in the bush, it is no longer a recession; it is a depression. I have not seen anything on the horizon-either in the Budget this week or in the attitude of the Government-which will get things going again. I will quote a few things that Mr Sinclair said during the debate in the other place. He said:

I do not think many people understand the extent to which wool incomes and wheat incomes-two of the primary sources of income in rural Australia-are going to continue to contract. Farmers will find when they get their annual income this year that their expectations are going to be significantly underrealised.

That is how it is. I have a son working a property; I do the budgets with him. It would be a good idea if a lot of people forgot about listening to and reading what ABARE says is happening out on the farms and went to see what is actually happening to the farmers of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Senator Panizza knows what happens in Western Australia, and Senator Walters knows what happens in Tasmania.
—The women bear the brunt of it.

—Yes, the women bear the brunt of what happens. It is really quite something. A lot of people should get out of their cosy little holes in Canberra and go out to the country areas and meet with real farmers, not with farmer groups necessarily. They should meet with real farmers-not the ones who want to set up for a television camera-who just want to tell the politicians, the parliamentarians, how it really is. Mr Sinclair went on:

SPEECH.PARA: Without going back into it all, we should remember that the crisis in the wool industry is largely the result of decisions taken by this Labor Government.

It was this Government which put the uncertainty into it in the first place. The new President of the National Farmers Federation recently called for woolgrowers to `put industry and political trauma behind them and to concentrate on rebuilding their industry'. These are words of courage and of leadership but, frankly, how can growers put the political trauma behind them when the Government which writes the legislation keeps bungling it? How can growers put industry difficulties and income instability behind them when they face the consequences of the collapse of their industry every day?

This Government, I believe, ought to have provided in the Budget this week incentives and opportunities for growth and investment. It did not. Instead, it gave us despair, a deficit, a predicted 10.5 per cent unemployment rate, a tax higher than what it needed to be on the woolgrowers and a promotion levy less than what it has been in the past. I support Senator Tambling, who led this debate for the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate to which many members of the Opposition have contributed. I am sure that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, will avidly read their contributions and, while not necessarily agreeing with what they have said, nonetheless, respect the sincerity with which the contributions have been put.

SPEECH.PARA: The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is fondly called the `the Wool Bill'. The Bill enables wool tax imposed on wool sold prior to 30 June this year, but collected by the Commonwealth after 1 July, to be paid to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the Wool Research and Development Council and the Australian Wool Corporation, as is appropriate in those circumstances.

The Bill also provides for the Commonwealth to pay interest at a rate determined by the Minister for the duration of the delay because the statutory authorities will have been without the flow of wool tax moneys which they should have had since early July. In addition, the Bill includes amendments to give effect to the Commonwealth's policy of matching research and development funds raised by primary industries up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production or the amount of wool tax collected, whichever is the lesser.

The Opposition has agreed to give the Bill a speedy passage, and we thank it for that. The Government has a responsibility to take prudent decisions on the rate of the wool tax to balance the best interests of woolgrowers and taxpayers of this country. The rate of wool tax is only one part of the Government's overall strategy for reducing the wool stockpile and restructuring the industry on a sustainable basis.

It is totally simplistic to argue that reducing the wool tax from 15 per cent to 10 per cent is of benefit to the grower. If the tax is less, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission has less to operate with. The Commission then has to put more wool on to the market, which, of course, depresses the market and reduces the returns to growers. It is therefore wrong when it is said that woolgrowers would be better off with a 10 per cent tax. More importantly, because the Senate cannot make an amendment to a money Bill, the intention of the Opposition's disallowance, if successful, would raise the tax to 15 per cent. With those remarks in reply to the second reading contributions of honourable senators, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
(Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has one amendment to clause 9 which has been circulated. After dealing with that matter I would like to answer some of Senator Spindler's queries relating to clauses 10, 14 and 15 which he signalled in the second reading debate yesterday. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 9, page 4, paragraph (a), proposed paragraph 15(2) (d), lines 28 and 2, omit ``published by the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation''.
This particular amendment omits an incorrect reference in the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1991 to telephone directories published by the Australian Overseas Telecommunications Corporation.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions to ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the query that I foreshadowed in the second reading debate yesterday about clause 10 of the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill. I asked the Minister how the Government proposes to deal with a situation where the employee is of the view that to make a request through internal channels will damage him or her professionally or personally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ought to give a little background to this. The Government amendment, which makes it a requirement that requests by public servants seeking information relating to their employment matters should first of all be dealt with through internal avenues, arose from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Basically, that Committee accepted that Public Service guidelines provide a less costly and less formal means for public servants to seek access to staff records and that they should be encouraged to use Public Service guidelines in most cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 10 of the Bill provides that a public servant must use internal agency procedures to get access to personnel records before using the Freedom of Information Act to seek such access. Clause 10 does include some safeguards to prevent agencies abusing the provision. If the agency does not make a decision on access under its internal procedures within 30 days of a request by a public servant, that person may then make an FOI request. If the agency refuses to grant access under its internal procedures, the applicant can make an FOI request and pursue the appeal rights provided by the FOI Act.

It is difficult to get the balance right. I understand part of the concern that Senator Spindler is expressing, but the Senate Committee envisaged that the balance would be better served by encouraging public servants to use Public Service guidelines rather than the FOI Act which, as I say, ought to be the last resort after internal agency procedures have been attempted but have not produced the information sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this case I believe that the Government's drafted amendment considerably exceeds the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee said that employees should be encouraged in most cases to use internal procedures first. The Government's amendment puts a clear and unequivocal obligation on the employee to do that. I believe that it is far in excess of the measure recommended by that Committee. I would like to pursue this matter with the Minister a little further and ask whether there is any way that regulations can be provided, in view of this amendment, which make it feasible for an employee still to be heard through the FOI process if he or she has not first used internal channels.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to seek advice as to whether it would be possible to deal with the concern that Senator Spindler has raised through a well drafted regulation made under the Act. I undertake to pursue that and inform him as to whether that is possible and, if it is possible, whether it will be done.

—I have a second inquiry to pursue. It relates to clause 14. I ask the Minister, firstly, in view of the fact that an agency is now able to delete material from documents on the ground that the material is irrelevant, will the applicant be advised that the material has been deleted because it was considered to be irrelevant? Secondly, what recourse, if any, has the applicant if that person wishes to dispute the judgment of the agency concerned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has ruled that the existing Freedom of Information Act requires an agency to decide whether to disclose the whole of the document covered by a request, even if it is clear that the applicant is interested only in obtaining access to part of the material in the document. This has disadvantages. The agency is required to use resources in making a decision about disclosure of material which it knows the applicant has not asked for, and the applicant is required by the FOI charges regulations to pay $20 for every hour spent by the agency in reaching a decision on the disclosure of the material that that person has not asked for which, obviously, is rather odd.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, the Committee recommended that the FOI Act be amended to permit agencies to delete material that is irrelevant. Clause 14(a) of the Bill amends section 22 of the Freedom of Information Act to allow an agency to delete material from documents where the material is irrelevant to the subject matter of the applicant's request.

The Senate Committee-we are now getting to Senator Spindler's concern-also recommended that decisions to delete material on the ground of irrelevancy be reviewable. The Bill, therefore, provides that the applicant must be informed that material has been deleted on the ground of irrelevancy and provides that the applicant may seek review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Commonwealth Ombudsman. New subsections 55(1) and 57(1) are relevant to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply. I wish to raise a final query with reference to clause 15 which permits an agency to refuse a request which would involve a substantial and unreasonable diversion of the agency's resources. My question is: what recourse has the applicant if he or she disagrees with a finding of the agency?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before answering that question specifically, I should indicate that section 24 does not simply allow refusal of a request merely because it involves a substantial workload. The agency must be able to show that the request would unreasonably divert its resources.

SPEECH.PARA: There are various safeguards to prevent abuse by agencies. There is the requirement for consultation with the applicant. A statement of reasons has to be given to the applicant indicating that the processing would be substantial and, therefore, unreasonable in terms of the diversion of agency resources. New subsections 55(1) and 57(1) will allow an applicant to challenge the agency's decision as to whether the workload is unreasonable before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Commonwealth Ombudsman.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In yesterday's discussion on the Quarantine Amendment Bill, a number of issues of quite a substantive nature were raised by me, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Brownhill, Senator Bell, Senator Macdonald and Senator Knowles. I believe that before we continue with the detailed consideration of the Bill in the committee stage we should hear the response of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Cook) to those questions, challenges and issues raised in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook was not able to be present at the conclusion of the second reading debate last night. There was considerable debate with the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who was the duty Minister at the time. He was unable to address all of the issues that were raised. I look to the appropriate portfolio Minister to give a response to the considerable number of issues that were raised in the second reading debate before we proceed with the committee stage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take that in the form of a question as to whether I will add to the closing remarks of the duty Minister last evening, Senator Collins, in replying to the second reading debate. I do not have before me at the moment any indication of what specifically may have been raised which requires there to be an additional reply. I note, however, that the occasion for the second reading debate has now passed and the obligation upon the Government to make any remarks passed with it. Unless there can be more specific questions put, such as questions that Senator Tambling may feel are so burning that they require a more specific reply, then to invite me to reply carte blanche to unspecified matters is a bit unusual and, in these circumstances, with due respect, a bit unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not consider my comments to be at all unfair. In fact, I find what the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Cook) says to be quite insulting to the Senate. All of these matters are set out in Hansard, which is now readily available and has been distributed. The Minister would have had access to the Senate pinks last night in order to follow through all the issues.
