SPEECH.PARA: I find it insulting to the Senate that the Minister has not been able to be briefed on a considerable number of issues raised by, as I mentioned earlier, six senators in the debate on the second reading. It was quite within the parameters of reason that the duty Minister last night, who had officers present, could have addressed each of the issues raised. Similarly, the officers present could have quite adequately briefed the Minister overnight.

I am sure that some other honourable senators will now want to come into the chamber and perhaps regurgitate the issues and questions they raised and the challenges to be met by the Minister. I give an example of some of the points I raised. I quote from Hansard:

. . . I will certainly ask the Minister to substantiate the criteria that he would wish to see applied by AQIS, particularly with regard to matters affecting the duration of quarantine, fees at the commencement of service and the acceptance of fee fluctuations not to exceed the consumer price index over the corresponding period. There needs to be a clearly established relationship which sets out with the intending client a clear and agreed set of criteria in respect of conditions that would prevail throughout the agreed service period. I will certainly ask the Minister to give consideration to this matter and for those organisations that have dealings with AQIS to have a watertight contract.

I certainly look for a response with regard to the way in which the contracts and arrangements could be brought to bear. I then raised a number of issues that were not specifically related to the impact of this legislation on the goat area but which will be affected and caught up by the legislation. Those issues will have impacts on plant importation by horticulturalists in northern Australia. I spent considerable time in the debate outlining that. I said:
I hope that the Minister will be in a position in his response to address a number of these issues . . .

It is important that we pursue those issues. I hoped that the Minister would have taken the opportunity overnight to have been adequately briefed on those issues because I am well aware that AQIS and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy have been challenged for some considerable time. In fact, in the Northern Territory there has recently been a review of the post-entry plant quarantine facilities. Honourable senators would be well aware of the recommendations of that report because they have received wide media publicity. Specifically, there were five recommendations. I will read them and ask for a response:
RECOMMENDATION 1
That a Government Post-entry Quarantine (PEQ) facility continues to be located in Darwin.
RECOMMENDATION 2
2.1 That one or more new PEQ screenhouses be constructed to withstand cyclonic conditions, utilising the most appropriate design and equipment taking into account local and worldwide expertise.
2.2 That houses Nos 3 and 4 be further substantially modified and equipped to improve humidity, air movement and temperature.
RECOMMENDATION 3

That the responsibility for management and operation of the growing of plants in the PEQ facility be transferred from Quarantine and Inspection Branch (QIB) to DPIF Plant Industry, together with appropriate resources, under supervision of QIB to ensure that quarantine security is not jeopardised.
RECOMMENDATION 4
That AQIS consider insecticidal dipping rather than Methyl bromide fumigation as the standard treatment on arrival for tropical fruit trees of unknown sensitivity to fumigation.
RECOMMENDATION 5
5.1 That the system for charging for importation and PEQ of plants be changed.
5.2 That a reasonable fee for services performed on arrival be payable at that time.
5.3 That a further fee be payable in respect of plants which successfully establish in PEQ and that no further fee be payable in respect of plants which fail to establish.

The Cattle Council of Australia, in correspondence with Minister Griffiths, has also brought matters to the Government's attention. I have certainly seen a copy of correspondence to the shadow Minister for primary industry, Mr Bruce Lloyd, in which the Cattle Council proposed a possible amendment, which we did not proceed with, after consultation with the Clerks, because of certain difficulties. It is the basis of the information that I am seeking from the Minister. I quote from the request of the Cattle Council letter:

``The provider of quarantine services (AQIS) will establish in concert with the intending client a clear and agreed set of criteria in respect of conditions that will prevail throughout the agreed service period.
The criteria would include . . .
These are points that I made in my speech in the second reading debate yesterday, with requests. It continues:
* the duration of quarantine
* the fees at commencement of service
* acceptance of fee fluctuations not to exceed the Consumer Price Index (CPI) over the corresponding period.''

I have just highlighted a number of examples of questions that I posed. Five other senators raised in the second reading debate issues that ought properly to be addressed, and I look forward to the Minister's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in the nature of a somewhat mildly extraordinary performance by the Opposition. The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to amend the Quarantine Act to enable the Quarantine Service to hold animals kept in quarantine until such time as the owner of those animals has paid the bill for having them retained in quarantine.
—There is no argument on that.

—In that case, let us deal with the business of this chamber. Senator Tambling has raised a whole series of matters dealing with quarantine. This is not a fishing expedition; it is not a general debate on quarantine. It is a debate about a specific amendment to a Bill. If honourable senators wish to pursue other matters about quarantine, of which there is a multitude-and some of which are now being misrepresented in the form of questions-let them do so in a proper forum, not during debate on this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that there is a practice in this chamber that when a Bill about X comes along everyone speaks about the rest of the alphabet and not about X. The Bill before the chamber provides a vehicle to sound off opinions about every damn thing under the sun. However, the purpose of parliamentary debates on Bills is to make remarks related to the legislation, believe it or not. Many of the questions that Senator Tambling has just set out do not deal with the matter before the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they do.

—No, they do not. They deal with general issues of quarantine. Senator Tambling knows that shortly, in the Estimates committee process, he will have a chance to pursue some of these matters. He knows that he will be able to pursue those things when the Estimates are discussed in this chamber in the Committee of the Whole. He knows that he can pursue his questions now by putting them on notice and having them answered by the relevant Minister. He knows that he can pursue his questions now by asking them of me, without notice, during Question Time. He can find many other vehicles to air what grievances he believes exist, if he so wishes.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling pretends that there is now an obligation on the Government to answer all of those extraneous questions which are unrelated to the legislation and implies that, until we do so, he will somehow obfuscate or carry on. I will not be intimidated by that. Let us get on with the business before the Chair. If he wishes to raise matters relating to the committee stage of this Bill, I will deal with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fairly obvious that the Minister played no part in the debate last night and was not even interested in it. He is now trying to escape any responsibilities he might have in this area. I guess that he has no real interest in primary industries in any case. It is fairly clear that he took no notice of what anyone said. It should be obvious to him, if he listened to the speeches-or if he had been advised by the duty Minister-that a lot of the matters raised by my colleagues and me have consequences. They relate to this Bill and this Bill has consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised at length-and if the Minister paid any attention he will know the background to it, so I will need only to mention it briefly today-the question of whether it would be possible for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to propagate bud wood and grow lots of trees while it was in quarantine. In that way, when the bud wood came out of quarantine it would be available for immediate sale, rather than having to wait two years and then an extra three years-which might be possible.

I guess one of the reasons why this was not possible before was that the Quarantine and Inspection Service may have been a bit concerned that it would never be paid for doing this. This Bill is all about that. The Quarantine and Inspection Service could hold the trees until they were paid for or, if they were not paid for, it could sell the trees-and there is a ready market in the instance I talk of. It could readily sell those trees and get its money back. In so doing, it would be helping the Australian stone fruit industry. It would be allowing the Australian stone fruit industry to get its produce, its new varieties, off the ground and in competition with overseas fruit two or three years earlier than now applies. That is a very legitimate question. It is directly related to this Bill, and I would like the Minister's comment on it.

The other major point I raise, although it is not quite as directly related to this Bill-again, it is related to stone fruit, which is related to that other matter-is why Australian growers are banned from using antibiotic sprays on their stone fruit. I understand that the reason for that-although it is not quite in this Minister's portfolio-is that the Government does not want Australians eating antibiotic spray because it builds up our resistance to antibiotics, so we ban it in Australia. That puts Australian producers at a severe disadvantage. But if the reason for banning the spray was correct, why do we then allow the sale on Australian shelves of overseas fruit that has been treated with antibiotic sprays, and not too long ago-not long enough for it to break down? We are still eating the antibiotic spray, but on foreign fruit. Our fruit producers are put at a severe disadvantage as a result. That was a subsidiary point which I made in my speech that the Minister might like to comment upon also.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the Minister, let me say that the Minister has raised the question of relevance and I think that the Committee should take account of the comments that he made. The last matter mentioned by Senator Macdonald was not at all relevant to the Bill before us.
—Mr Chairman, do you concede that the first matter was relevant?
—I was not making a comment on the first matter; I was making a comment on the second matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I like to believe that my record in this chamber is one of being as helpful as I can to members of the Opposition. But if we want to have an outing this morning and raise every matter dealing with quarantine--
—They are consequences of the legislation.

—They are not consequences of the legislation. It is well known that quarantine is a controversial matter in rural Australia because there is a major lobby in rural Australia which would like to use the Quarantine and Inspection Service as a non-tariff block to the entry of goods that are in competition with products produced in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an open debate. We do not have to have ohs and woes and interjections about that. That is a fact; we all know that is the case. We can have a debate about that; we can have a debate about bud wood; and we can have a debate about whether we transform the Quarantine and Inspection Service-which is retained at taxpayers' expense as a service to protect Australians from the importation of disease, a service that quarantines items coming into Australia so that we can be sure that they do not transmit disease-into a service that does those things as well as farming, propagating and breeding the particular items or animals that come in. That would change the very nature of the Quarantine Service quite dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest, in all humility, that if honourable senators here are serious about wanting to pursue those questions, then we can have a stint in the chamber in which those matters are raised and I will deal with them in the way I have; or they can pursue the matters seriously by making the proper representations in the proper way. If honourable senators were to adopt the second of the two alternatives, it seems to me that that would be a more responsible course than if they simply used these items as a way of disrupting the proceedings of this debate and making a political point. That seems to be an exploitation of the seriousness of the issues that they raise and a perversion of those issues for political purposes, rather than an effort to try to resolve those issues in a serious and constructive way.

So I make this plea: let us get on with this Bill and deal with the charges elements of it. I am sure that the Minister will be available for discussion of the matters that honourable senators wish to raise. If they then wish to ask about those matters in the form of questions on notice and receive written replies, I am sure that he will oblige them in that process-nay, he is bound to. If honourable senators want to pursue these matters in the Estimates hearings, that is also a forum in which they can do so. That process is only about one month away.

Meanwhile, the Bill before this chamber is about people who can take animals out of quarantine without paying their bill, thus requiring the Quarantine Inspection Service to pursue them at law for the debt that they owe the Australian taxpayer and cart these people through the court systems at great delay and at considerable loss. It would seem to me that the ability of the Quarantine Service to hold on to those animals until people pay their bills, which is what this is about, might be something that this chamber can give expedition to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is trying to avoid answering questions which were legitimately addressed at the substance of what this Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991 is about. To ensure that we do stay with what is germane to the Bill, I point out that I referred to the Bills Digest in my speech on the second reading and I again refer to that journal to give guidance to what might be a relevant question.

SPEECH.PARA: During my speech I quoted from that Bills Digest and I quote two words again. I accept the explanation and agree that it is an accurate explanation of what the main provisions of this Bill are about. In writing about two clauses, clauses 3 and 4, the Bills Digest mentions the words `the expenses'. My question and the question that a number of importers want answered is `which expenses?'. Before they enter into an agreement with AQIS, they want to know what expenses we are talking about. That is not an irrelevant question; it is entirely germane to this because it is of great concern to somebody embarking upon an importation program or somebody who is importing animals into Australia to know what expenses we are talking about. That is essentially the substance of the matter.

Senator Tambling quoted from a suggested amendment to this legislation which was put up by the Cattle Council and which was endorsed by us but unable to be delivered. We understand the reasons why. But although it is unable to be delivered, we want the concerns that were expressed in that attempt at an amendment answered here and now by the Minister. That is a legitimate question. I do not know where the Minister has run off to, but if we have frightened him away with the question, perhaps somebody else will be able to take up the battle for him. I have asked the question. That is all I can do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has misinterpreted a few of the questions. It surprises me that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has not actually briefed the Minister before he came into the chamber. The Minister made the point a minute ago, when replying to Senator Macdonald, that some of the questions were not relative to the Bill that is before us at the moment. But he did make the point that the fees are charged and then the Government can get those fees remunerated to it. I believe that my questions are quite relevant. In my speech yesterday I asked this question:

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether they were able to negotiate a price for the agistment of their stock in quarantine.

Surely if the importers are going to have to pay back fees for something, then they also should be able to know whether they can negotiate a price or whether it is a set price and one is going to cop it-I do not know what they are going to do. Maybe it would help if I stop for a minute so that the Minister can listen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the question. I have got two ears; I can listen with both of them.
—As long as the Minister listens with both ears and only talks with one mouth he will be right. Another question I asked the Minister in my speech was:

SPEECH.PARA: What opportunity has the importer to determine a fair and equitable price for the cost of boarding animals?

This is aside from actually agisting animals in quarantine. These are very serious questions. If one is going to get the money back afterwards it is all a part of it. If those fees are extortionate, obviously it is going to mean that someone will not be able to pay some of the fees afterwards. I also stated yesterday:
Maybe the Minister will be able to explain that at the committee stage.
I would have thought, with respect to the Minister's advisers, that the Minister would have come in today and answered that question. Another question I asked was:
In the event of a dispute, who actually will be the arbiter?

Who does one go to? Who is the person that an importer goes to if he believes that the fees have been unjustly charged; if the agistment rate is higher than it should be; if the boarding fees are higher than they should be; or if the animals are kept there longer than they should be. Who is going to be the arbiter? Further on in my speech I asked:
On the Government's side-
that is, looking after its interests-

what is to stop an importer running up a large bill and then, anticipating that the price at the subsequent auction of the livestock might be less than the import bills, waiting for the auction and paying the lower price?
That was another question. I then also asked:
Another area of the Bill that concerns me is that those who import the livestock are going to be at the mercy of whatever fees the Government chooses to levy.

That is precisely what has happened in the past. I would like the Minister to assure me on this aspect because he knows that I have had a long interest in this matter, going back to the time when the Minister was responsible for the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

The other thing that really astounds me is in respect of the interest charged. I believe that in previous cases it was 20 per cent. Is 20 per cent still the interest rate charged, is it bank rates, or does the Government have a special interest rate fee set? In the past I have asked why it has been set at 20 per cent. It is all part of this Bill.

Another question I asked was whether it is and whether it can be fair and equitable when there is no choice for people. It is a monopoly. The Australian Quarantine Inspection Service in Australia is a monopoly, and monopolies tend not to create an atmosphere of affordability or equity. Therefore, how can anyone get a guide as to what are fair and equitable fees in the quarantine timing? Everyone is being sincere. We are not trying to hold up the Minister or anyone else; we are just trying to get some facts and figures before we go further with the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some concerns which relate to the provisions of the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991 in so far as they concern the importation of sheep and goats. To some extent, they mirror the concerns of my National Party colleagues Senator Tambling and Senator Brownhill, but they are slightly different. Clause 3 of the Bill provides for the inclusion within section 64 of the principal Act, the Quarantine Act 1908, of subsection 3 which relates to the importer making an agreement with the Commonwealth in respect of the release of the plants, animals or goods.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsection 4, which is also contained in clause 3 of the Bill, provides for the payment of interest at a rate not exceeding 20 per cent per year. I am very concerned, however, that there seems to be no guideline within the Bill for the setting of that interest rate. It is clearly not by delegated legislation; there is supposed to be an agreement. I have been approached by importers of goats who have a concern that they are going to be held to ransom on the interest rate. Certainly, a ceiling of 20 per cent could easily become a rate of 20 per cent, should the Commonwealth so choose. The effect of this legislation means that one would not be allowed to import the animal if one did not make the agreement with the Commonwealth because one would not be able to have the animal in quarantine.

For that reason, I am very concerned that there is no mechanism here for setting the interest rate. Given that we could be talking about quite long periods of time in which animals may be in quarantine, I would appreciate the Minister's advice on the manner in which the interest rate is to be determined under the new subsections (3) and (4) of section 64 of the principal Act. That is my No. 1 concern.

My other concerns relate to the manner in which the charges will be determined because, again, we have importers dealing with a monopoly, which is the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I have no difficulty with that. However, there is no guarantee that the Quarantine and Inspection Service is necessarily running itself efficiently. One of the concerns, for example, is that if one has sheep or goats and they are breeding progeny in quarantine, they are held for a minimum of five years to determine whether they have scrapie. That is fine but, of course, one can get a substantial charge building up, especially when one could end up with as many as 30 to 40 animals for every one that was imported at the end of that five-year period.

We also need an assurance or some advice from the Minister on how the charges will be determined and whether the importers will be asked to pay for any inefficiencies that may exist within AQIS. That is of great concern when one talks about the increase in progeny over that five-year period in which progeny will be quarantined to wait to see whether there is any scrapie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell asked whether the syndicates were advised of the possibility of an increase in fees. Seminars were held by the Department in late August 1984 for the syndicates that were holding sheep and goats at the Torrens Island quarantine farm. At those seminars the syndicates, all importers and owners, were told that although it is intended that the annual fee remain at $75 per animal during the full quarantine period, circumstances may arise which will demand a review-that is, when costs substantially outstrip revenue collected-and that the Minister, therefore, reserves the right to increase this fee if it is deemed necessary. That answer to what formal advice was offered to the syndicates needs to be seen against the normal practice of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in setting its fees.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brownhill and Senator O'Chee asked questions about how the fees are determined; whether we know that the Quarantine Service is efficient; whether people are asked to pay for inefficiencies; and the interest rate charge and who determines it. I think that is the range of questions put.

The fee charged is a cost recovery fee. The Quarantine Service is a service provided to the Australian community to prevent foreign diseases coming into this country. For people importing animals or material, which may bear or run the risk of bearing foreign diseases, they import in the knowledge that there will be a quarantine requirement before they make the decision to bring into this country the particular animal or material.

The practice of the Quarantine Service is to advise people doing that in advance of what the charges would be so that they can make a commercial judgment, knowing what the charges are likely to be, as to whether it is a profitable enterprise for them to import this animal or material. That is the normal and usual practice. They know, if the animal or material is to be retained in quarantine for a period, what the reasonable charge will be and they can make a proper commercial assessment.

On the question of what interest rate charges are made, I have to say by way of explanation that the interest rate charge we are talking about is an interest on people who have not paid the fee. It is an interest on the outstanding moneys that ought to have been paid at the appropriate time when recovery is undertaken. We are not talking about an interest on people who pay fees at the appropriate time. We are talking about people who are in arrears and who ought to have paid but did not. If interest was not charged, a loss to the Department-that is, the taxpayer-would be made.

The interest that is charged at the present time is 20 per cent. It is not an interest charge that is determined by the Quarantine Service. It is an interest charge determined by movement in the appropriate interest rate scales and advised by the Department of Finance, which on all matters of cost recovery advises other department and government agencies on what the appropriate interest charge should be.

It is not some sort of charge invoked maliciously or with an intent to defraud or to steeple the charges upwards as a penalty. It is a charge arrived at by the Department of Finance and advised to the Quarantine Service. It is the sort of advice that the Department of Finance gives any government agency or department on the appropriate interest rate according to movements in interest rate scales.

The quarantine farm at Torrens Island in South Australia holds sheep and goats imported for the purposes of breeding, I think their owners would say with pride, exotic fibres in Australia for commercial gain. That is quite a proper undertaking and I have only praise for their enterprise, certainly no criticism.

The animals that are brought in are animals which, on reasonable biological evidence and evidence relating to their health and with the possibility of being hosts for other diseases, run the risk of introducing into Australia scrapie-a disease which would devastate sheep and goat flocks in this country. If this country travels on the sheep's back, clearly, a quarantine service should prevent any diseases which would devastate the back upon which we travel.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree.
—We agree, good.
—This doesn't apply only to goats on Torrens Island; it applies to all animals.
—Yes. But the specific issue, the one that has given rise to the need for the amendment, relates to the quarantine--
—But the legislation will affect all animals; that is what we are pursuing.

—Yes. But the outstanding example is the quarantine farm at Torrens Island. It is therefore useful to talk about real things rather than imaginary concepts because here is a real example of the operation of this charge.
—What else is it going to get in its net?

—I really fail to see the point of debating abstract theories when we have a real case before us, unless Senator Tambling wants to live in the abstract world and not the practical one, not the real world. It may well be that Senator Tambling does in fact live on another planet and not in the real world.
—I live in Australia.

—Yes. I should perhaps continue with my remarks. In the case of Torrens Island, these animals are in quarantine for eight years because it takes eight years to breed out the possibility of scrapie. During that time considerable charges have been made because considerable costs have been incurred. Not all of the costs have been recovered. Something in excess of 50 per cent of the charges have been borne by the Commonwealth-that is, by ordinary taxpayers-so that this program can be fulfilled and the exotic fibres that these entrepreneurs wish to blend in Australia can gain entry into Australia without damage to the rest of our flock. So the Australian taxpayer has borne a significant part of these charges-50 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, if I take the implication of the reference to what interest rate is being charged to defaulters on payment, I would point out that no allegation can be made that the Commonwealth has behaved in an unreasonable way. In fact, the contrary allegation could be made by taxpayers who believe that we have been bending over backwards to accommodate this program and that we should not have gone as far as we have. As I have answered the questions put to me by various honourable senators on this program, I think that we should now get on with the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I contend that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has not answered the question that I addressed to him. In fact, the briefing received by the Minister on the matter is inadequate and totally uninformative. The answer that he gave could have been deduced from the speech which I made during the second reading debate in his absence. A seminar was held at which importers were advised that the price per animal would change from $50 to $75. The importers had little complaint about that in the final wash-up. What they did complain about was the change from $75 to $311. That was not mentioned in the Minister's answer, nor was the method by which that change was addressed. The change was advised by press release and subsequent notice to the importers.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Brownhill has observed, there is little opportunity in this mechanism for the importers to approach an arbiter of any description, consult any other authority or have any redress over that alteration. If the Minister refers to my speech during the second reading debate, he will see mention of the fact that the case history takes the charges-by CPI increases and other means, whatever they are-now to be in excess of $400. In that process, as Senator Brownhill rightly observed, there is little or no opportunity for consultation, negotiation or arbitration of any description. That is the question-not $50 to $75, but $75 to $400-plus. When I referred to the expenses and asked what expenses we were talking about, that is what I meant.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other question that I do not think the Minister answered unless, as a result of his eloquence, I missed his answer. I asked whether one could enter into a contract when the stock goes in. Does one get a quote for the length of time involved? Will those concerned know about this under the new Bill and what is expected of them? In other words, the person who builds up this account will know what it will cost when the stock is first imported. I thank Senator Bell for supporting me and asking about the arbiter.
—Stock or plants.

—Stock or plants, that is right. A lot of people do not have any idea what they are letting themselves in for. If the Government slugs them at the other end or slugs them too hard when they have got the animals, plants or stock in there, so that at the end the money has to be recouped, it will be difficult for the Government, the taxpayers and the people who have the stock or plants.

—My concern is similar to that expressed by Senator Brownhill, but on a slightly different tack. From my understanding of the Minister's answer given a moment ago, the rate of charges will be advised to the importer at the time at which he enters into the agreement. Does that mean that the agreement will fix those rates of charges, or am I correct in taking it from what the Minister said that there may be a provision in the agreement for variance in the rate of charges? If that is so, is that done by consultation with the importer?
—Or limited to the CPI.

—Is it limited to the CPI, or is it something that the Commonwealth can choose to do on its own? If the purpose of entering into the arrangement is to facilitate a more commercial enterprise in the importation of plants and animals to improve the breeding stock within Australia, then it is very important that the agreement encourage importers. An agreement that would allow the Commonwealth to unilaterally vary the rate of charges, or to vary them far in excess of CPI, would hardly encourage somebody to import.
—It would hardly be an agreement.

—I acknowledge the interjection by my colleague Senator Bell that it would hardly be an agreement. I have a concern on that aspect and I hope that the Minister will be able to allay my fears now. My other observation is that an interest rate of 20 per cent is well above the costing of Commonwealth funding, which we all know to be around 10 per cent. That seems rather peculiar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Three honourable senators have asked me questions. Let me start in batting order-or am I the batsman and honourable senators the bowlers? I will start in the bowling order with Senator Bell.
—I thought we were batting a little better than you, actually.
—There are more in the chamber on Senator Brownhill's side at the moment than on my side--
—Senator Cook's performance is Bradmanesque compared to yours.
—My batting partner here is standing up for me.
—Look out that he doesn't run you out.
—Some of you should cease standing at silly point.
—Order! I think that we should get on with the first innings.

—I intended to go on and extend the metaphor, which perhaps I should not do now, so I do not intend to flash at balls outside the off-stump-like the one bowled by Senator Bell in which he kindly omitted to refer critically to me and then attacked my advisers. Senator Bell's basic question was, `What about an arbiter? Why can't there be an arbiter, or is there an arbiter? What appeal do these people have?' The charges that are levied are applied on a cost recovery basis.
—A monopoly cost recovery basis.

—It is certainly a monopoly. I would be surprised if anyone would argue that the control of quarantine should not be vested in a government authority and exercised under government regulation and control but that, in fact, it should be allocated to someone who might be the lowest bidder in a tender system. A regulatory authority is needed that does, in fact, do that-it regulates. That is what the Quarantine Service does. It regulates to prevent the importation into Australia of diseases that would have a deleterious impact on those of us-and the animals-who live here and vegetables that grow here.
—There is no dispute, but I would like to know whether you buy your hay competitively and so on.

—There is a place for regulatory authorities and they need to be monopolies to regulate. If they are not monopolies, they cannot regulate the field that they are given authority to regulate. That seems to me to follow.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asked whether there is an appeal. There is not an appeal because it is based on cost recovery. It relates to the costs incurred for the purposes of minding the plants or the animals in quarantine for the length of time that they are required to stay there. Those are recovered and that is reasonable. But to say that there is no appeal of any sort, which was the implication in the question, is wrong.

In the particular case of these sheep and goats at Torrens Island in South Australia, the syndicates which own them have already taken action to the Commonwealth Ombudsman to complain about the Quarantine Service, the management of the island and the steepening of the charges. That is still with the Ombudsman and still undetermined. No doubt the Ombudsman will express an opinion about it and there may or may not be action flowing from that. Therefore, to pretend that ordinary citizens have no recourse against what might be implied by this question-an insensitive bureaucracy-is not true. There is that device, it is exercised in this case and we will get an answer in due course.

There is, of course, in Senator Bell's question also a reference to how dramatically the charges have increased. It is true; they have increased dramatically. However, these sheep and goats get out of gaol on Torrens Island, I think, sometime next year. They and their progeny will have been there for eight years in order that we can be sure that diseases do not come in. In that time Government decisions on cost recovery-I stand here and take responsibility for it on behalf of the Government-have moved from 50 per cent through the range to now 100 per cent. That has been Government policy. It is not that the costs of the Service alone have increased; the percentage of costs recovered has increased by government decision. That explains why the charges have gone up so much. I will move now to the questions raised by Senator Brownhill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was No. 3 in the batting order.
—No, Senator Brownhill was actually No. 2 in the batting order I think.
—I was first drop.
—Regardless, you are out for a duck.
—No ducks were kept in quarantine on Torrens Island.
—Look out you are not goosed.
—I have to say that I have now lost my place and I cannot remember what Senator Brownhill's question was. I will have to go to Senator O'Chee's question.
—I think the Chairman ought to hold his finger up and give you out.

—I think, Mr Chairman, I had better get on with my reply and not detain the Committee any longer with this mirth across the chamber. People will think that we come here to enjoy ourselves. Senator O'Chee asked a question, as did Senator Brownhill I think, as to whether contracts are entered into. No, they are not. The Quarantine and Inspection Service tries to provide an indication to importers of the charges for quarantining. Importers know what the detention time will be. They are then able to make a commercial judgment as to whether there is profit in their enterprise. But this is an indicative arrangement; it is not a contract system nor is it an agreement. It is an indication that if one wishes to access this service these will be the charges over that length of time. Therefore, the subsidiary questions that have been asked, probing what nature of agreement or contract there might be, are not relevant because there is none.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments (by Senator Tambling)-by leave-proposed:
1. After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:

``3A. The amendment of the Principal Act effected by section 3 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, embryos, gametes or other genetic material, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991.''.
2. After clause 4, page 3, add the following clause:

``5. The amendment of the Principal Act effected by section 4 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, embryos, gametes or other genetic material, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) summed up everything that he had been trying to say in the last half-hour in about three words when he said earlier that when people want to access quarantine-animals coming in must be quarantined; rightly so-they would be `told in advance' what costs they would be up for. Those were his words. That is the concept of the Opposition amendments. I believe, and the Minister did say, that there is no contract. But there must have been some sort of arrangement. An importer bringing in animals, or anything else, would be an utter fool to quarantine animals if he did not know what it would cost him when those animals were brought out of quarantine. That is the gist of our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: A communication I have states that importers of some goats were told by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service that it would cost $50 per head for quarantine. That must not have been a very well run service because it is claimed also that the attendants fed whole wheat to some goats. Anyone with half a brain should know, especially if they are involved in agriculture, that whole wheat is a no-no; the goats died. The importers got some more goats and were told that it would cost $75 per head for quarantine. It is my understanding that that $75 per head did not increase on the basis of inflation but went up to $311 per head and that later the importers were told that the cost would be increased to nearly $400 per head. The purpose of our amendments is to prevent the charging of a higher than arranged figure for animals quarantined before 1 September-or the day on which the Bill is given royal assent. Our amendments will protect people who already have animals in quarantine.

It is obvious from the questions the Minister has been asked that there are a lot of loose arrangements. No-one seems to be able to be quite definite. However, there are importers who claim that the figures they were given started off at $50 and that they later agreed to a cost of $75, and that was the last agreement they made. If the Quarantine and Inspection Service is not able in the future to operate within reasonable costs the Government could look at privatising just the farming out side. I am not talking about the statutory requirements, but just the farming out of the animals for agistment. That could be quite easily worked out. It would be no different from putting an animal in the veterinary hospital. That side of things could be looked after quite easily.

Obviously this situation has got out of hand. I would like to commend the Australian Democrats for supporting the amendments. They have obviously had the same representations as we have and have seen that this is a gross case of retrospective legislation. I believe that if importers had been contracted to pay $50 per head and they later agreed to pay $75 per head plus an allowance for inflation, that is what the importers should be charged. I believe that when the new regulations come in on 1 September there will be more definite guidelines on exactly what an importer will pay to bring animals through quarantine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to resolve this matter. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) has indicated to me that if the amendments were in the following form, `The amendment of the principal Act effected by sections 3 and 4 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991', he would be prepared to accept them. It is my understanding in the interplay that has been joined between us behind the Chair that the omission from the amendments of the words, `embryos, gametes or other genetic material' is causing concern on the other side as to whether the form of words approved by the Minister is sufficiently broad enough to cover the range of interests that agitate concern in the Opposition and the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: My advice is that the words included in the proposal from the Minister are sufficient-I should be quite precise-to cover the omitted words `embryos, gametes and other genetic material'. That is the advice we have. I know there has been some discussion that that does not appear to be quite clear from the Act. I reassert in Hansard that our advice is that they do cover those words that would be omitted. Moreover, if that advice is found to be in error at some point, the Government would be prepared to further legislate to correct the error. That is how confident we are that the words are covered properly.

Therefore, I say on behalf of the Minister for Resources that if the words that I read before-and perhaps I should conclude by reading them again-were to replace the words in the amendment that Senator Tambling has put forward, we would accept them and the Bill could be thus amended and proceed accordingly. The words again are:
The amendment of the principal Act effected by sections 3 and 4 does not apply to expenses incurred in respect of any animals, plants or goods first detained in quarantine before 1 September 1991.
If those words could be accepted, we could dispense with this matter immediately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill seeks, in the main, to make changes to recreation leave entitlements and other matters that are exactly the same as the changes made in the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 which was passed and became an Act earlier this year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time comments are made in this chamber about insurance companies. One of my former colleagues, Ralph Jacobi, both in the chamber of the House of Representatives and outside the Parliament, was often critical of insurers. Ralph will not be the last to level this type of criticism against insurance companies. Indeed, I seem to recall a question in this area being asked only last week by my colleague Senator Crowley.

SPEECH.PARA: Insurance companies were not initially established to allow ordinary householders to share risks amongst themselves. Trade and commerce led to the growth of the insurance industry so that the inevitable risks in those areas could, for a price, be shared. Later, individuals became involved with the purchase of life insurance and insurance over their personal possessions. Insurance companies provide a valuable service in our community. Without them, the normal risks of business would be compounded to such a degree that economic development would be stifled. Traders and those in the commercial field would not be prepared to expose themselves to what they consider to be unacceptable risks.

Insurance companies, of course, are not philanthropic institutions. The only way they can stay in business is at least to cover their costs. Because their shareholders have risked their funds, it is acceptable for insurance companies to make a profit; otherwise, their funds could be used in other, more profitable, enterprises. These companies, therefore, in their financial planning, must keep to the fore a number of competing interests. Their premiums must be sufficiently high to ensure, under normal trading, a profit which may be paid to shareholders; on the other hand, they must be sufficiently low to make the cost of insurance realistic for the customers; and, to attract and hold the public's custom, their premiums must be competitive when compared with those of other insurers.

Insurers must also guard against fraudulent claims. Some people think insurance companies are fair game and so inflate or invent their losses, but when the converse is true-namely, when a customer has a genuine claim-they think that an insurance company must make the necessary payment promptly. Under normal circumstances, it should not be expected that the premiums that insurance companies accept should be matched by what they pay to customers who suffer losses. After all, those of us who insure are sharing the risk amongst ourselves and are using a third party-an insurance company-to manage this aspect of our affairs. That third party needs to be recompensed. The most obvious source of funds to provide that financial backing is customers' premiums.

Not too long ago, insurance was a fairly simple process. I can remember that for years my father used to have his home insured against loss by fire only. These days there are all sorts of options; for example, damage by storm and tempest, malicious damage, breakage of glass, and fusion of electric motors. Similar complexities have occurred in relation to life insurance. With more decisions facing insurance companies' customers, the companies themselves have an additional responsibility: to make sure that their customers are paying for an appropriate product and that they clearly understand for what risks they are covered.

In this area I consider that some companies are not totally fulfilling their responsibility. Because of this, I would like to alert my constituents to one of the traps of taking out insurance. Where the warning applies, it should also be heeded by residents of States and Territories other than my own State of Queensland.

A case which was brought to my attention relates to a burglary in a Brisbane suburb. The person concerned had taken out a contents insurance policy with a southern company which is making a major marketing move into Queensland. This company was chosen because its rates appeared quite competitive. In retrospect, it was a case of one gets what one pays for. The burglary was reported to the police, and a claim was made to the insurance company. Among the goods stolen were two computers, which were used as word processors, and a laser printer.

Theft of goods from one's own home is a traumatic event, but at least this person was consoled by the fact that he had shown sufficient presence of mind to have the contents insured. But his contents insurance was of little use. He was told that because he had not listed the computer equipment separately he would receive a total of $1,000 for the computers and the printer. This was at least $4,000 less than the value of the goods. Four thousand dollars may not seem a lot to some people. To a university student who is not receiving Austudy, but wants to have a certain amount of independence, it is a huge sum of money. The fact that the person thought he had done the right thing and insured his property made the limited pay-out of the insurance company even more unpalatable.

The plain English policy document which was forwarded to this person listed, amongst its exclusions and restrictions, a $1,000 limit on computer equipment unless previously notified to the company. However, it is a pity that the company had not mentioned this fact to its client before he paid for the policy. Because the provision about the computer equipment was in the written policy, the customer probably has no recourse. It is a sneaky way of conducting business. I subsequently examined the fine print of the contents insurance for my own home in Queensland. There was no mention of specifying computer equipment. There is well over $1,000 worth of computer equipment in my home protected, I might add, by a reliable burglar alarm system as well as security doors and windows.

The warning I give to my constituents is for them to read their insurance policy or policies with great care, and note whether there are any ways an insurance company could welsh on what would seem to be a reasonable claim. If this is the case, an immediate call to the insurance company is required, either to take out the required additional cover, or to notify the company that a more reasonable company has been located. I cannot stress this too greatly: read the policy with extreme care. If any doubt exists, seek some independent advice.

I do not intend to name the particular company in the Senate because it may place it at a disadvantage in relation to other companies which have similar clauses in their policies. However, both my wife and I each have separate policies with this company and, when the time comes for renewal, we will be looking for a company which has a better customer record. When I am back in Queensland and the subject of insurance is raised, I shall have no hesitation in providing the name of the insurance company to which I have referred today. I will be candid about my opinion of its service to its customers. As far as I am concerned the company should stay south of the border and keep its sticky fingers off the money of Queenslanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with my colleagues I have much to say about the content or, perhaps more precisely, the lack of content of what one would describe as the moribund ninth Hawke Budget. I will be addressing this matter in the context of the Budget debate at a later date. However, there are some vital factors of public interest in relation to the Budget which I think ought to be put on the record now. In some instances they have their origin in the March Economic Statement put down by former Treasurer Keating. For example, how does the Hawke Government continue to have the audacity to wage a scare campaign against a goods and services tax when it has, in this Budget, in effect, introduced such a tax on the sick? I refer to the $3.50 Medicare fee. The Government has also introduced a similar tax on service for migrants using our health care system.

SPEECH.PARA: I am in absolute agreement that Medicare needs much more to be done to it if it is ever to show any semblance of efficiency and to become cost-efficient and, to a certain extent, self-funding through the Medicare levy. But the Government should be more honest. The $3.50 up-front payment for a GP's visit, which increases to $5 in November next year, is simply a tax on a service; nothing more, nothing less-a tax on a service. Taking the user pays principle, it is, absolutely, a goods and services tax in that particular area-in this case, the sick. The Government cannot deny this, although I have no doubt that it will attempt to do so.

This proposal comes from the very team which has been attempting to bring tears to children's eyes with emotive comments about a coalition government goods and services tax making every visit to McDonald's a visit to the tax man. What this hypocritical and deceitful Government refuses to put on the table is that a goods and services tax from a coalition government comes as part of a tax package, with income tax cuts providing more money in the pocket to spend. The point conveniently overlooked by the Government is that it means tax on what one spends and not so much on what one earns. That is the objective behind our restructuring and, incidentally, was the objective behind the restructuring put forward by former Treasurer Keating. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), also advocated that line not so long ago. Those who had the opportunity to see the Sunday program could well foresee Senator Richardson's remarks coming back to haunt him.

A GST from a coalition government totally removes the tax by stealth of the present wholesale sales tax system and also tackles the black economy. Yet on Tuesday every Australian needing the services of a local doctor was hit by what is in effect a 15 per cent goods and services tax on that service. Taken as a proportion of the present Medicare schedule fee of $22.50, the $3.50 is a 15 per cent tax being levied by the Hawke Labor Government on a visit to the local GP. Labor's Budget delivered no more money into the pocket of the public from which to pay that added tax, unlike the coalition's proposed goods and services tax with its corresponding substantial reductions in income tax rates. As ever with the Hawke Government, it is taxation by stealth; it seems to be the only way it operates. Just look at how it has broadened the net of the wholesale sales tax system since the Tax Summit. Instead of $3.5 billion being collected by the indirect hidden wholesale sales tax system, we now have in excess of $11 billion being collected by this Administration. There is nothing up-front in the taxation sense with this Government.

While I do not disagree with the principle of user pays, nor argue with the introduction of a non-returnable levy of, I think, $822 on all migrants to cover their initial usage of Australia's health system, I most definitely will not sit quietly by and let the Hawke Government pretend that the levy is not a goods and services tax. It is a goods and services tax with another title on it. The public and the media should not be fooled: a services tax is already in place in Australia courtesy of the Hawke Labor Government, but the Government will not admit to it. It makes the scare campaign by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) against the GST sound very hollow indeed.

In contrast, a coalition government will be honest enough to tell the people of Australia exactly what they are being taxed on, up-front. There will be no hidden tax system such as the wholesale sales tax system, nothing hidden or behind the scenes-it will all be up-front, to openly display the tax on the goods people buy and on the services they use. Sadly, hidden taxes, like hidden political agendas, have become the norm over the past nine years of the Hawke Labor Government. Look at the deal that was done prior to the last Federal election campaign; it showed a preparedness not to be straightforward and honest with the people.

A Budget week example from South Australia says it all. It occurred to me as I flew to Canberra from Adelaide on Monday morning that the line `A funny thing happened on my way here tonight' used to be every comedian's favourite introduction, so I suppose I could have laughed at the joke as I opened my copy of the Adelaide News-if I thought it was at all amusing. Splashed all over page 2 was what one could only describe as a funny thing-self-confessed Hawke supporter, Senator Graham Maguire, promising more than $400m in wholesale sales tax cuts to be announced in John Kerin's Budget to be brought down the following day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which year?

—This year. What was the good senator up to, I thought to myself, with a headline like that? Perhaps he had had a leak from the top designed to show what a great bloke Prime Minister Hawke was, or perhaps he had ESP, or just the usual determination to fool all of the people all of the time. I did not have to wait for the Budget the following day for the answer to that. Every single change to the wholesale sales tax system announced by Senator Maguire in the news on Monday as about to happen in the next day's Budget had, I discovered, already been announced by Paul Keating in the March Economic Statement. Every one of the changes was five months old.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly, Senator Maguire did not happen to mention in his press release the one wholesale sales tax change that was announced in the Budget, that relating to motor vehicles used for the transport of the disabled. He had left that out. There was no leak, no ESP. It was just another press release trying to get a headline without honesty and fact to back it up. I repeat that he talks about $400m being provided this year. According to the Budget Papers, one has to wait until 1993-94 before anything like $400m in wholesale sales tax cuts are actually delivered and returned for a full year.

I suppose Senator Maguire counts his antics in fooling a journalist relatively new to the political job, in a blatant bid to puff up the Prime Minister and con the public, as a success. I suppose he would count the headline as being a success. However, all it does is reinforce the desperate deceitfulness of a debilitated government, a government with nothing left in the medicine cupboard to prescribe for the wounds it has inflicted on the Australian population.

Certainly most economists presumed there would be, and should be, more simplifications and changes to the wholesale sales tax system announced in the Budget to give some relief to the business sector. It has been pounded by the Government's high real interest rate policy-I spoke about that last Thursday-and profits after tax are at their lowest level in 25 years. The business sector has now been slugged again by the Government's Budget superannuation proposals. Economists are still waiting, just as the business community is still waiting, for the changes announced in the March Economic Statement-and helpfully reannounced by Senator Maguire this week-to be introduced into Parliament so they can actually take effect. Relief is long overdue and has been a long time coming with this Government.

We had a promise from the Government that the March announcement of changes to the wholesale sales tax system on business inputs would be followed by legislation early in the Budget session. We wait with interest to see whether the promised timeframe is adhered to. Meanwhile, if Senator Maguire is really so keen to dispense good news Hawke-style, perhaps he could let the business community know immediately when to expect the long-awaited review legislation. I feel that at least he owes it that after Monday's press release-a blatant piece of nonsense-or are we simply asking too much of him? The simple fact is that the business community has been promised, for more than five months, a major restructuring of the wholesale sales tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't believe any of your promises in the last State election. That is why you're here.

—They did believe my promises, because the fact is that 52.4 per cent of the population of South Australia supported the Liberal Party in the last State election. Forty-seven per cent of the population supported the Labor Party. The honourable senator would well understand that the Labor Party has talked about gerrymanders, but it practises and puts in place and lives on gerrymanders itself. Senator Ray is in this place, despite the fact that a majority of the two-party preferred vote in this country does not support the Government sitting on the government side of this House, nor did it in South Australia last time around. One can go to other States and get exactly the same example. So Senator Ray should not give me that nonsense about the Liberal Party not getting the endorsement of the South Australian population. We did, with 52.4 per cent, and we are not there because of the boundaries that have been drawn in South Australia. That is the reason we are not in government. It is like playing grand final footy. One can have more points on the scoreboard at the end of the day but somebody else gets the premiership flag.
—That is why Playford won 10 premierships in a row!

—I am not defending that era, but Senator Ray should not stand up and defend his era when he is presiding over exactly the same set of circumstances. That is why there is currently a redistribution in South Australia. Following the last State election people were asked whether they endorsed the current boundaries and overwhelmingly they said they did not. They said that there needed to be change; that fairness and equity needed to be put back into the electoral system in South Australia. I ask Senator Ray not to chide me with any nonsense about not getting the support of the population of South Australia. I did. That support was at the ballot box and it was absolutely indisputable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that we will be putting forward to the population of Australia a series of fundamental structural changes to the economy of this country, which it needs. There are no better examples to be had than getting out in the community and meeting small business people, recognising the constraints they are under, seeing the number that are going bankrupt and seeing the number that are having to dismiss long time employees simply because, at the end of the day, they cannot afford to pay them. The Budget that has just been brought down ignores that need. It does not address it in a meaningful way. I have highlighted in my comments today how in March we were promised relief in relation to business inputs. That relief has not come about, and what we have to do is wait until 1993-94 before we get anywhere near $400m worth of relief-that is, if the legislation is introduced and we actually get to debate it and if this week's headline concerning Senator Maguire has any reality or honesty to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this matters of public interest discussion to highlight a particular set of figures which do not get much publicity. We hear much about the current unemployment situation and the fact that the registered unemployment rate is close to 10 per cent. In my State of Western Australia it is 11 per cent. Often the Government compares the rate-Senator Button did so yesterday in Question Time-with that which existed when we were last in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I want to talk about bankruptcies and what is happening in that sector. My colleague Senator Olsen has referred to some of the impacts stemming from the lack of action by this Labor Government in terms of giving some relief to small business. Of course, one such impact is interest rates. It is interesting to compare the bankruptcy figures during the Fraser Government's term of office with the figures during the Hawke Government's eight years of office. During the Fraser years there were 30,945 bankruptcies, an average of 3,868 per year. During the Hawke-Keating-and now Kerin-years there were 60,089 bankruptcies, or an average of 7,511 per year. The figure has almost doubled. It has gone from 3,868 per year to 7,511 per year, on average.

If we go a little further and look at what has occurred this year as a result of Labor Government policies that have been foisted on the Australian public-the policies that have created the present disastrous unemployment rates-we find there was an overall increase in the number of bankruptcies in the period from 1989-90 to 1990-91. The figure went up from 8,552 bankruptcies to 12,991-an increase of 52 per cent. In my State, Western Australia, the number of bankruptcies rose from 1,088 to 1,849-a massive increase of 70 per cent.

In New South Wales, the figure went from 2,230 to 3,396-an increase of 52 per cent. In Victoria, the figure of 1,809 had blown out to 3,098-an increase of 71 per cent. In Queensland, the 1989-90 figure of 1,591 had blown out to 2,424-an increase of 52 per cent. In South Australia, the number of bankruptcies in 1989-90 was 1,319 and in 1990-91 it was 1,655-an increase of 26 per cent. The only State that had any joy at all in terms of these figures was Tasmania which had a reduction from 440 to 211.

When we look at the other side of the equation, at the businesses which will provide the employment to overcome our unemployment problems, we find a massive 52 per cent increase in the number of bankruptcies in the last financial year. This is going to have a dramatic impact on the capacity of this country to re-employ those people who are unfortunate enough not to have a job. Without going into my reply to the Budget, I must say, as Senator Olsen did, that there is no relief in terms of the taxation system for small business, or anybody else for that matter. The changes to the wholesale sales tax, which will not come through until 1994, will do little to overcome this problem at a time when it needs to be overcome.

When we look at the estimates that have been put forward, in terms of what is anticipated this financial year, we see no light on the horizon and no sign that the figures are going to get better. In fact, the signs are that the situation will get worse. It is important that the Australian public be aware of the other side of the equation: not just the unemployment disaster but also the business bankruptcy disaster that is going on in our country at this time as a result of the Labor Government's failed economic and industrial policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of the Budget having been brought down this year and the pain and suffering that are being inflicted upon the Australian public generally, I also want to analyse some of the arguments that are put forth in the public arena against the need for tax reform which we on this side of the House see as one of the most important aspects that this country needs to tackle.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague who spoke before me, Senator Crane, dealt in a very across-the-board manner with the figures concerning the number of bankruptcies and how they are growing. He also outlined, for the record, just how bad the economy is in that regard. My colleague Senator Olsen pointed out how the imposition of the $3.50 medical fee, which is to be imposed for a visit to the doctor, in effect, amounts to a de facto consumption tax of 15 per cent.

When we start to look at those who would decry the need for tax reform, which would include a goods and services tax, it is worth while looking at the record of those who cry out the loudest. Today I have chosen to look at the criticisms that come forth from one Mr Eric Risstrom. Mr Risstrom writes a regular column and has long held himself to be an astute tax commentator. He likes to think he is known as the taxpayers' friend. But an appraisal of his record over the period ranging from the Tax Summit in 1985 to the present shows that one should, perhaps, look much more critically at the sorts of opinions that Mr Risstrom frequently puts pen to paper to express.

Mr Risstrom's record is one of resisting genuine tax reform. Describing his attitude as being equivocal about the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax would perhaps be correct. He was reported in the Australian of 15 February 1985 as saying:
. . . the Government should only introduce an expanded sales tax-which at present takes effect at the wholesale end-if it were determined to broaden indirect taxation.
Further, on the opening day of the Tax Summit Mr Risstrom opposed the consumption tax proposal but said:
. . . the retail tax in the economy is something that I believe should be studied.
He went on to mention the IBIS study, which, he said:
. . . suggests that it would be dangerous to introduce a retail tax for at least four years and maybe seven years.
He said that in 1985. Six years have gone by, so one could reasonably say that any danger that he might have seen then would have passed. Why does he still resist reform?
Almost a year ago to this week Mr Risstrom wrote in the Sun-Herald:
. . . the worst time to introduce such a tax on spending is when inflation is high-and there is no evidence it will come down for years.

Mr Risstrom could not have been more mistaken. Today inflation stands at 3.4 per cent, the lowest in 20 years, and the Budget Papers put out this week predict a 3 per cent inflation rate for the coming year.

If we go on to look at the way Mr Risstrom has handled his arithmetic, I think it is reasonable to look at the 1985 Tax Summit, when Treasury revealed that a $1.1 billion error was present in Mr Risstrom's calculations regarding the cost of abolishing the wholesale sales tax. Also, he likes to exaggerate figures. This was demonstrated by his estimate, again at the Tax Summit, that the administration of a consumption tax as cited at that time would be greater by some 600 per cent than the Treasury said it would be.

Another tactic that Mr Risstrom likes to use is to pluck figures out of the air. In his article in the Sun-Herald of 21 July 1991 he claimed that people spend 75 per cent of their income on things that are currently not taxed. There is, of course, no publicly available data to support this proposition. To the contrary, the Coopers and Lybrand report shows that in a large retail store, such as a supermarket, at least 50 per cent of all goods are subject to wholesale sales tax. Even those goods which purport to be exempt from the sales tax are very often subject to a tax component.

Let us look again at the comments Mr Risstrom has made concerning tax evasion. One of the arguments used for the need for tax reform is that, if a goods and services tax were introduced to replace the wholesale sales tax and at the same time the rate of income tax were cut and a compensation package were introduced, whole sections of the black economy or the cash economy which presently do not participate in the tax system would be brought into the system.

Mr Risstrom said in the Australian Financial Review of 1 June 1989 that it is often said that if we switched to a consumption tax it would multiply tax avoidance by four. I do not know where he got the numbers or the concept from, but a similar claim was made by him in the Age of 15 July 1991:
. . . nobody knows how big the cash economy is but don't believe the argument that a GST would fix it. Evidence from overseas countries is that overall it would be far worse.

Nobody is saying that it is a panacea, but what we are saying is that the evidence does not back up Mr Risstrom's statements. After all, in New Zealand, after the introduction of the goods and services tax the Government recouped an estimated 5 per cent of GDP from its newly taxed cash economy. Putting that another way, it simply meant that the number of people who chose to register their businesses-that is, as businesses with a certain turnover-was way beyond the expectation or the knowledge that they had from businesses that were already paying tax; that is, businesses that had not been paying tax beforehand began to pay tax because they saw the reform as being beneficial. In Australia, the Victorian employers' Chamber of Commerce estimated that a GST would collect at least $500m from the cash economy in Australia.

I want to return to that tax summit, because it is quite revealing about how some people develop their ideas. Three days into the tax summit Mr Risstrom said, `I felt throughout the community no great opposition to an extension of indirect taxes in some areas of services'. Without any explanation whatsoever Mr Risstrom has now reversed his position on the question of taxing services. Instead of applauding the proposal, he now likes to be a scaremonger on the proposition.
In the Taxpayer, the journal of the Australian Taxpayers Association, of 16 June 1990, Mr Risstrom wrote in the most emotive terms. He said:
But just what services would be taxed? Answer: Expenditure on situations such as
- funerals
- accountancy fees
- the cost of joining the local club
- and the list is endless.

In a way it is evidence of his lack of intellectual honesty that having first supported the proposition of the legitimacy of taxing services and accepting that a consumption tax-be it a goods and services tax or some other that he then encountered-was worthy of support, he now says that somehow it is not.

His present contention is that we ought somehow to leave the wholesale sales tax in place. I remind honourable senators that the tax is both inequitable and illogical, ranging as it does from a 10 to 30 per cent tax; a tax on chocolate biscuits but not on caviar; on orange juice but not on pornographic literature; people who can afford to go by aeroplane to their holiday destination get that tax free, but people who buy a caravan to minimise the cost of their annual holiday have to pay a tax on the caravan. That shows that already there is not only a lack of logic in the way that the tax is imposed, but also a total lack of equity.

To accept Mr Risstrom's proposition that somehow the wholesale sales tax system should be broadened and allowed to become the de facto, valid, indirect method of taxation alone would, in fact, make it a broad-based consumption tax. On 4 July 1985, again at that tax summit, he said, `The wholesale sales tax has been deprecated in many ways, but I believe in many ways it is intrinsically a good system'.

I would like to tell Mr Risstrom that there are thousands upon thousands of Australians, both eminent and ordinary, vocal and silent, who find that it is not a sensible tax; it is neither logical nor equitable. Those people wish to see-and indeed demand-tax reform. They demand that their politicians' intentions be open and honest. That is exactly what the Opposition is doing. We are presenting our tax reform package in such a way that people can really understand the need for and the sense of it, and our true intent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to reports that Senator Cook has said that the Government might have to review just how quickly it moves to the 9 per cent end of decade occupational superannuation target if wages blow out. How committed is the Government to the superannuation levy increases? How high does the CPI effect of the changes-already forecast to be 2 per cent-have to go before the Government will abandon this new payroll tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are, I think, some hidden assumptions in that question. The basic one is that the superannuation payments, which have been given as indicative figures in the Budget Papers, are indeed add ons to wages.
—What are they-off the money tree?

—No. I illustrate the point simply by saying that in previous years there has been an award prescription for a 3 per cent superannuation increase. That was set off, in the context of the accord, against wage claims in a particular year.
—You have just made it compulsory.

—My reply to the interjection that we have made it compulsory is that that is not correct at all. What is correct is that one cannot assume and it would be wrong to assume that superannuation costs will be an add on cost to business above normal wages payments.
—That is right.

—Senator Walters says that it will, and that is what she would like to believe. The Opposition has an economic model prepared on the basis of producing certain figures on the assumption that wages as identified in the Budget Papers, that is, wage outcomes of 4.5 per cent to 5 per cent, would be additional to, or would be added to, superannuation. That is not the case. Indeed, in September there will be a conference between the Government, unions and employer organisations to discuss all of these questions.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no good coming in here and arguing on the basis of quite false assumptions, which are not there, which are not part of the Budget and which are not part of the process which the Government envisages. I illustrate that point further by saying that both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have said that superannuation will be taken into account in future award negotiations and that award negotiations will be taken into account similarly in relation to the superannuation entitlements which employees are given under the announced program.
