As I have indicated, the figures set out in the Budget are indicative. One has only to read the Budget Papers to understand that.

I want to set the environment for what I am saying by simply making the point that throughout the years of this Government there has been significant wage restraint and reduction in real wages. The fact of the matter is that that has been agreed to as a policy which is beneficial to the Labor movement and the work force generally. The same comments can be made about superannuation. The Government is interested in locking in low inflation, creating jobs and stimulating investment. That is an agenda which is shared, for example, by the ACTU. It is a Labor agenda.

During Question Time yesterday there were all sorts of false assumptions put in questions and I am sad that it is happening today. I gave those opposite the opportunity to do some work last night. In fact, I asked them to go away and do some work on the Budget Papers. Yet the first question popped up by Senator Bishop, by arrangement, is a question which is based on totally false assumptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. After that answer I might say that I could call the Minister `Senator Pollyanna Button'.
—I think you are on thin ice, myself.
—You can't afford to be on thin ice.
— Order! That is why all interjections are disorderly.
—Senator Button said that he wanted to make a simple point, and I think he did. Just for the record, his answer meant that he was in disagreement with Senator Cook.

—That is not a supplementary question but let me say that I am in no disagreement with Senator Cook about this issue. I have discussed it with him on a number of occasions and there is no disagreement at all.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade provide the Government's response to the collapse of the coup in the Soviet Union and the restoration of President Gorbachev to the key leadership position in the Soviet Union?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the Senate will share my relief and delight at the news we all woke up to this morning. It really was a triumph for the democratic instinct. It gives us all, I think, very great confidence both for the future of the peoples of the Soviet Union and, indeed, for the future peace and stability of the world.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear that the coup has comprehensively failed. As to the key participants in it, I understand that Defence Minister Yazov is now in the Crimea; KGB Chief Kryuchkov is under arrest by the Interior Ministry of the Russian Federation; and Yanayev, who led the State of Emergency Committee, was at last report still in his Kremlin office but, presumably, he will not be there for very much longer. Most of the rest of the Committee are reported to have fled Moscow for the central Asian republic of Kirghizia. All troops have left Moscow and the curfew has been lifted. President Gorbachev, who is in fact in very good health, is back in Moscow this morning, is back in control, and is shortly to make a major speech.

There are, clearly, a number of reasons why the coup failed. One of them was the crucial role played personally by Boris Yeltsin. Secondly, there was the bravery and determination of the peoples of Moscow, Leningrad, the Baltic states and elsewhere not to be cowed by brute force. Thirdly, there was the international reaction, in which Australia joined and which was so comprehensive and so intense that, clearly, it did do something to weaken the Committee's resolve. Fourthly, I think one has also to ascribe it to very poor planning and organisation by the coup leaders, who seemed to think that all they had to do was embark upon some re-run of the coups of the Krushchev era and before involving backroom deals, the gagging of the media and a reliance on the shut up or be shot system prevailing so far as the community as a whole is concerned.

Clearly, the outcome represents a very significant victory for both President Gorbachev and President Yeltsin. With the conservatives now comprehensively discredited, the progressive forces that Gorbachev and Yeltsin represent should be able to move the reform process forward with renewed vigour. A precondition for that will remain the effective cooperation between those two leaders as well as the acceptance of a durable legal and political arrangement defining future relations between the centre and the republic. That will, of course, be necessary for those republics, particularly the Baltics, that have made very clear their wish to opt for full independence.

In the rather euphoric atmosphere that is prevailing post-coup, we must not forget the very real problems that the Soviet Union continues to face, particularly in the economic sphere. The Australian Government will support concerted international action to provide a framework for economic development to the Soviet Union. In that respect I am pleased to be able to indicate that the freeze measures that were taken by this Government have now been lifted, including the restriction on the trade credit facility.

We look forward to further development and consolidation of the bilateral relationship between Australia and the Soviet Union. We also look forward with very considerable relief to the Soviet Union, without any ambiguity, continuing the very constructive policies that were pursued by President Gorbachev. Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh, who is now back in action, has told a press conference that with the collapse of the coup the Soviet Union is coming back to the road of commonsense policies, and that Soviet foreign policy remains unchanged. We can now reasonably expect a continuation of solid Soviet cooperation on a range of international issues, including those of the Middle East and Cambodia, and we also anticipate the Soviet Union maintaining its largely more constructive policies to the Asia-Pacific region generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's admission yesterday that 900,000 Australians will be out of work this year-an estimate that I consider to be very conservative. Can the Minister inform the Senate how many of these will be young Australians under the age of 20 years? As this will increase the present 60-year record full time youth unemployment rate of 28.5 per cent, what will Labor's new record youth unemployment rate really be?
—I do not have that figure. I will get it for Senator Campbell as quickly as possible.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to complaints by various spokespersons for industry and business groups that employers cannot afford universal superannuation cover for people in the workplace? Has he any information about the superannuation entitlement in the remuneration packages paid by the employers of those people, as distinct from the workers they are complaining about? Further, is there any great difference between the superannuation cover typically paid in the private sector, on the one hand, to executives and professionals and, on the other hand, to workers who are further down the pecking order?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the complaints that have been made by people representing various organisations about the inability, in their assertion, of the members of those organisations to pay superannuation entitlements. For example, I am aware that the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Business Council of Australia, the Small Business Association and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures are among organisations whose spokespersons have made that allegation.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat, as I said yesterday, that legislation to enshrine superannuation as a major social change in this country would not bring any cost until 1 July next year, which means that the recovery can proceed this financial year without that cost being imposed. As honourable senators will know, under the award system most employers in this country are bound in any case to pay a 3 per cent superannuation levy. Many are bound by agreements in which they have voluntarily offered to pay more, and under that formulation most small business, which would be paying superannuation at the rate of 3 per cent now, will not face an extra charge on 1 July.

I am asked in this question whether I know of the remuneration package that these spokespersons have obtained from their own organisations. I do not know. The spokespersons for these organisations are certainly senior executives, and traditionally in the packages for senior executives there is a provision for superannuation entitlement. So it is fairly safe to assume that all of the people who are complaining about the spread of superannuation are safe in the knowledge that they have the entitlement for themselves.

For example, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics more than 80 per cent of specialist managers in this country obtain superannuation and more than 70 per cent of business professionals do so. By contrast, only 30 per cent of female receptionists obtain the advantage of superannuation; 23.2 per cent of farm labourers have a superannuation entitlement; and female shop assistants check in last, with only 17 per cent having a superannuation entitlement. There is, if you like, a double standard in the sense that those who rest in the security of having superannuation are complaining that those who hold low wage positions and are not obtaining superannuation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I feel that you have to make a ruling and take singular exception to the Minister imputing base motives to people simply because they criticise his Government's policies. I think that it is quite improper for him to stand up and say that the people who are speaking for employer groups are doing it out of self-interest. I would ask you to ask him to withdraw those comments.
—Order! There is no point of order. I cannot be held responsible for the answer that the Minister is giving.
—I have completed my answer, but the interjection just forces me to ask what superannuation entitlement Senator Bishop has.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has any cost-effective analysis or quality assessment been carried out on the operations of the development import finance facility scheme? If so, what has been the impact of the scheme on Australian companies? How is the impact on recipient countries assessed? Does the Minister accept that it would be more appropriate for the $93m which has been allocated to the scheme in the current Budget to be drawn from the trade allocation rather than from the development cooperation allocation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All substantial proposals under the development import finance facility, or DIFF, scheme are subject to feasibility studies and appraisal by AIDAB officers. In addition, there is an annual program of project evaluations to assess whether the projects have met their objectives. In regard to the impact on recipient countries, all DIFF proposals are assessed against a number of quite specific developmental criteria. These include the project's contribution to the recipient's economic and social development, its priority in the recipient's development plan and, of course, the project's economic and financial viability.

ANSWER.PARA: The benefit to Australian companies is primarily that it allows them to compete equally against aid supported financial packages which are offered by other donor countries. Clearly, it does, therefore, allow firms from Australia to participate in more overseas projects. The benefit of the scheme to Australian firms is currently being surveyed by AIDAB. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the scheme has allowed firms to demonstrate their capabilities and has led to further export sales. The difficulty is to quantify that in the still relatively early life of the program as a whole.

As to the last part of the question, the DIFF scheme is a very important part not of the general foreign affairs budget but of the aid program and is appropriately, in our judgment, funded from the aid budget. Many parts of the aid program provide trade spin-offs of one kind or another. That is as it should be. Provided that the basic rationale of any money that we spend under the aid program is developmental-and that is the case here-there is no need to apologise for Australian business getting some benefit from such a program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to an incident on 3 August in which debris estimated to weigh approximately 44 kilograms fell from a Thai International aircraft onto suburbs north of the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, including Marrickville, Stanmore and Annandale. I ask the Minister whether it is true that the draft environmental impact statement for the proposed third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport failed to recognise, let alone evaluate, a life threatening risk of this nature. What steps does the Minister propose to take to ensure that risks of this type are fully investigated and evaluated, particularly bearing in mind the substantially increased number of flights that will occur over residential areas to the north of the airport in the event that the third runway proposal proceeds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to say in response to Senator Faulkner's question is that the EIS canvasses the question of risk at the airport. The second thing to say is that calculating the odds on this incident happening would be almost impossible because the number of incidents is so small. The aircraft concerned, which was from Thai Airways, an airline with a very sound safety reputation, lost a portion of the exhaust system-the exhaust cone-from the rear of one of its engines. The aircraft continued its flight and landed safely in Bangkok.

ANSWER.PARA: The pieces of the engine were recovered and given to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. They are currently being subjected to detailed metallurgical testing in order to determine how and why the failure occurred. The results of this examination are not yet known, but the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has advised me that this failure is so rare that it is only aware of one other similar incident on any aircraft anywhere in the world. The Civil Aviation Authority is providing laboratory facilities and expertise for the investigation, and a senior engineering specialist from the engine manufacturer, General Electric, is in Australia to assist the investigation that is being carried out at the moment.

In conclusion, I say categorically-not just in response to Senator Faulkner's assertions but also to some recent public statements by another enthusiast in the House of Representatives-that the problem at Sydney Airport is not a question of congestion of the air space; it is a question of congestion of the runway space.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It follows the answer by Senator Evans to my question regarding an inquiry into admissions of neglect by senior management of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In his reply, Senator Evans told the Senate that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, known as the Martin Committee, had already inquired into the foreign loan situation and that no other investigation was needed. As the admission by senior bank management has occurred since the Martin inquiry examined the CBA, as the spokesman for the banking inquiry, David Elder, as late as last Friday admitted that the inquiry is still not in possession of certain documents from CBA and as today's report in the Sydney Morning Herald says that the CBA prevented or discouraged borrowers from hedging, which is contrary to the assurances given to the Martin inquiry, why will the Government not further instruct the inquiry to look into these admissions?
—That question seeks information about a variety of matters. I suggest the honourable senator place it on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and concerns the announcement in the Budget that the Federal Government will contribute $22.4m over the next four years to improve the effectiveness of screening for cervical cancer. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why a new approach to cervical cancer screening is needed and how the funding will be spent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that many honourable senators have taken an interest in the problem of cervical cancer in the community, which is the sixth most common cause of cancer in women. What has been noted before in this chamber is that it is eminently preventable. A screening is able to detect precancerous abnormalities of the cervix. However, despite significant financial support from the Government, the current system of cervical cancer screening in Australia is not well organised. Older women, who have the highest incidence of cervical cancer, Aboriginal women and women who are isolated are poorly screened, while many younger women are screened more often than is necessary. It is anticipated that the adoption of an organised approach to screening can reduce by half the number of cervical cancer cases detected in Australia every year.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to the poor rate of screening amongst certain groups of women, other concerns with our present approach include the variable quality of Pap smear taking and reporting and the lack of an organised approach to the follow-up of women with abnormal smears. Also until recently there has been no agreement on the vital issue of the age at which screening should commence and the interval between screenings. The new policy, which has been widely endorsed by professional groups and cancer societies, recommends that all women between the ages of 18 years and 70 years be screened every two years.

The $22.4m for cervical cancer screening announced in the Budget will improve the effectiveness of screening by redirecting the emphasis of our screening effort to at risk women. The funds will be used to develop and implement a communication strategy targeted initially at service providers, followed by information aimed at women. The funds will also be used to improve the reliability of Pap smear taking and guidelines for treatment of abnormalities.

Dr Edith Weisberg, the Medical Director of the Family Planning Association of New South Wales, has been appointed the Commonwealth spokesperson on cervical cancer. There will also be the development of strategies to encourage the improved participation of at risk women and also to improve the effectiveness of training, monitoring and evaluation. The benefit of an organised approach to screening will be a 50 per cent reduction in the number of cases; that is, a reduction of 1,040 of cervical cancer cases diagnosed annually.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Tate, to an article in Tuesday's West Australian regarding the Yakabindie mine row in Western Australia. The article stated that even though the local Aborigines in the area approved the $350m mining project going ahead, the Federal Minister, Mr Tickner, may still intervene. Does the Federal Government intend to override the stated position of the Aboriginal elders, who represent the area, in favour of the position stated by general activists such as Robert Bropho and Rob Riley?

—I just indicate that, whilst I did represent the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs during a particularly traumatic time in this chamber, that responsibility has been given to Senator Collins. He might care to answer the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sign of the times that, when Aboriginal affairs is not the scandal of the month that it used to be, people forget who handles the matter in here. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided me with the following advice: an application under section 9 of the Act was made by the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia on behalf of the Ngalia Heritage Research Council on 28 May 1991. This application sought protection of several sites at the proposed mine. In accordance with the requirements of section 13(2) of the Act, the Minister wrote to his Western Australian counterpart, the Hon. Dr Judyth Watson, to seek advice as to what action, if any, the State Government proposed to take to protect these sites, given the apparent threat of injury or desecration presented by mining activities. The Minister subsequently met with Dr Watson and discussed the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: By way of background, two anthropological reports on the Yakabindie area were compiled, the first one clearing the area for mining and the later one providing evidence that the sites will be destroyed by mining operations. On the basis of the first report, the State had previously approved the mine project. Dr Watson referred both reports to the Aboriginal Cultural Material Committee for assessment, an expert body set up under the State's Aboriginal State Heritage Act 1972. This Committee proposed that an independent anthropological expert from the South Australian museum should be commissioned to examine all of the evidence in relation to Aboriginal sites at Yakabindie and the credentials of all persons who have provided information to the previous studies.

Dominion Mining Ltd agreed that it would not proceed with site works until the matter was resolved. At a recent meeting at Leonora, Aboriginal people attending supported the mining project and saw no need for further studies. The State has now decided that the further studies should not be undertaken and the Premier has written to the Prime Minister requesting that the Commonwealth decline the application before it. The State's request is under consideration. The Minister is conscious of the importance of resolving the matter as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware of a press release issued by Senator Newman on 20 August which contained an alleged quote from Budget Paper No. 1? Is the Minister aware that this press release has been reported as fact in this morning's Australian Financial Review? Can the Minister advise on the truth or otherwise on this quotation by Senator Newman?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in my possession a copy of the press release. I have also noticed that it was covered without checking in the Australian Financial Review. What the press release says-and this is only a typical example-is:

ANSWER.PARA: ``The Government has decided to maximise combat capability by reducing the numbers of service personnel''
Underneath that it says:
(This is a quote from 1991/92 Budget Paper No 1, not from Lewis Carroll!)
When we read what Budget Paper No.1 says, we find that either Senator Newman is being deceitful or she does not understand punctuation. The actual quote is:
- maximise combat capability by reducing the numbers of service personnel involved in support functions and increasing the use of civilian and commercial support.
That sort of abbreviated quoting from Senator Newman is a deceitful approach to politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you deny that you are cutting back on paid people in the Air Force and the Navy?
—Order, Senator Newman!

—It gives a completely different context to the statement contained in the Budget Paper. Anyone can take any statement out of the Budget Paper and cut it in half and give it an entirely different meaning. It is not the first time that this has happened. This happens time and time again with Senator Newman.
—Read your own documents.
—Order! Senator Newman, you are consistently interjecting. You will cease.
—We see this distortion constantly appearing.
—It is a disgrace.

—I agree with Senator Bolkus; it is a disgrace. The press release gives a completely different meaning. There is nothing new in this. We have had the great spectacle of Senator Newman saying that we are not cutting enough civilians in the Defence Force. Meanwhile, on the day of the Force structure review, Senator Newman is up the hill with the rest of the ACT Liberal Party handing this media release out which says that the Australian Labor Party is taking away jobs. It is the old business of working both sides of the street. The Liberal Party says that we are not abolishing enough jobs, but to those who have jobs it says, `The other mob are abolishing your jobs'. We have heard enough of this hypocrisy, in my view. If those opposite want to have a defence debate on the real issues, we will have it, but this sort of petty polemics and misquoting is a disgrace. I am surprised that the Financial Review, with its reputation for accuracy, did not check this quote by Senator Newman. I am sure that it will never again accept gullibly the press releases of Senator Newman without actually checking the facts of the matter.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Has the Federal Government committed any funds to challenging or investigating a challenge to the Australian Federal Police Association in its application to extend its federally registered rules to cover all police employees throughout Australia? If so, why does the Government object to a national union covering all police in Australia? If not, will the Minister explain why the Government has allowed the Australian Federal Police to allocate funding to such a challenge or to the investigation of a challenge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Australian Federal Police Association, being the union which covers members of the Australian Federal Police, has made an application to the relevant industrial tribunal seeking to extend its coverage in a way which would enable it to embrace members of all police forces throughout Australia. I understand that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has decided to notify a dispute-or whatever the terminology is in relation to that particular attempt to extend coverage. This would be a decision taken by the Commissioner within his own budget. It would not require any special allocation by the Federal Government to enable him to undertake that particular process within the industrial tribunals.

ANSWER.PARA: If I understand Senator Calvert's question correctly, there is no special allocation by the Federal Government to enable this proposal to be dealt with in the relevant tribunal. However, this is a matter that the Australian Police Ministers Council has adverted to. All police Ministers are seeking to understand the implications of this proposal by the Australian Federal Police Association, obviously with a view to reaching a considered Australia-wide stance in relation to that proposal. That is being undertaken under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers Council at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I ask again: does the Government object to a national union covering all police in Australia and, if so, why?

—I have tried to indicate that this is a matter which would be best discussed in the context of the Australian Police Ministers Council where all those jurisdictions can get together and, through the police Ministers, come to an appreciation of the implications of this attempt to create an Australia-wide union for police forces throughout Australia. It is in the context of the deliberations of that Council that I will come to a conclusion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Carriage of Dangerous Goods on Aircraft

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware that there has been an increase in the number of incidents of dangerous goods being carried on civil passenger aircraft in Australia? Can the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government is taking to inform the public of the dangers from such goods being carried? Will the Government consider imposing or increasing penalties for passengers who deliberately flout these regulations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, there has been a rapidly increasing incidence of dangerous goods being carried on aircraft. That is of great concern to the aviation industry and to the Government. As a result of that, this morning in Melbourne I launched a public awareness campaign on the carriage of dangerous goods on aircraft. The aviation industry and the CAA are becoming increasingly concerned that a growing number of passengers are not aware of, or are ignoring, the laws relating to carriage of dangerous goods on aircraft. I am sure that all honourable senators, being frequent fliers as we are, would share this concern.

ANSWER.PARA: Every day, passengers are detected carrying or attempting to carry prohibited goods onto aircraft in their hand luggage or in their baggage; some passengers are even found carrying these goods in their pockets onto aircraft. In most cases, the incidents have been found to be as a result of ignorance; the people involved simply did not realise that many common items such as books of matches, cigarette lighter fluids and aerosols have the potential to cause a major aircraft disaster.

Until recent times, I had to include myself in that category. Having seen a fire at Adelaide Airport in the hold of an Australian Airlines Boeing 727 that I was travelling on caused by carrying a book of matches in a suitcase, I want to particularly highlight the real problems of carrying books of matches in hold baggage. A Darwin woman by the name of Mrs O'Brien was in fact brought to the launch this morning-I happen to know her particularly well; I did not realise that she would be there-to talk personally of an incident where her luggage had spontaneously combusted, fortunately before it got onto the aircraft.

A fairly spectacular demonstration was staged this morning in Melbourne by the CAA safety personnel showing what can happen if two normally harmless substances-and the three demonstrated were all household goods found in every home-are mixed together. The results were very spectacular indeed. This is a serious problem.

Ignorance in this case is not bliss and the legal requirement on the carriage of dangerous goods in aircraft exists to protect the airlines and their passengers from these incidents. The CAA will prosecute serious offences, with offenders facing substantial fines or gaol sentences. But legislation alone will not solve the problem, which is why the public awareness campaign that has been launched this week is crucial to ensure that the current situation, whereby Australia has never had an aviation accident caused by dangerous goods, is maintained.

In conclusion, I also draw the attention of honourable senators to a related issue-the role of the Civil Aviation Authority in combating a major chemical fire which started in Melbourne yesterday. All of us would pay tribute to the work of all firefighting services in controlling this major fire in what were clearly very dangerous circumstances for the firefighters.

I particularly congratulate the Civil Aviation Authority rescue and firefighting services from the Melbourne Airport for their contribution. Fortunately, the CAA was holding a major training program for its fire services this week and a number of units-I think nine altogether-and personnel were able to be moved directly from these exercises to attend the chemical fire. The Civil Aviation Authority units from Melbourne Airport acted in response to requests from the Metropolitan fire brigade and are continuing to play a significant role in combating the fire which I understand is still being attended by both fire units and personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Given the recent acquittal of four IRA terrorists charged with the murder of Australians Nick Spanos and Stephen Melrose in Holland, and the fact that some 12 Australians in the last three years have been the victims of political unrest overseas, what representations have been made to the Attorney-General to give Australian courts the power to try foreign terrorists for crimes committed against Australians overseas? What consideration has the Government given to this very important matter, which would bring our law into line with that of many other Western countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator O'Chee has made representations to the Attorney-General as to whether it might be possible for Australian courts to exercise jurisdiction over those who carry out terrorist acts against Australians overseas. Representations have also been made by Professor Wilkinson of the University of St Andrews, and some other world authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst the Government is giving consideration to those representations, some matters need to be kept in mind. One is the sheer difficulty of the court exercising its jurisdiction in a way which is familiar to us. In other words, how does an Australian court examine the evidence in relation to an incident which occurred overseas? How do we get witnesses back to Australia, or take evidence overseas in relation to events which are the subject of the allegation and prosecution? I would have thought that the many days spent by this chamber in relation to similar problems when we considered the war crimes legislation would indicate the grave difficulty of ensuring the fair trial of those who are accused of committing an offence overseas-the question of getting evidence before the jury.

With regard to the particular case that Senator O'Chee mentioned of the murder of Spanos and Melrose overseas, I would not want to agree with any inference I am asked to draw about the correctness of the acquittal verdict reached by the Dutch judges in that instance.

As far as extradition of such accused persons from overseas jurisdictions to Australia is concerned, I think there would be some difficulty in ensuring that all countries would agree to such extradition. The real value of having such a proposal accepted would be in putting pressure on those overseas countries either to prosecute or to extradite, and there is some merit in that. Therefore, Australia is a party to several international conventions which do provide, in limited circumstances, for precisely that sort of regime.

In other words, where there are particular aspects of terrorism, if the overseas country does not prosecute, then Australia-if a party to a particular convention-can ask for the person who is accused to be extradited for trial in Australia. These conventions include the International Convention Against the Taking of Hostages; the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of Crimes Against Internationally Protected Persons, including diplomatic agents; and the Convention for the Suppression of Unlawful Acts against Safety of Civil Aviation which my colleague Senator Collins would, of course, be very familiar with.

In those limited circumstances-for example, if an act of terrorism occurred on a Qantas flight or on a flight to or from Australia-the sorts of procedures which Senator O'Chee mentions could be undertaken in accordance with those conventions. As to the wider question, the Attorney-General will give consideration to the honourable senator's representations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. I would also ask: in the event, for example, that a terrorist passes through a country such as the United Kingdom or the United States, having committed an offence against an Australian in another country, is it not correct that without a change of jurisdiction for Australian courts, even if these people are apprehended in, say, the United States or the United Kingdom, they cannot be tried here in Australia unless we give our courts the power to do so? Would the Attorney-General also take that into consideration?

—It would depend on the international convention that one was trying to implement in relation to the terrorist activity that Senator O'Chee was speaking of. Quite clearly, if the various countries through which the terrorist had passed are parties to a convention-and certainly if the country in which the person has been arrested or is located is a party-I do not see any difficulty in extraditing that person if the crime alleged falls within the terms of the convention. I will seek further and better advice on that and make it available to the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is it not a fact that the Hawke Government promised in 1986 to address the issue of the importation into Australia of tropical rainforest timbers and the related matter of the protection of the world's tropical rainforests? I ask what, then, his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, meant when he said in answer to a question from me last week:

QUESTION.PARA: That is simply acknowledging on the public record very specifically that this is a matter on which the Government has not yet formulated a final position. As is well known, the importation of tropical timber is something that will be considered shortly by Cabinet.

If five years is not long enough to consider this matter, how much longer does the present Government need? Does not this excessive procrastination indicate to everyone that the Government's claim to be concerned about the protection of the environment is, indeed, a sham?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I accept the five-year term that Senator Coulter has referred to. When I was Minister-and I think it would have been in 1988 or perhaps 1989-I got a consultancy to report on the issue. Since then, as I understand it, an interdepartmental committee which consists of representatives from Mrs Kelly's Department, Senator Bolkus's Department and Senator Evans's Department, has been looking at the issue. I believe that it will report very soon and that a submission from Mrs Kelly, and perhaps some other Ministers, will be going up to Cabinet. I believe that will occur within a matter of weeks. As far as I know, consideration has been taking place and Cabinet will debate it very shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think that one can jump into arguments of this kind too quickly. The obvious difficulty always was in the crux of the argument that if Australia and other countries like Australia were to take action to ban tropical timbers, that may have had the opposite effect to what we desired. That was always a concern I had. I do not say that I necessarily agreed with it but certainly it was a concern that required the closest consideration. That is what the Government has attempted to do over the course of the last few years. I would have thought that that was the right way to go. As I said, I understand that Mrs Kelly will be bringing the matter forward soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the 1986 ALP platform resolutions and rules which, in part, refer to the environmental problems caused by the actions of Australians, in particular, and support and provide financial assistance for the conservation of tropical rainforests, particularly in the Asian and South Pacific regions. I ask the question again of the Minister: how much longer does the Government need?

—I think I have already answered the question. The Labor Party conference may have passed a resolution in 1986. I would have to check the resolution. I do not recall it specifically saying that we had to ban the import of all rainforest timbers. In any event, since then, when I was the Minister charged with the responsibility of implementing party policy-and I think I did the right thing-I established a consultancy. Since then, that consultancy has reported and an IDC will finalise government consideration. I do not think that in questions of this nature, which are very serious, one just jumps in. If I started the ball rolling in 1988 or 1989 that it would be considered and a decision made in 1991, I think that is appropriate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Australia's economic relations with Latin America. Perhaps this is one of the first questions in recent years to be asked of the Minister about this area. Does the Minister agree that there is very considerable capacity to increase Australian trade and other economic relations with the republics of Latin America, especially with Mexico, Chile and Colombia? What progress is being made with country by country strategies being formulated in his Department for maximising Australia's trade? What steps are currently being undertaken to build foundations for free enterprise to achieve realisable goals? I ask the Minister, in particular, about those recommendations I proposed in a speech in the Senate on Tuesday evening about Latin America and my urging the Australian Government to urgently negotiate with Mexico a bilateral free trade agreement ahead of the USA-Canada-Mexico North America free trade agreement being concluded later this year and, in conjunction with that, to sponsor Mexico's admission to APEC, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government has been encouraged, as Senator Teague obviously has from his travels, with the political and economic developments which have taken place in many Latin American countries over the past five years or so. Unrepresentative governments and protectionist economic policies have given way to popularly elected civilian leaders committed to improving human rights and to introducing economic reforms.

ANSWER.PARA: I saw for myself some of the quite remarkable progress that has been made, particularly in this respect in Mexico, when I visited there in October last year. I know that Dr Blewett was similarly impressed by the developments that he saw during his visits to Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Argentina and Uruguay this year.

The Government has been developing appropriate trade strategies to take advantage of the manifest economic opportunities that are opening up for us in these countries, in particular in Mexico and Chile. We have been actively encouraging Australian companies to seize the business opportunities now available in that region.

Dr Blewett is a member of the ministerial trade strategy group which has commissioned policy papers on the appropriate trade strategy for developing markets with high potential in which we have certainly included Mexico and Chile. It will be recalled that a Mexican trade delegation accompanied President Salinas when he visited Australia in June last year. Dr Blewett led a reciprocal Australian delegation to Mexico in May. There is another one going to Chile in October.

We have assisted major Australian companies in Latin America, including BHP in Chile, AWA in Venezuela and various coal companies in Mexico. The Australian Government consults regularly with peak business organisations such as the CAI and the Australian-South American Business Council. Our embassies have also been supportive of the local chambers of commerce which have been established in the region.

Australia is sympathetic to the aspirations of a number of the Pacific-focused Latin American countries to join APEC. In principle we favour appropriate expansion of APEC. We are giving priority, as is the rest of the membership of APEC, at the moment to the three Chinese economies. But Mexico would seem to have a reasonably strong claim, particularly in the context of its negotiation with its own free trade agreement with Canada and the United States. How far and how fast that can be advanced will depend on consultation with our APEC colleagues.

The concept of a bilateral free trade agreement between Australia and Mexico raises extraordinary complex questions on who turns out to be the beneficiary. It has a lot to do with the range of products that can be incorporated in the agreement and the general negotiating environment. It is something that we are not adverse to having a look at, as has been the case in the context of Australia-US arguments for such an agreement.

However, it would be premature to leap quite as rapturously into that particular pond as Senator Teague is presently suggesting. However, it is not something that we rule out. It is just that in the present trade context we are giving, overwhelmingly, our priority to the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round rather than looking for an extension of bilateral solutions to trade liberalisation problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs seen a press release by Senator Newman claiming that the Australian War Memorial budget has been cut by nearly 11 per cent in real terms in this year's Federal Budget? Is this accurate?
—At least you are reading our releases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, while it might be nice for me to read the releases, it has caused great concern out in the veterans community, and that is what I want to deal with in this answer. Senator Newman has put out a press release saying that `the budget of the Australian War Memorial has been cut by nearly 11 per cent in real terms in today's Federal Budget'.
—It is precisely 10.52 per cent.

—Once again, Senator Newman has not done her homework. She has rushed into print and given a completely misleading impression of the funds available to the Australian War Memorial. The explanation for the reduction of $1m in the moneys available to the War Memorial is very simple. In 1989, the Government announced that it would provide $5m for the construction of the first stage of a new technology pavilion at the memorial-$3m of this was included in last year's Appropriations; $2m in this year's. For Senator Newman's benefit, that accounts for $1m of the difference and can hardly be incorporated in any comparative figuring of the memorial's budget. There has also been a small reduction in running costs. This simply reflects the efficiency dividend required of all Budget funded departments and agencies and other non-recurring expenditure.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been no turning away from our obligation as a national government for the proper functioning of the Australian War Memorial dedicated to the memory of those who have fallen in the various wars and battles in which Australians have been asked to engage. I believe it is a very simple explanation. Indeed, I believe that the technology pavilion at the memorial will be a very significant addition to the various displays which give so much pleasure to so many people who visit that memorial here in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to a report that prisoners recently released by the African National Congress from ANC establishments outside South Africa have made allegations of torture and wrongful imprisonment. I ask the Minister: firstly, has the Government indicated to the ANC its concern about this matter; and, secondly, were any such prisoners ever held at ANC facilities that have received Australian funds channelled through non-government organisations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, I certainly do not believe so. As to the former part of the question, we have expressed a concern-I have done it myself on occasions in the past-when reports have become current of allegations of this kind being made. There is an acknowledgment within the ANC hierarchy that there have been, on occasion, excesses perpetrated against those formerly within their own ranks whom they have regarded as having been guilty of treachery or disloyalty or things of that kind.

ANSWER.PARA: What we are seeing with these latest allegations may or may not prove well-founded. But they should be regarded as part of the unfortunate trail of debris which the apartheid system has left. Liberation organisations of the kind that the ANC has been do not always behave as one would ideally like in pursuing a struggle of the kind that has been waged. That is the case with every liberation organisation that I can recall in history, not least, for example, in the context of the creation of modern Israel and some of the people who are now running the Government there.

There are excesses of a variety of kinds perpetrated in the course of such struggles. The important thing for us to appreciate is that that now is, hopefully, history and that what we can reasonably look forward to is an environment in the future where excesses that have been committed in the past, not only by one side but overwhelmingly in fact by the other in this situation-the behaviour of the South African Government security forces I would hope does not need to be brought again to Senator Kemp's attention-can be regarded as part of history and that we can look forward to a future in South Africa where nothing like this will ever happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister check to make sure that none of the vast sums of money that the Australian taxpayer has paid to the ANC, either directly or through non-government bodies, has gone to such establishments where torture has taken place?

—I do not recall seeing any item listed for barbed wire, torture camps, gulags or anything of that kind, but I will check the system and see whether that is so. The truth of the matter, as Senator Kemp perfectly well knows, is that although some money has been earmarked for projects developed in cooperation with the ANC, they have been all of a developmental or humanitarian character. They are in the context of training, of education, and the humanitarian support for returning exiles; they are matters of that kind. I will certainly check, in the context of those particular allegations, on the locations involved. But I do not believe there is any conceivable foundation for the imputation that Senator Kemp, with his usual charm, is making.

—Yesterday Senator Michael Baume asked me a question relating to unemployment beneficiaries-I think I am using his term- `expected by the Government in 1991-92'. There was no estimate in the Budget of the peak number of unemployment beneficiaries in the 1991-92 Budget Papers. However, I refer the honourable senator to page 3.9 of Budget Statement No. 3, where the average number of unemployment beneficiaries for 1991-92 is estimated to be 770,000, an increase of 260,000 on the projection a year ago-the same figure a year ago, averaged through the year. These numbers include both Newstart and Job Search beneficiaries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday there was a somewhat noisy Question Time when Opposition senators got a bit excited about investment figures.
—You were the one who got excited.
—Not at all. I invited Opposition senators to come back here today with articulate, informed questions about investment.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I say with goodwill to Senator Button that we did not hear what he was saying. Therefore, we did not hear what figures he was referring to.
—That is an excellent point of order, Mr President-that the honourable senator cannot hear.
—It was a genuine point of order. Can you go through it again?

—Yes. Senator Vanstone and others yesterday got pretty excited about investment figures, and I want to put the figures on the record. I invited those opposite to come back today to ask questions about investment based on fact.
—You have come back with an answer that your minions have prepared. You could not give it off the cuff.
—Order! Let us not have a debate.

— Yesterday honourable senators opposite had a day like the Hindenburg dirigible-they came down and created a great storm here. But let me give them some figures. Let me go to the recent history of investment in Australia. Private business investment as a share of GDP reached record levels in 1989-90.
—In current prices?

—Yes, real figures. The figure was 13.2 per cent compared with the long term average of 11.2 per cent. Those figures are there in chart No. 7 and chart No. 4 in the Budget Papers-in colour, for those opposite who have difficulty with graphs. Those figures go back to 1954, if honourable senators want to make comparisons. What was suggested yesterday by Senator Vanstone and by way of a number of interjections was that somehow there had been some sort of structural decline in, or long term debilitation of, investment under this Government. That condition is well known to the Opposition, but it is not recorded in these figures.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me get this clear both in relation to investment and wages policy, which was again the subject of a bit of excitement on the Opposition benches yesterday. Business investment in plant and equipment and non-residential construction has fallen since the onset of a recession. Of course it has, but the point Opposition senators were trying to make yesterday, it seemed, in so far as there was any articulate point being made, was that between 1983 and 1991 there had been a decline in investment. That is not true.
Senator Alston-No-one said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they did. Senator Alston should keep quiet and let me answer the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston-Investment has fallen in nine out of the last 10 quarters. Is that right or not?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not right. Senator Vanstone, by the way, invented a new economic concept by referring to investment in the traded goods sector.
— `Tradeable' was the word. Read carefully.

—Does the honourable senator draw a distinction between the traded goods sector and the tradeable goods sector? I do not think so. One component of investment that is important to the tradeable goods sector is manufacturing investment. Between 1983-84 and 1990-91 it grew by 7.7 per cent annually. That is reflected in the strong growth in manufactured exports, which is of the order of 20.9 per cent in 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to put these figures on the record for the benefit of the Opposition, and then perhaps those opposite can come in with some informed questions. They have a week to study this matter and ask some informed questions on the investment issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I have moved that the Senate take note of what really amounted to a statement rather than an answer to a question. It seems to me that the Minister is inviting debate on this issue. Whereas I do not want to delay the Senate for long, I think it is fair to put the other side of the argument, as we have heard only one side of it.

The Minister bases his assessment, as I understand it, on the 1984-85 prices, which he indexes. What he fails to advise the Senate is that that particular price basis has been criticised by a number of economists for a number of different reasons. It has been criticised because of the uniquely high price of computers that prevailed at that time, and it is also being criticised because it fails to take into account changes in the quality and productiveness of new investment.

If the Minister had put that on the table he might have made a contribution towards a fairer debate. The facts, it seems, are that if one looks at it in current prices, which a number of economists say is the best way to make a fair assessment and a fair comparison, private new capital expenditure as a percentage of GDP in current prices under the Hawke Government has never exceeded the last two Fraser years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really!

—Senator Button can make another contribution to the debate if he wishes. New capital expenditure in the tradeable sector has, as Senator Vanstone said, been falling as a percentage of GDP since 1986-87. But there are other ways in which the Minister ought to be looking at the poor record of his Government in this regard. One way is to compare its contribution with that of other OECD countries. In fact, he will find that we are near the bottom of the list. Even Senator Button would concede that it is important for Australia to be a competitive nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to one respected commentator who has been collating these figures and writing on this subject for some years and who I believe Senator Button would regard as a respected commentator. I refer to Tim Colebatch, who writes for the Age. He said in an article earlier this year when assessing OECD figures:

Over the three years from 1988 to 1990, Australian investment in plant, equipment and machinery averaged 8.8 per cent of output, if measured in constant prices. The only countries to invest less were Canada (8.1 per cent) and France (8.6 per cent).

So another important aspect of this debate is that we are near the bottom of the list of OECD countries in investment. That is without the new figures that we introduced into the Senate debate last week, which the Minister seems to be disregarding. I shall conclude with Colebatch's view. On the error that the Minister is making in basing his figures on 1984-85 as indexed as opposed to using current figures, he says:
The essential difference between the two is that investment at current prices measures the share of resources being devoted to new investment; for plant and equipment, as reported yesterday-
this article was written in March 1990-
that is now 7.4 per cent GDP, the lowest since 1984.

If the Minister wants to debate the issue we will do so, but he should be fair and put both sides of the argument. Business knows the cost and the Minister knows that the investment that is being made is insufficient. He knows that it affects the competitiveness of this country, and the record is simply not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) has decided to throw down a challenge in regard to figures, and in view of the impact of what has been said here about investment, it is worth making some reference to the number of bankruptcies that are occurring in this country today. It is worth noting when looking at the figures that on an Australia-wide basis bankruptcies increased from 8,550--
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Hill sought leave, as I understand it, to--
—No.

—Senator Hill moved a motion that the Senate take note of my answer. The answer related to investment. Senator Crane might as well introduce sheet blatt or something into this discussion as bankruptcies. It is a totally different subject matter from the subject matter which Senator Hill sought to deal with.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: we are not seeking to extend the debate, but I put it to you that Senator Crane is quite within order: bankruptcies are in part related to poor investment contributions. There is a direct nexus and he is entitled to put his argument.

—I believe that there is a question of relevance here. The answer that the Minister gave was very specifically in response to a question about investment, so I ask Senator Crane to make sure his remarks are relevant to that issue.

—I believe that the figures relating to bankruptcies and investment are very relevant. I shall deal with them quickly. When we talk about investment and the number of bankruptcies, since the Hawke Government has been in power there has been a total of 60,089 bankruptcies or an average of 7,511 per year in that time. However, if we look at the previous eight years of the Fraser Government, we see that there were 30,945 bankruptcies, which is an average of 3,868 per year. The figures have doubled in the Hawke period of government.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go a little further and look at figures for the last two years, we see that there were 8,552 bankruptcies in 1989-90. In 1990-91, bankruptcies increased to 12,991, which is a 52 per cent increase. If we look at my State, we see that bankruptcies have increased from 1,088 to 1,849-an increase of 70 per cent. Senator Button is leaving the chamber because he does not like hearing the figures and the truth about what has occurred; he cannot handle it. As the Minister leaves the chamber, I will mention the figures for his own State of Victoria. In 1989-90 in Victoria, there were 1,809 bankruptcies increasing to 3,098 in 1990-91-an increase of 71 per cent. That shows the impact of the drop in investment and the inadequate economic policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like also to contribute a little to this matter. I think it is time that the Government and public recognised the impact of this Government's policies on fixed capital investment. I am glad that the appalling response of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to a question has given us the opportunity of dealing with the matter. I draw the Minister's attention to page 54 of the recently issued Australian National Accounts which shows that from the March 1989 peak quarter expenditure on new plant and equipment by the private sector in constant dollar terms-in 1984-85 prices seasonally adjusted-has now fallen by something like 29 per cent. It has fallen from $6,070m to $4,322m in the latest quarter. That is a 29 per cent collapse in gross fixed capital expenditure by the private sector on new plant and equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that the Government has to have this drawn to its attention over and over again. It does not yet seem to understand what it has done to destroy this economy. We have people such as Senator Button, the Minister in charge of this disaster, allegedly the Minister for Industry, coming into this chamber and pretending that everything is wonderful; that it is all on track and what a magnificent record we have. The figures clearly show that Senator Button himself has presided over a total disaster.

The lack of competence of the Minister is further underlined by the fact that yesterday we asked him-we have asked him repeatedly specific questions about elements of the collapse, the disaster-how many people would be on unemployment benefit and neither the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) nor Senator Button knew. We asked today what the number of youth unemployed would be as a result of this disaster. After all, the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) admitted yesterday that there would be 900,000 total unemployed. But what are the forecasts for youth unemployment here? The Minister did not know. He did not know again today what the reality of the collapse of private sector capital expenditure was on new plant and equipment. He tried to fudge the issue.

These issues are too big for this Minister and this Government to try to fudge. They have destroyed the capacity of the Australian industrial community to provide jobs for young people. Now they are trying to destroy people's perceptions of the reality. They are fudging the issue over and over again. They might be successful in deceiving themselves, but they will not be successful in deceiving the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too share the concerns of my coalition colleagues about the collapse in private sector investment in this country. I think this is just part of the dilemma that Australia suffers at the moment because, of course, the collapse of private sector investment, especially in the areas of tradeable goods, has been matched by a failure of this Government to be able to fund new investment within the public sector. Of course, that is the real reason why our socialist friends on the other side of the chamber choose to privatise Qantas, choose to privatise Telecom and have been forced to privatise the Commonwealth Bank. The Government of this country no longer has sufficient resources to enable it to invest in the functions which it operates itself.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the collapse of investment in both the private and public sectors which is a hallmark of the collapse of this nation's economy. As my colleague and friend Senator Michael Baume has so ably said, we on this side are dreadfully concerned that this collapse of investment will lead inevitably to more and more unemployment. Already, we see youth unemployment rates, as a result in part of the collapse in investment, exceeding 28 per cent-that is, 28 per cent of young Australians cannot get a job. As a young Australian myself, I am very concerned at what this Government is doing to the future of a whole generation of young Australians. It has spread despondency and desperation amongst the people who will be the future backbone of this country.

It is not just an investment problem; it is now manifestly a problem that touches the lives of just about every household in this nation. That is a result of an eight-year flirtation with the Australian Labor Party and its economically backward policies. That is why it will be only a coalition government that can return prosperity to Australia and once again return opportunity to young Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This afternoon I had the doubtful pleasure of being misrepresented by two Ministers in one Question Time. The Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, and the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, both had a go at misrepresenting me and I now wish to have the opportunity to set the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray said that I had been selective in my reporting of the Government's intentions for defence in the Budget. He questioned my use of a quote from the Budget when I said that the Government had decided to maximise combat capability by reducing the numbers of service personnel. It was a quote from Budget Related Paper No. 1. He felt I was not playing fair by going on to give the whole quote. The Minister's own Budget figures demonstrate that he is reducing the combat forces of both the Air Force and the Navy by 59 and 57 respectively; that is just the combat forces, not all the forces. He is not reducing the combat numbers in the Army because he is moving over 700 people in the training role--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. There is a point at which a personal explanation becomes a debating speech. I would submit that that point has now been reached.
—It is becoming somewhat prolix, Senator Newman. Will you just tell us how you have been misrepresented?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I need to demonstrate the figures from the Budget documents in order to be able to justify my press release.
—I think it could be done less extensively.
—I shall try to keep this brief. I have only brief notes, but I do need to--
—Give us the page numbers you are relying on.

—The Minister has his own page numbers. I would have hoped that he would have known this himself. More than 700 people are moving from the training role to flesh out the regular units in the Army, which have been existing substantially on paper only. On the other hand, however, he is reducing the combat capability of the Army by eliminating two regular battalions, one tank squadron and one engineering construction squadron. That was the part of my press release which the Minister did not read out to the Senate. He thus misrepresented me.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Clearly, Senator Newman is not only debating the issue but also flouting your ruling.
—It is a somewhat overdetailed explanation, Senator Newman. I ask you to maintain the usual proprieties in this exercise.

—I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. However, I point out that it is a technical area as to what the Government has done to the numbers in order to justify my explanation for my press release from which the Minister chose to quote selectively. In Budget Related Paper No. 3 the staff years for Army logistics and support actually increased by 219 and the civilians reduced in that area by 10.

—Staff years for logistic support are getting so far away from arguments about combat capability that is not even funny any more. Madam Acting Deputy President, I suggest that you ask the honourable senator to sit down.
—I ask the honourable senator to please complete the point that she has been trying to make in a very short period. You have been very prolix, Senator Newman.

—I appreciate your concerns, Madam Acting Deputy President. However, it was a question of combat capability or logistics capability on which the Minister was questioning me. Therefore, that is very relevant to my explanation.
—I think that you have made your explanation.

—The Minister also went on to refer to the handing out of a document by me with members of the ACT Liberal Party outside Russell Hill offices some months ago. The document which was being handed out was headed Liberal Party of Australia-Labor Cuts You Out. The Minister said that this was being handed out to civilians in the Department of Defence and suggested that this meant I was being dishonest-or perhaps he meant double-faced-in my concerns about Defence personnel. As anybody who reads this document knows, and anybody who was outside Russell Hill on the day concerned would know, it was Defence personnel who were handed that document. It was addressed to and intended for Defence personnel, not the civilians in the Department of Defence. That really is all that needs to be said about Senator Ray.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to Senator Tate and questions about the War Memorial. The Minister claimed that a press release that I put out on the funding cut for the War Memorial was inaccurate. In fact, anybody who goes back to the Budget documents will find that the Australian War Memorial budget has been cut by 10.52 per cent precisely. The Minister's response to me is simply an explanation as to why that is. It is not denying the accuracy of my statement.

I also said in my press release that the corporate services staff years in the Department of Veterans' Affairs had grown by 213. That is precisely what the Budget document says, as my press release indicated. Five men were sacked last Friday, and for this so-called efficiency dividend of the Australian War Memorial-

TALK.START.PARA: —I stress once again that this goes well beyond that which is necessary to make whatever point Senator Newman wants to make about misrepresentation. This is debating a substantive issue.
—Once again, Senator Newman, you are going beyond what is necessary to make a simple personal explanation. I ask you to keep it brief and to the point.

—I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am keeping precisely to the point that Senator Tate covered just now in the chamber. He referred to the fact that the War Memorial was suffering from an efficiency dividend and that nobody was exempt. However, the ABC has been exempted. I understand that the security staff sacked last Friday may not be the last because the cleaners may be next on the list. It seems to me that the Prime Minister of Australia needs to ensure that the War Memorial of Australia, which commemorates our war dead, is adequately provided for. That is all I ask.
—Senator Newman, you are definitely debating the point.
—I move:
That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a summary record of proceedings of the twentieth meeting of the Sport and Recreation Ministers Council held on 17 August 1990. I suppose that we could congratulate all the Ministers involved, particularly the Commonwealth Minister, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), for having taken only one year to produce this slender document. The time delays involved in reporting to this Parliament are getting ludicrous. I want to protest as strongly as possible to the Commonwealth Minister in another place, Mrs Kelly, about these delays if they are the result of the need to get agreement between States before these reports can be presented to us.

I draw her attention to one of the matters on the agenda for the conference which related to the increase in cooperation that is supposed to exist between the States and the Commonwealth in sporting matters. If they are going to cooperate in sporting matters and try to coordinate their activities, all I say is that I hope they do it a damned sight better than the way in which they coordinate and cooperate to get their reports of these meetings out.

There are a couple of matters of some substance in this report which are of concern to the Parliament. One of them relates to tobacco sponsorship in sport. I know that many honourable senators have concerns about this issue. In this report it is noted that, after discussions, the Council, which is made up of Federal, State and New Zealand Ministers for sport, decided to establish a working party to compile a paper for circulation to all State and Territory members outlining options for application of tobacco sponsorship legislation across Australia. I do not know to what stage that has progressed, but I do note that the report also said:

Members were informed that despite Commonwealth Treasury having estimated that $64 million per annum could be raised by imposing a Commonwealth tax of five cents per tobacco product no decision on the introduction of such a tax had been made.

No doubt this will be a matter of continuing concern. The other matter I want to raise relates to doping, the use of drugs in sport. As a result of the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, known as the Black Committee-of which I think Senator Crichton-Browne was a member, among other honourable senators who are here now-it was decided that the Council would:
. . . agree to develop State doping policies consistent with that of the ASC and to provide details of their respective State doping policies to the Commonwealth;
I do not know whether that has been done, but I hope that it has. The question of privacy has also been of concern in matters of athletes testing positive to prohibited drugs. The report states:

Members were informed that extensive consultations with the Privacy Commission and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission had been undertaken when the ASDA legislation was developed. The Commonwealth indicated that it would reconsider and further advise members on the question of notification to a state institute/academy of any positive test result.

In other words, there is a real problem that under the privacy provisions apparently there is some restraint on the capacity to let a State sporting academy or institute know that one of its people has been tested positive.

The other matter I want to raise very briefly concerns the fact that States have been getting involved in regional games. In fact, I commend the Northern Territory which hosted the Arafura Games in May 1991, which I attended as a guest of Senator Grant Tambling. The games were brilliantly organised and very well-staged and enhanced Australia's reputation in the area, particularly with Indonesia and Malaysia. Perhaps Senator Evans should have been there to welcome the Malaysian athletes. It was an outstandingly successful regional games and I hope other States will pursue this course of action.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present the sixteenth report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, and in accordance with provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia Board on the operations of the bank, together with financial statements and the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1990-91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Reserve Bank of Australia's annual report-which I notice the Senate is now about to take note of half an hour before its embargo time of 4 p.m. today-is an important document. Indeed, it is the second most important document from official sources that is produced in the course of any one year. The Budget documents are the most important ones, of course. The Reserve Bank annual report, coming as it traditionally does two days after the introduction of the Budget, gives the Parliament and the community an opportunity to see one of the other major wings of economic policy advice to the Government express its views on the policy situation and the economic situation over the last 12 months and to give its thoughts for the future.

I must say that the annual report this year-which I have only had occasion to glance at very briefly to date and which will certainly bear further consideration-does not have quite the same vigour as the reports of some other years. It is a much more anodyne report than I remember on certain other occasions. In particular, last year or the year before some very interesting material was contained in that report which, quite rightly, drew very sharp attention to, and criticism of, the whole thrust of the Government's economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it was right.

—As my friend Senator Baume said, it was dead right. This year, on a very quick read of the introductory policy pages, there does seem to have been an attempt to tone down any disagreement with the Government. Indeed, I am sorry to see what appears to me to be some attempt to rewrite the history of the economy and economic developments over the last 12 months.
—You only believe them when they agree with you.
—It is not the only criterion, but it helps.
—It is evidence of good sense.

—The honourable senator is right. Some important points are made which I think require a second look. For example, on page 4 the report says that it was during the last financial year-1990-91-that business sentiment swung from optimism to pessimism and new investment dropped off. That drop in business confidence and the drop-off in business investment certainly happened well before that. One of the staggering things in Government policy making in the last 12 months was the fact that the Government so misread the economic situation and the direction in which the economy was travelling.

SPEECH.PARA: It was quite clear when the 1990 Budget was introduced in August last year that the economy was heading for a major downturn.
