Despite the assurances of the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) only three months earlier that there was no way we were going to have a recession, it was quite clear by the time the Budget was introduced last year that we were into a recession, and that developed a full head of steam within weeks of the Budget being introduced, yet the Government did not pick that up in any way when framing the 1990-91 Budget.

For example, new investment-and this is why I believe that the Government should have picked it up much earlier-did not just drop off in the course of 1990-91. Indeed, gross fixed capital expenditure, according to the Australian National Accounts, has fallen in each of the last seven quarters and for something like nine out of the last 12 quarters. So the evidence was there for all to see. I do not think the bank gives sufficient attention to that point in its report. Perhaps this year it is attempting to be more protective of, or less confrontationist toward, the Government than it has been in previous years.
The bank does draw attention to the progress made in lowering inflation in the last 12 months. In its opening paragraph it states:
For the first time in many years Australia's inflation rate fell below the OECD average and inflationary expectations took a large step down.

However, it makes the very important point on the following page that, despite the improvement in the last 12 months, Australia is still behind the best OECD performers in the inflation stakes. The other thing that the report omits to say is that the last time inflation in Australia was below the OECD average for any period of time was during the Fraser years. It is only this year, when we have seen demand collapse as a result of the crunch of the greatest recession in the last 60 years, that we have managed to clobber the Australian economy down to the level where inflation is now below the OECD average.

During the Fraser years, when there was growth in the economy, the management of the economy was such as to enable us to have growth and, at the same time, an inflation rate below that of most of the rest of the world.

The report spends much time discussing the importance of inflation and the importance of getting it down on a permanent and sustainable basis. It deals with the role of interest rates and monetary policy in that context. Again, it leaves some things half said, which can give a misleading impression. For example, it states:

. . . nominal interest rates have been lowered, since January 1990, in response to the changes in the economic cycle and the inflationary environment. The very high rates which helped to slow the excessive growth of 1988 and 1989 ceased to be necessary as the economy slowed. Short-term interest rates in June 1991 were 7 1/2 percentage points lower than eighteen months earlier.

That is certainly true in nominal terms. The point the report does not make is that with the fall of inflation we have had the maintenance of huge real interest rates. It is the real interest rate that is the important consideration in determining investment, consumption and savings decisions. In Australia today we have virtually the highest real interest rate of any country in the Western world. For the bank and the Government to trumpet this fall in interest rates, without talking about real interest rates, is an indictment of them both because it is very misleading indeed.

The bank is hopeful in its report that inflationary expectations have been lowered on a sustainable and sustained basis. I question that. I hope that the bank is right, but I think there are some very real grounds for doubting that. One only has to look at the Government's own Budget forecast for this year.

It does not seem to be widely recognised yet, and certainly many of the economic commentators have not picked up this fact, that the Government in its Budget forecast is going for a growth in average weekly earnings-a growth in wages-of 4 1/2 per cent this year over last year. Treasurer Kerin, in his press statement immediately after the Budget, admitted-and it is extraordinary that this figure is not in the Budget documents-that the June 1992 on June 1991 increase in wages will be no less than 6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus superannuation.
—As my friend Senator Watson just pointed out, those figures seem to exclude the further added wages cost of the compulsory superannuation that is now to be levied.
—How much is that superannuation levy going to be before June 1992?

—That is not a relevant point because it will add to the cost expectations. It will also add further to costs right at the time that the Government claims to be expecting some form of economic recovery. The Government reckons it will get economic recovery in the course of the 1992 calendar year-and every person in the business community has told the Government this, but it does not believe them-right at the time that it is going to impose a compulsory new cost on jobs and, therefore, on all costs of input. It will cost this economy something between 50,000 and 101,000 jobs and it will add a minimum of 2 to 4 per cent to inflation. That, I might point out, is a cost which will not be compensated for by this Government by one cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the inflationary expectation situation, the Government's own figures point to an underlying surge towards higher inflation. We simply cannot have real wage growth, year on year, of 4 1/2 per cent and June quarter on June quarter of 6 1/2 per cent; inflation at 3 per cent; and growth of GDP at 1 1/2 per cent, which the Government is claiming but which is very low and is probably optimistic.

Even taking those figures at face value, the only conclusion that can be drawn from them is that they can be achieved only if one of two things happens. The first is an enormous increase in productivity. That is simply not achievable on the basis of our history or on the basis of the scope for increased productivity within an economy that, virtually, will not be growing. That one can be ruled out. The only thing left is a further massive increase in unemployment. There are no alternatives to those conclusions. Both of them in the end-particularly the lack of ability for productivity growth-add up to a further increased cost pressure on the economy and increased inflationary pressure.

I hope that the bank, in terms of its comments on inflationary expectations, is correct, but there is a great deal of evidence to suggest that that is optimistic at best. Indeed, in that context, it is very interesting to remind ourselves of the abuse that the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank, John Phillips, got last year when he talked about the role of monetary policy and its requirement to be directed at curbing inflation. The then Treasurer, Mr Keating, in perhaps the most disgraceful exhibition of public humiliation and criticism of a public official that I can ever recall, berated the Deputy Governor for expressing such views. Mr Keating and the Government have become very late converts to the cause of lower inflation-very late converts indeed. The conversion has come in the form of rhetoric rather than substantive policy changes to date.

In the Senate yesterday, in response to my question to him, Senator Button acknowledged that if the Government in its Budget this year had exercised more and correct financial self discipline, then the level of interest rates would be lower than they now inevitably will be. So yesterday, the Leader of the Government in the Senate admitted that the fiscal laxity in this Budget will cause interest rates to be higher than they should be. That is going to have a very damaging impact on investment and savings and, therefore, on job growth and, indeed, a very detrimental impact on the maintenance of existing jobs.

In this country in the last 12 months we have had the largest fall in employment in living memory-certainly in the post-war period. In the last 12 months 308,500 people lost their jobs. That is almost 1,000 jobs for every day of the year. The policies that this Government has pursued during that period, and which it is continuing to pursue through a lack of discipline and fiscal responsibility in the Budget, will compound that problem during the year ahead. The great tragedy is that this Government is so concentrated-so obsessed-with its leadership problems and the divisions within it, that it is diverting attention away from the main game, which is trying to get this economy right and doing something for jobs and for the Australian people.

Today, again, the leadership struggle has resurfaced-not that it needed much resurfacing, but it has bubbled again even more intensely-as a result of the Budget. Great stories are being put around by the supporters of either Mr Keating or Mr Hawke as to the relative merits of the Budget. The amazing thing I find about the Keating camp-if one can believe it-is that Mr Keating nowadays is advocating a whole range of economic policies and an economic policy direction different from that which he was purporting to pursue as recently as two months ago when he was still the Treasurer.

In that Budget we have seen in particular the better cities plan, which was pushed through, according to all reports-and they have not been denied-by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Deputy, the leader of the Left, Mr Howe, despite strong opposition by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis). That decision will cost the Australian taxpayer $800m over the next five years. The main spending requirement of the plan will come at a time when there will be even greater need than at present-if such can be the case-for restraint on government spending. The Government has built a time bomb into the spending process over the next few years as a result of that better cities plan, as occurred in the March industry statement. The Senate might recall that the financial impact of the March industry statement decisions in the first year, 1991-92, will amount to $447m; that next year, 1992-93, it will amount to about $850m; and that the following year the cost to the taxpayer will be $1.2 billion. Again, we have a series of economic policy decisions which, when they are implemented, will lead to increased pressures on the Budget, therefore on taxpayers, therefore on interest rates, therefore on investment, and therefore, inevitably, on jobs in this country.

The great indictment of this Government is that, two days ago when it had the opportunity in the Budget to do something for the people of Australia, who want above all an opportunity to work and to have some security in their job situation, it made a series of decisions which, collectively, added up not to any good news on the job front but, inevitably, to a worsening in that situation. The Reserve Bank report is important in that context. It gives a somewhat different perspective in terms of official advice to government. It rightly stresses the critical importance of inflationary expectations and of the need to continue at all costs to bear down on inflation if we want in time a productive, dynamic economy that can create increased living standards and jobs for our people.

As I said, whilst the performance has not matched the rhetoric, the Reserve Bank report is to be commended for what it says about the importance of inflation. It warrants further consideration by us all. In the meantime, I welcome its tabling today. I think it is an important contribution to the economic policy debate, although there are points about it that one obviously would have some real doubts about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The very thorough analysis and the inconsistencies that have been drawn to the Senate's attention this afternoon in the content of the annual report and financial statements of the Reserve Bank of Australia by Senator Jim Short, representing the shadow Treasurer in this chamber, must give Treasury officials, banking leaders and business personnel great comfort that in a coalition government the finance portfolio is in such strong hands. The Reserve Bank Act, which is one of several pieces of legislation which define the functions, powers and responsibilities of the Reserve Bank, says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the duty of the Board, within the limits of its powers, to ensure that the monetary and banking policy of the Bank is directed to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and that the powers of the Bank under this Act, the Banking Act 1959 and the regulations under that Act are exercised in such a manner as, in the opinion of the Board, will best contribute to the stability of the currency of Australia; the maintenance of full employment in Australia; and the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia.

It would appear that the Government has available to it in the form of the Reserve Bank a means by which to address a few of the economic problems which currently face Australia. Yet nowhere in the Budget Speech delivered a few days ago did I hear mention of the Reserve Bank and the role it would be performing over the next 12 months in ensuring economic prosperity, the welfare of the people of Australia and the maintenance of full employment. Nowhere was that role stressed.

Indeed, the Government has insisted on binding the hands and muzzling the mouth of the Reserve Bank, instead of giving it full rein to act in a way that would allow it to carry out its duty as set out in the Act-those words that I have just mentioned. The question of the autonomy of the Reserve Bank has been on the political agenda for some time now and, unfortunately, it still remains unresolved. There are many examples around the world, such as among our Pacific neighbours-New Zealand being the nearest-where the Reserve Bank has been given autonomy and specific goals to work towards. We always thought those objectives were goals but, unfortunately, our Reserve Bank is not meeting those objectives at the present time.

I believe that we have to reform the operations of the Reserve Bank to ensure that it acts in the best interests of our country. From a reading of the annual report and the chapter entitled `The Focus of Policy', a strong link between the Government and the Reserve Bank is evident. Phrases such as low inflation being `an important pre-condition for sustained economic progress in the 1990s' are straight out of the Budget Papers. That chapter states:

Inflation remained the focus of monetary policy even after the surge in demand had passed. Last year's Report, with its theme of inflation, reflected the Bank's belief that a consistent framework throughout the whole of the economic cycle would be necessary to lower inflation decisively.

However, the recent actions of the Government on the wages front, including the Budget-announced policy directives on superannuation, will only lead to a further breakdown of what should be a coherent wages policy, and such demonstrable actions make a mockery and a complete sham of its inflation-fighting priority, which has now been stated in two reports of the Reserve Bank.

Industries in Australia must be encouraged to become more competitive to increase job opportunities, and government policies must be directed to this end. I remind the Senate that real interest rates-that is, the difference between the nominal rates and the inflation rates-are historically high in such depressed conditions. The deliberately high interest rates pursued by the Government are maintaining an artificially high exchange rate. Not only does the interest input factor impact on cost to businesses, thereby diminishing profit, but it also reduces consumer demand. At the same time an artificially high exchange rate which is exacerbated by a high interest regime has the impact of reducing the relative cost of imported goods which are in competition with locally produced goods. Therefore, interest rates must be brought down to save the economy from a further dramatic collapse in conditions which have been unparalleled since the 1930s.

Senator MICHAEL BAUME (New South Wales) (3.59 p.m) I too want to speak briefly to the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It is a very important report because, as Senator Short said, while it does not have the fire and brimstone of Mr John Phillips's report of a couple of years ago-which said that the Reserve Bank was right and the then Treasurer and Treasury were patently wrong-parts of this report dramatise the collapse, the failure, of government policy. Even though those parts of it are written in very restrained language, the pointers are there, and no doubt Senator McMullan will be eagerly looking to those pointers when I line them up for him. The first point I would like to make is that the Reserve Bank said:
Even before the national accounts and the labour market confirmed the weakness of the economy, it was clear that the slowing in activity was greater than had been expected.

In other words, the Government was lying to us for months and months about the real nature of the downturn. Yet the Reserve Bank says that it was clear that the slowing down was greater than had been expected. The report, to an extent, tries to justify the incorrect forecasts at this time last year. It said:
Those assumptions were reasonably close to the mark, although the sluggishness of world industrial output contributed to a significant fall in Australia's commodity prices.

The terms of trade, while they did show a downturn, continued to be higher than they had been in the 1982-83 recession, which the Government likes to remind everyone about continually, generally with totally false and massively incorrect analogies.

The Reserve Bank, in referring to the corporate balance sheet assets becoming hard pressed by reduced cash flows and declining assets prices, particularly in respect of commercial property, along with the significant fall in commodity prices, stated:
These developments, which had not been widely forecast, led several financial intermediaries (and other repositories of household savings) into difficulties.

The Government did not know about this and seemed to be caught absolutely unprepared. I would have thought that the Reserve Bank should have been in a position to have a better level of information about the downturn in balance sheet assets.

The Reserve Bank says that price expectations will remain at low levels only if the public maintains its confidence in the Government's anti-inflationary resolve. There is a clear warning for this Government, which I certainly hope Senator McMullan takes on board. There must be a great level of difficulty within the business community in accepting the fact that the Government should be given confidence in its anti-inflationary resolve. How can the Australian community have any confidence when the left wing of the Labor Party opposes even the present Budget? It is demanding further spending, and Mr Hawke must be a captive of the left wing in order to remain in power.

The fact is that the Opposition's policies, which over the years have been attacked by the Government because they demanded that there be a reduction in inflation, are totally confirmed by the Reserve Bank annual report, which underlined the following:

. . . living with high rates of inflation, out of concern for the costs of reducing it, is not a credible policy . . . inflation perverts the taxation system and the pattern and financing of investment, and the way income and wealth are redistributed in favour of those best placed to take advantage of those distortions.

I notice that all the people who are described as Bob Hawke's mates seem to be in that category, at least while the situation was going their way. The report says that more recently the authorities have been attaching greater priority to reducing inflation after early attempts to slow it had made only limited progress. All these factors and particularly the sustained high real interest rates needed to reduce inflation have also helped to change the environment in which business operates. Why on earth was it only recently that the authorities attached greater priority to reducing inflation? As the report says, inflation perverts the taxation system and results in long term economic disaster, which is what we have had. On inflation, the bank said:

By the end of July, ten-year bond yields were about 11 per cent, compared with the latest CPI-based estimate of inflation of less than 5 per cent, leaving Australian real bond yields at the high end of the international spectrum.

As Senator Short said, our real interest rates are very high by international standards. In fact, since then, they have got relatively higher than at least one or 1 1/2 percentage points. As the bank said-and this is a key point; this is key subtle criticism of this Government:
To the extent that this reflects a premium for uncertainty about future inflation, it suggests that inflationary expectations need to be brought down further . . .

In other words, the markets do not trust this Government, and they have no reason to do so. That is why this matter of expectations, which Senator McMullan did not seem to understand when Senator Short was speaking, are so absolutely vital. One of the points that the Reserve Bank made disagrees with what Senator Cook and Senator Button have been saying recently in Question Time. They have been denying that there is any relationship between wage levels and unemployment at any point. The Reserve Bank said:

The pace of this recovery is likely to be somewhat slower than recoveries from previous recessions, in part because of the corporate debt overhang and in part because policies are expected to remain relatively firm. This could limit the size of the increase in employment during 1991-92 . . .
I do not know where they get the idea of there being an increase in employment. The Budget figures show a fall in the levels of employment. The report continued:
. . . although the trend in wage costs will also be critical in that regard.

The Reserve Bank said that the trend in wage costs is critical to levels of employment. Frankly, I would much rather believe the Reserve Bank on this matter than Senator Cook, who has just come in, because Senator Cook's assertions that wage levels have nothing to do with employment levels are clearly totally demolished by the Reserve Bank itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Government is going for a 3 per cent increase in real wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly. Despite what the Reserve Bank says here, the Government is going not only for a 6 per cent June-on-June wage rise but also for a big increase in the cost of employment at the end of that series, which will affect cost expectations-that is, a tax on employment involved in the superannuation payments. The report continued:

SPEECH.PARA: While the current account deficit has been reduced in 1990/91-
this is one of the Government's great achievements-
some of this reduction reflects cyclical factors which will be unwound as the economy recovers.

It seems to me that, if it is not a fundamental or basic reduction, the Government is going to face more and more trouble. The Reserve Bank is carefully pointing that out. However, one of the key elements of criticism that the Reserve Bank made of this Government is implicit at the bottom of page 18. When arguing that the main task for monetary policy this year is to peg the progress that has been made on inflation over the past year, it said:
Cyclical falls in inflation-where prices slow in response to weak activity-have occurred in the past . . .
It pointed out that inflation dropped from 12 per cent in 1982 to a little over 5 per cent in 1984. It continued:
On that occasion much of the gain was lost within a couple of years, an outcome which policy makers are determined to avoid on this occasion.

In other words, we had all the pain to get the inflation rate down to 5 per cent in 1984 when this Government was in office. It destroyed our chances by its incompetent and disgraceful budgetary policy, and its lack of fiscal policy in 1984, 1985 and 1986. It destroyed our chances of having a sustained lower level of inflation. The Reserve Bank points that out exactly. That is when the failures of this Government's policies first impacted.

As we in Opposition have been saying for years, we are now suffering the consequences of that policy disaster by the Treasurer who at that time was being touted as the world's greatest treasurer. He set the scene and destroyed the results of all the pain of the 1982-83 recession. The Government bought short term success by increasing employment at huge and overwhelming long term cost to this country-huge foreign debt-and now huge, entrenched unemployment. The report of the Reserve Bank states:
An important part of the ongoing process is for wage-setting over the coming year to embody these lower price expectations.

If wage setting is to embody lower price expectations, I wonder why the Government is boosting wages so much. Why is it disagreeing with the Reserve Bank? Why is it flying in the face of its advice? The Reserve Bank then gives a little bit of a passing gesture to the Government's policy by saying:
That does not imply any reduction in real living standards; a decent productivity performance would allow goods prices to rise more slowly than wage costs.
But then, here is the sting in the tail; it goes on to say that what is needed is:
. . . structural changes and improvements in work practices . . .

It does say that business and government instrumentalities have implemented things during these years. But the fact is-as we have seen on the waterfront-that these structural changes are minimal and have achieved only a fraction of what is vitally needed.

The Opposition's policies have concentrated on the need for massive structural change. For example, Mr Howard has been at the forefront of this with labour market reform. All the time that Dr Hewson has been in this Parliament, he has been calling for structural change. It is absolutely vital. The Reserve Bank here in its report is supporting the Opposition's policy.

In conclusion, this Reserve Bank report, even though it is in very modest terms, quite clearly provides an indictment of this Government's incompetence going back to 1984 when it dropped the ball. Instead of chasing the ball, it has been kicking the people of Australia vigorously and unfairly, when it should have done what it had the opportunity to do-win the game for us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Speaker, in answer to a question, tabled a copy of the agreement reached between the Presiding Officers, the Trades and Labor Council and the Liquor Trades Union in the presence of the Minister for Industrial Relations. In also tabling the agreement, I advise honourable senators that the basis of the settlement was that former employees of the PCS can either retain their redundancy payment or choose income maintenance in accordance with aims to provide assistance to people who have been made redundant.

INTERJECT.PARA: If the former employees choose income maintenance, they must repay the severance element of their redundancy payment. Under the agreement, former PCS employees have until 20 September to decide whether they wish to retain their redundancy payment or take income maintenance. Consequently, it will not be known how many people wish to take up the offer of income maintenance until 20 September. However, I understand that sufficient funds will be available within the sum allocated by the Department of Finance to run the PCS this financial year to cover this one-off payment.

The agreement is in accordance with normal Federal public sector redundancy arrangements and represents payments or benefits, the range of which would be generally available in similar circumstances in public sector employment. It has, at all times, been the goal of the Speaker and me that staff should be treated fairly, that the proceedings of Parliament should not be disrupted and that our obligations for the efficient and economic operation of Parliament House be discharged. These goals have been fully achieved. I table the agreement.

I point out that by contracting out, we expect to reduce the subsidy to $1m per year, which will be some $1.2m less than we achieved under the previous arrangement. This process was in line with the Government's policy of micro-economic reform. The Speaker and I have at all times observed proper employer and industrial policies. This has been confirmed by proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission in relation to our alleged respondency to an award of the Commission and in the fact that an agreement putting in place processes acceptable to all parties has been reached.

In all industrial disputes there are instant experts and it is fair to say that in this dispute the matter might still be at a stalemate without the intervention of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), both as an honest broker and as an adviser on acceptable industrial practice. We had reached a stalemate and in all such circumstances, both parties are required to give a little. In this case, we agreed to adopt acceptable redundancy, retention and redeployment provisions while refusing the union's claim to overturn the contract and revert to the previous arrangement.

Senator Hill yesterday accused the Speaker and me of weakness in dealing with the picket imposed by the TLC. I reiterate that at no time were the proceedings of the Parliament seriously disrupted. Contrary to claims, there was no great delay in getting mail in or out of the building, newspapers were delivered and the work of the chambers went on as usual. Despite some claims that the Budget would be disrupted, normal procedure followed. The only inconvenience was that members and senators had to walk a few hundred yards to their offices.

I might remind senators that neither the Speaker nor I have responsibility for Commonwealth cars, nor was the picket placed within the parliamentary precincts, where the Speaker and I would have had powers to engineer its removal. I indicated earlier in the dispute that the proceedings of Parliament would not be disrupted, and they were not. I indicated that the Speaker and I would spare no effort to resolve this dispute as quickly as possible, and that has now been done. It has been done in the normal manner whereby industrial disputes of this nature are resolved by negotiation and conciliation. I thank the Minister for Industrial Relations for his role in the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

We will obviously want to give careful consideration to the detail of your statement, Mr President. I have to confess that at first blush it seems that the intervention of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has meant that further taxpayers' funds have been expended in resolving this dispute, but we will consider that and might comment upon it in due course. However, I want at this time to make a further comment on the pickets, particularly in view of the comment you just made, Mr President.

It is the view of this side of the chamber that the picket was an illegal obstruction. Contrary to what Senator Cooney indicated yesterday, the pickets were stopping the passage of vehicles. That is an illegal activity. In some instances, picketers were searching vehicles that were entering the precincts of the Parliament. That is also illegal. It should not have been tolerated and it should not have been particularly condoned by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), who said in this chamber that he supported the picket and therefore he supported the illegal activity. That is not the way in which we on this side of the chamber believe that industrial relations should be practised. We will maintain that position.

As I said yesterday, regardless of whether it was a hindrance simply in relation to the Parliament-which it was because senators' mail was hindered, senators' access to printing facilities was hindered and in other ways their work was hindered-it involved a principle that applies to all institutions, to all enterprise in Australia. Australians who wish to go about their work should not be hindered by illegal picketing. As Senator Crane is aware, it is what has happened in the meat industry in Victoria, with dire consequences. It is not the direction which industrial relations should take in this country, and this Government should not accept that it should. That remains our position and it will continue to be our position. Mr President, we will consider your statement and perhaps bring it on for debate when the Senate resumes after the break.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have heard your statement. I think it is a full and fair presentation of the circumstances of this matter. I thank you and your fellow Presiding Officer, the Speaker, for your comments about my role in this matter. I say in that respect that if I had a role at all it was simply to provide a focal point upon which the parties could come together and provide a forum in which they could talk through the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case dismissals in employment had occurred, the employer-employee relationship which would give access to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in normal circumstances did not obtain, and the re-employment of some workers by the contractor complicated the situation as to whether or not an avenue into the Industrial Relations Commission could be found. The case was complicated to the point at which, if the parties had wished to be difficult about the matter, the matter would not then have gone to a conference-a normal event in these circumstances-in the Commission. My role was simply to provide, in the absence of the normal circumstances, an avenue for discussion, and to provide whatever background I might have in this subject to aid the parties.

It is indeed true that the parties in the end came to their own agreement-as advised and as assisted, of course. The fact that the agreement has now been accepted, that the dispute is now over, that the pickets have now been removed and that any minor impediment-nay, irritation-which may have occurred has gone as well is a tribute to the parties. It is something I think this Parliament, and this chamber in particular, should celebrate. A matter that was difficult and sensitive has been removed, and that is a good thing. I think that commendation is due, Mr President, both to you and to Mr Speaker.

The question of the pickets has been raised in comments by Senator Hill not just today but also on previous occasions. Senator Hill takes a point of view which I think anyone is entitled to take; that is, that there are acts which some may hold to be illegal being performed, and that the full force of the law should be visited upon those against whom it is alleged there is law breaking going on. That is a point which anyone can make which several people argue strongly.

I see in the recent events in Canberra no comparison with events that may or may not occur in the meat industry, which has been referred to by Senator Hill. Nor do I see in the recent events in Canberra any onerous impositions, because, as has been said in the President's statement, the normal affairs of the Parliament at a sensitive time such as Budget time went ahead without complication. Nonetheless, the point still can be made. To that point I say this: the strength of law in matters of this nature is best regarded with some tolerance. It is not unusual that in areas of law dealing with social questions or questions of an industrial relations matter tolerance, moderation and sensitivity are shown.

I say that because we ran the risk here of having an escalation of this dispute, which would have obfuscated the primary reason for the disagreement and transported the dispute to a level dealing with fundamental questions that divided the parties. The logical outcome would have been that the dispute would have run for a long time, that the ability to resolve it would have vanished and that the possibility of then engaging in a dispute about other factors which so deeply divide this community would have arisen. When one comes to a set of circumstances such as this, one should approach it with a sense of some tolerance about the activities being engaged in, but with a keen idea that the primary issues in contention need to be identified. As non-contentious a climate as possible should be created so that the parties can be brought together to discuss the real issues that divide them to see whether, on a more considered view, an answer can be found.

In the circumstances, what has unfolded is a tribute to the tolerance, moderation and sensible behaviour of both sides. We now have an outcome and, because we have an outcome, 20 : 20 hindsight can be applied as to whether or not those involved conducted themselves properly. I do not think anyone was injured. No delay occurred to this chamber, as far as I can tell, and any inconvenience that may have occurred was moderate. I quite enjoyed the short walk from the picket line to the House, which is a walk that I now regret I do not have every day.

There is an outcome which is acceptable and which, in terms of the statement just put down by the Presiding Officers, incurs no extra penalty in terms of supplementation on the budget of the Parliament. Any question that has been raised by Senator Hill about taxpayers' money needs to be looked at from that point of view. I understand that the settlement that has been obtained can be handled within the normal guidelines of the Department of Finance on matters of this nature. If one wants to try to pretend that this is a dispute resolved at the expense of the taxpayer, I think that is a hard row to hoe.

The Presiding Officers made a decision based on investigation and report that it was desirable in their management of the Parliamentary Catering Service that the service be put out for tender and be let to a contractor. That is a decision which is in their right to make. The Opposition has offered no objection to it. I assume, therefore, that in this case silence can be regarded as support for the decision of the Presiding Officers.

Given that a decision of that nature is made there is clearly a human resource management problem, to put it in the jargon of the issue. A number of people, 147 in total in this case, faced immediate loss of employment. Ten of those people who were covered by an award for retention and redeployment did not lose their jobs but 137 faced immediate loss of employment. That is the law and no-one argues that that is not the law.

But there are provisions that apply in the case of redundancy. The Presiding Officers made, I think, a quite reasonable settlement on the redundancy front. However, in the economic circumstances of the time-circumstances in which this Government takes no comfort whatsoever-there is, unfortunately, a high level of unemployment which gives anxiety to individuals facing a depressed labour market with little opportunity in a smaller city setting like Canberra of finding alternative jobs for themselves. It is no wonder in those circumstances that their anxiety arises.

How those matters are resolved are matters of judgment and degree. They are not matters of perfect understanding. There is no scientific explanation of applying some particular formula whereby all human problems are dealt with in a logical framework. It requires judgment and degree.

The underlying legal issue was whether these employees were entitled to coverage by the redundancy and redeployment award, colloquially known as the RRR award. That matter was dealt with by the Commission and their entitlement was found not to exist. In the settlement arrived at the standards held up by that award have not been met. So the Presiding Officers are not in a situation of having found one level in the Commission at which they were not obliged to observe certain standards and then having gone out and obliged those standards. The standards are different.

Nonetheless, the standards that are different are standards which a compassionate employer, in recognition of the realities of the labour market, the low wages of the workers concerned and the lack of job opportunities, would make to ensure that in a transition of managerial arrangements occasioned by economic need and not the responsibility of the workers concerned, the workers would not be the victims of the decision that was necessary out of economic need, and their needs would be reasonably met. I think that is a tribute to the employers concerned.

If there is an imputation, as seemed to occur in a question to the Speaker yesterday from the former Leader of the National Party, that the terms of the settlement may be too lavish, all that I have said would rebut that because there is a need to recognise the circumstances and deal with them. However, if honourable senators in this place at some time want to try to sustain an argument of that nature, under the general catering award that now applies to employees of the contractor, I point out that the highest rate is that for a chef.

The rate for a chef in the general award is $19,776. That is the award rate. We are not talking about workers who live high on the hog. We are talking about low income earners in this country. We stand here as members of this place receiving a base salary of $64,768. If the imputation is that the settlement has been lavish, one ought to see ourselves as others outside this chamber see us-people in receipt of a base salary of $64,768 complaining about a settlement which would ensure that workers receiving $19,776 might have an opportunity over six months to try to find alternative employment at around that level and might find an opportunity to be redeployed somewhere else in the Commonwealth or, at the end of that time, face unemployment.

Whatever huffing and puffing might go on if this point is raised, honourable senators should keep in the back of their minds the disparities in income that we are talking about. I return to the point: these are low income earners. It ill behoves us to rail against a settlement, which in a flat labour market enables them to have some security, to find alternative employment. Frankly, we would be seen, dare I say it, as hypocrites were we to do that.

The negotiation that occurred is, in microcosm, what is being debated in macrocosm about industrial policy. The Opposition would say about industrial policy that enterprise bargaining is the model. That is often said-Mr Howard says it frequently. He does not define its meaning. However, in these circumstances negotiations were conducted by the management in the form of the Presiding Officers with the workers and their union in the form of the catering staff. They arrived at an outcome without benefit of the Commission, which is an exact definition of what the Opposition talks about in its industrial relations policy.

The fact that it has worked on this occasion should be something that the Opposition commends rather than opposes because this is the model that it wants to force on the rest of the Australian community.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am glad to have this opportunity of speaking to the report of the Australian Soil Conservation Council on its meeting in Nelson, New Zealand. In doing so, I want to first congratulate all those in the Australian community who are making strenuous efforts to promote soil conservation activities across Australia. Senator Brownhill also asked me to associate himself with the remarks on this report because he has had to go to another meeting this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years we have often heard of several pressing issues in environmental matters which have been competing for the public's attention, including energy, pollution and the greenhouse effect. But soil degradation would be our most basic issue. Often in the media it is forgotten and there do not seem to be many votes in this issue when politicians parade before the public their concerns about the environment. Yet soil degradation would be Australia's No. 1 environmental issue.

Over thousands of years, floods, dry spells and the prevailing wind patterns have combined to strip numerous layers of the fine, fertile soil from Australia's surface. Most of it has ended up in the Pacific and Indian oceans, stretching out from the coastline in two plumes to the north-west and south-east, mirroring the prevailing wind systems. We all would have read numerous stories about windblown soil from the Australian mainland which is regularly dumped on the New Zealand Alps.

Nothing is more important to a nation's environment than its soil and the preservation of the quality of its land. The loss of our thin and fragile soil, the progressive degradation of our land and the expansion of the desert and arid areas of the Australian continent would be our No.1 environmental challenge. Left unmet, the result will be a disaster on a massive scale for Australia.

By 1983, about 66 per cent of all our lands were in need of some conservation measures. Significant long term problems have also arisen as a result of the progressive breaking down of the structure of Australian soils. Soil conservation is of particular importance not only to the greenies, to whom this Government and the media often pander, but it is of vital importance to those Australians who often have much more to do with the environment, and that is the man and the woman on the land.

Only in the past few years has the subject of soil degradation come a little into focus. This is due partly to the fact that during the past few years Australia has experienced a series of storms, droughts and floods which were directly or indirectly related to the problems. Also, the nation's stocktaking during the Bicentenary brought a reawakening of concern for what has been happening to Australia's land. It is estimated that about half of Australia's rural land requires treatment for land degradation. Human activity has been responsible for about half of that degradation. Indeed, Australian farmers play the leading role in the environment, caring for over 200 million animals and millions of square kilometres of land. The care of this nation's environment, to a remarkable degree, is already in their hands.
Agriculture is a sustainable and renewable industry, yet there is growing criticism, much of it from ignorance, of farming practices. Indeed the report notes that:
. . . although the rural recession has reduced the scale of soil conservation work, it has not reduced landholders' commitment to land care.

That is because farming is very much a family activity with a number of generations usually working the same farm. Consequently, there is a powerful incentive for each generation to leave the land in a better state than that in which they found it. The majority of farmers have for decades been environmentally conscious and have taken many initiatives to improve the environment. As a matter of fact, in our Kingaroy area farmers really apply rules for soil conservation to their farms, as no doubt do farmers in many other rural areas of Australia. They consult with their soil conservation experts in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and take action to ensure the best conservation of their land. This is very necessary in Queensland at present when everything is so very dry. A farmer has just taken over a new farm opposite to where I live and he has put a lot of time, money and work into making sure that he conserves the land. I commend the work done by many in the community on land care programs, but I also note that we cannot leave the fight against soil degradation solely to farmers, who are already battling other outside forces and are currently being squeezed on all sides. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Report No. 5 on details of determinations made under the Higher Education Funding Act sets out the grants for higher education under different sections of the Act which, in total, amount to $2.9 billion. I want to mention areas of particular concern, not only to me but to everybody engaged in higher education today. In particular, I want to focus upon section 21 grants which are for projects of national priority. There were 14 separate determinations during 1990 and more than half of them were wholly or partially for expenses related to the wasted amalgamation exercises. This is sadly typical of what the Hawke Labor Government is doing to promote the clever country. Section 21 grants should be for research projects or for the development of new courses. The total amount for 1990 was $28m, but a large proportion of this total was eroded in 1990 to pay for amalgamation expenses which institutions did not want and which since that time have led to a very low state of morale in our universities.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that we do not know from this report exactly how much was spent on the amalgamation exercise. The determinations for the year 1990 are all listed with the date and the purpose of each determination, but no amount is listed against the determinations themselves. All the report provides is the total amount and the amounts which went to individual institutions, but it is impossible to marry those amounts with the determinations. So we know what institutions received money but we do not know for what purpose. For instance, the Australian National University received $315,000 under section 21 in 1990, but over half of this amount-$200,000-was for amalgamation expenses. I was only able to find this out by direct inquiry to the Australian National University, because the information was not available in this report.

Section 23 grants for 1990 amounting to $147m provide assistance to institutions for special research centres. There is considerable disquiet in the higher education community about the amount of government intrusion into the funding of research in Australia. The Australian National University put out a fact sheet in May which stated:
Australia needs a pluralistic system for setting research priorities, not a highly centralised system in which the judgments of a few committees dominate decisions.
The Stephen Committee, commissioned by the Government, endorsed the Australian National University view. It said:
There is value in there being a plurality of sources of research funding so that different perspectives can be brought to bear on the merits of different areas of inquiry.

However, the Government, through Minister Baldwin, announced in March this year that it proposed to destroy the independence of the Institute of Advanced Studies at the ANU by reallocating all the funds for the School of Medical Research to the National Health and Medical Research Council and by giving the Australian Research Council an intrusive role in the funding of its other schools. In a recent graduation address, Professor Peter Karmel said:

It is important to emphasise that the case for institutional autonomy stems . . . from the knowledge that universities will better achieve their purposes in serving a free society by self-government than by detailed intervention on the part of public authorities.

The time has come for those of us who believe in the importance of higher education for this country and the people who live in it, to proclaim loudly and clearly that the integrity and autonomy of our universities must not be eroded.

I endorse these comments from Professor Karmel. Government interference with and intervention into higher education has had catastrophic results. We now have a bureaucratically administered system dominated by ministerial discretion. At a time when the Government is promoting the clever country, the Government does everything it can to bully, to blackmail, to bludgeon institutions into forced amalgamations or new arrangements, such as the centralised method of allocating research money. This threatens the autonomy and independence of our very valuable higher education system.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
