SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990 not only on my own behalf but also, I think, to put on the record the Government's position that it will not support this legislation and to put some argument on the record as to why that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I would like Senator Coulter to know, in presenting this Bill, that it is not his intention or his sentiments that I am opposing. He is not alone in this chamber in being very concerned about the rate of destruction of tropical rainforests around the world. Indeed, as he pointed out in his speech, the rate of that destruction is increasing at a fearful pace-an exponential rate, perhaps Senator Coulter would say. That is due to a number of things. One reason is an interesting new desire on the part of people to possess rainforest timber. Another reason is that we now have a huge advantage in terms of getting that timber. Whereas previously people might have had to slog into a rainforest and chop such timber by axe, now we have huge mechanical devices to fell timber and to clear and haul it away. Therefore the mechanical capacity now to destroy or harvest such forests is contributing to the rate of destruction.

In rising to oppose the Bill I am not disagreeing with the sentiments expressed by Senator Coulter and his comments about the importance of protecting our rainforests, because they are becoming more and more depleted and a rarer and rarer commodity. However, the point that I wish to make on behalf of the Government by way of justification for our opposing the Bill is that Senator Coulter's Bill fails to deal with the very complex nature of the issue he is confronting.

His legislation proposes some prescriptive measures whose implementation and likely effectiveness have not been thought through and, indeed, are not likely to achieve even the intention that his Bill sets out to address. For example, the administrative framework of how the Australian Customs Service would prohibit or restrict the importation of certain tropical rainforest timbers into this country is not made clear in his Bill. How would, for example, anybody in Customs be able to tell whether timber had been felled in a tropical rainforest or in a regrowth forest? As I understand it, this legislation does not object to the importation of tropical rainforest timbers from regrowth forests. This is a complication and an administrative difficulty that seem to be insufficiently addressed in Senator Coulter's legislation.

On the other hand, the Government-as I said, it is not just myself but the Government-is very concerned about this matter and while it is in sympathy with Senator Coulter's Bill it has taken a different approach. The Government is aware that one cannot try to tackle such a complex issue in a limited or simple way. The Government's approach is to address this complex matter in a much more comprehensive way. What the Government has been giving consideration to are the very large differences and the need to balance the conservation needs of forests and, at the same time, the demand for forestry timber. The changes and improvements in logging practices-indeed, the question of value adding of timber resources-and the pricing of tropical timber to take into account the environmental cost have been taken into account.

I take the point raised by Senator Coulter about the speed with which tropical rainforests are disappearing from the face of this world. One would have to say that that speed of disappearance is no doubt increasing very considerably the value of what is left. I do not think that either Senator Coulter or I would take any comfort from that increased value of the remaining resource but at the same time I think we have a very inadequate way of trying to work out the value of that resource. Whether it is increasing in value or not, we still have to address the serious issue of trying to come to some way of adequately determining the value of that kind of resource. We need also to look at how we price that resource if it is allowed to be chopped down and sold.

The other thing we have to address when considering the rainforests of other countries is our relationship with those countries. Of recent times we have certainly seen the importance of good relations with neighbouring countries in our own region. It has not been without note that our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has been visiting Malaysia and making sure that relations with that country continue favourably for both them and us. Tropical rainforest legislation requires those sorts of considerations to be addressed and properly dealt with before it is brought into this place. If the legislation were brought in and those issues were not dealt with I presume that we could expect a minimal satisfactory outcome from that kind of haste.

We need also to look at the capacity of government to assist financially with forest and environment projects, particularly in regard to rainforests overseas. This is particularly important as we have come to know over the past few years-I think perhaps that is one of the benefits of television-that the rights of indigenous forest dwellers need to be taken into account. Perhaps there is the need for producer countries to address the question of how they set aside permanent forest estates. However, for some of the countries to decide to do that would require them almost completely to reappraise their economies. It is a very difficult thing for Australia to consider legislation that may require those kinds of considerations to be addressed. We have no power to address them, but it is important that they are addressed. I think that for all these reasons the Government has been concerned to hasten slowly, to be more comprehensive in addressing all of those problems, so that when it does introduce such legislation and takes steps to address this very important issue all of those concerns will be covered.

As part of this process the Government asked Coopers and Lybrand, in consultation with Forestry Technical Services Pty Ltd, or Fortech, to undertake a report. That was commissioned in September 1989. It was asked to look at, amongst other things, the extent of Australia's international trade in tropical timbers, the impact of this trade on both Australian consumers and tropical timber source countries, and options for increasing tropical forest management and protection. The consultancy report was completed in April 1990. Indeed, Senator Coulter, in his speech, examined that report very closely and addressed a number of the issues that were raised in it. I think it is fair to say that he was somewhat scathing in his dismissal of the outcome of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could say that.

—Scathing. Indeed, it is also true that he was not persuaded that the report would help the Government address this issue seriously. Notwithstanding Senator Coulter's speech, the Government has accepted that report and, as a result, has established an interdepartmental committee comprising a number of departments, including the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Department of Administrative Services, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. They have compiled comprehensive advice on the full range of those issues involved in tropical forest conservation. That interdepartmental committee has reported to the relevant Ministers. As a result of that report, the Government therefore has the information necessary to act on the recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding that, and in case it sounds as though the Government is not intent on doing anything to this point, I remind the Senate that in the recent Budget the new environmental assistance program was announced. It significantly expands the assistance for environmental projects and programs in international development and allows for cooperation between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Ros Kelly, and the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett.

The focus of the new environment assistance program in the forest sector is an allocation of $4.3m in 1991-92 to enable the continuation of bilateral programs in Papua New Guinea and the ASEAN region as well as enabling new bilateral and multilateral activities to be commenced in those areas and in the South Pacific. It is clear that, by addressing our region, the Government is trying to focus its efforts and to maximise their effect rather than spreading our contribution and interest widely across every rainforest country in this world. I am sure that that will cause some angst in some places, but it is the Government's intention to try to regionalise and focus its efforts, particularly under this new environmental assistance program.

The Government will also continue supporting its program with a grant of $1.4m to the Papua New Guinea national forest action plan, which will assist projects to achieve sustainable use of Papua New Guinea's forests. Amongst other things, it will include funding for a training program to try to improve tropical forest management in South East Asia, along with the Papua New Guinea forest action plan. That extra training program will receive $700,000. We cannot overlook the importance of this.

I had the pleasure of a very brief visit to Ethiopia. It is one of the few countries that are on the public record as saying it has been so dramatically deforested that it now acknowledges its changing climate and weather patterns as the cause of the extensive and fairly rapid deforestation of large tracts of its country. The point of Senator Coulter's Bill and the Government's behaviour is to try to prevent the massive denuding and deforestation of countries and the dramatic consequences of land degradation and the dislocation of populations, which have huge economic implications.

I would hate my words to be understood to mean that I put more value on the economic aspect of the issue than the economic dislocation of peoples; I do not. Indeed, one probably cannot be separated from the other. I suppose that the hardest pain that has to be borne from this kind of rape of primary preserves is the damage it does to people. The short dollar return of tearing out tropical rainforests in anyone's eyes has a long term effect. One does not have to look too far into the future to see the damage it does to people, in terms not only of economic loss but also of displacement.

The protection of tropical rainforests around the world is something that the Government is committed to. To this point it is trying to maintain that commitment through the new Budget initiatives such as the environment assistance program that I have just outlined and new activities which invest further moneys into the sustainable use and management of tropical forests in South East Asia and the South Pacific countries. It will also continue its contributions through international organisations supporting sustainable tropical forest projects such as the International Tropical Timber Organisation, the Consultative Group of International Agricultural Research and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. The contribution there amounts to some $900,000 for 1991-92.

Even just listing the number of international or Australian research organisations and/or the projects that are happening in the countries in the so-called South Pacific region highlights the complexity of this issue and the need to address the problem comprehensively. In outlining these bits of Government initiative, I pick up on some of the points that Senator Coulter suggested in his speech would be necessary. I take his point that we would not want to include all of them under the one piece of legislation, though I say by way of some criticism that, if we want all those things to happen and we address them only in a second reading speech, that is probably not a sufficient way of addressing it. That is one reason why the Government has reservations about Senator Coulter's Bill.

Rainforest conservation is a very important area, and the Government takes it very seriously. It is addressing that in a comprehensive way. For those reasons, the Government will not be supporting Senator Coulter's Bill, despite the sympathy we have with its intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise in dismay, with some disillusionment and with great disappointment that neither the Opposition nor the Government can see fit to support a very important piece of legislation which addresses a very significant issue. I listened a few moments ago to Senator Bjelke-Petersen speaking of land degradation in this country. She rightly pointed to the fact that it had a low priority but was a very important issue. As Senator Crowley has just said, and as I pointed out in my second reading speech, there are a number of ways of tackling aspects of this problem of the destruction of tropical rainforests and the loss of the cultures of some 1,000 indigenous people who still live in those tropical rainforests around the world. As I pointed out in my second reading speech, it is quite inappropriate to attempt to tackle all those issues within one piece of legislation, but this is one significant thing that Australia can do.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress again that when one is dealing with complex issues, which of course have economic consequences and consequences in terms of relationships with other governments, one clearly must set some sort of priority. What really annoys me is that this chamber is incapable of recognising the very important priority which must be accorded the enormous loss of the tropical rainforests of this globe and the species and indigenous cultures which they contain. That issue must override, in any sane, sensible, informed, intelligent set of priorities around this area, all these other considerations. I find it very depressing that the Opposition and the Government in this chamber cannot recognise the overriding priority that must be given to that.

Indeed, we heard from the Opposition particularly, and less from Senator Crowley, I must say, that the sensitivities of the Malaysian Government-and we heard this from Senator Evans perhaps more clearly the other day-are something to be given high priority. In July this year, a Mr Peter Bazos of Elite Wood Product was convicted in the Sydney District Court on charges relating to the evasion of $294,000 worth of duty on imported tropical rainforest timber. In the course of giving evidence, Mr Bazos pointed out that at every single stage in the exploitation of that tropical rainforest timber-the cutting of it in the forest, the transportation of it in Malaysia, the cutting of that timber into flitches, its passage through the customs system and its export-bribery and corruption in Malaysia are involved. So what we are hearing from Senator Evans is that, for some peculiar and distorted reason dealing with the niceties of our relationship with the Malaysian Government, we should support an activity which of necessity, according to evidence given in court, involves Australians breaking the law in Malaysia. That is something that the Government needs to think about very carefully.

As I pointed out in my speech at the second reading stage, we are indeed dealing with a very important subject. The Bill is a response to the alarming rate of destruction of the world's tropical rainforests. It is, as Senator Crowley has pointed out, but one element in a comprehensive strategy by which Australia could, and should, make a positive contribution to arresting this destruction.

I will read a few figures into the record. According to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, some 142,200 square kilometres of rainforest were destroyed in 1989-a 90 per cent increase in the deforestation rate in only 10 years. The World Resources Institute puts the annual loss at nearly 200,000 square kilometres, resulting in the average loss, conservatively estimated, of 100 species per day.

Compared with all of these other issues, this is the issue: how many holes can we tear in the fabric of life-in the global biosphere? How many holes can we tear in it deliberately, wantonly, and without taking any action to prevent it, and still protect a living environment for our children and our grandchildren? The answer is that, frankly, we do not know and yet we arrogantly go on turning our backs on this very important issue. The European Commission estimated that:
At present rates of forest loss, all but a few of the remotest forest regions, mostly in the Amazon and Congo basins, could have disappeared by the early 21st century.

Today I asked a question of Senator Richardson regarding the fact that in 1986 the Australian Labor Party moved a motion with respect to this matter. It is now 1991 and we heard from Senator Evans the other day that, yes, the Party is considering it; it is giving it some priority. How long does that Party need before it takes some action against a process which will be complete in some 10 to 20 years? At that time further action will be quite unnecessary because there will not be any rainforest left.

Of course the Australian Democrats support comprehensive action. We support these other things that need to be done, many of which have been set out in my earlier speech, such as international debt relief for the poorest countries, and large increases in overseas aid. We have directed our attention to these issues, not by way of legislation because, as Senator Crowley would know, we cannot legislate in these areas; but we have directed attention to them in our alternative budgets, both last year and this year. There is a great deal of detail in those budgets. In our alternative budget we have directed a great deal more money to those areas than is allocated in the Government's Budget.

I do not want to take up the time of the Senate because it is quite clear the way the vote on this will go. But I cannot reiterate too strongly that, compared with many-in fact most if not all-of the issues that are dealt with in this chamber, the loss of the world's rich diversity of animal and plant species and the increasing rate of that loss, the massive destruction of indigenous cultures, and the loss of the knowledge of how to handle the environment in many different areas of the world which are contained within those cultures are losses which we should grapple with as a matter of great urgency. It is for those reasons that I strongly commend this Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:
(i) 5 June is World Environment Day,

(ii) the current human-induced rate of species and habitat loss is greater than at any other time in the history of the earth, and that this cannot continue for very much longer without dramatic consequences for global ecological systems and human welfare, and
(iii) over the past 200 years, Australia's record with respect to habitat destruction and mammal extinction has been one of the poorest in the world, and that this is continuing at an alarming rate;

(b) recognises that the future of the world environment for centuries to come will be determined by people here on earth today, and particularly commends the efforts of one Australian, Dr John Wamsley, for his visionary efforts in the protection of Australia's endangered species; and

(c) further commends Dr Wamsley for his outstanding effort in establishing Warrawong Sanctuary in the Adelaide Hills and also for the establishment of Yookamurra Sanctuary in the Mallee region of South Australia.

This notice of motion was lodged in this place as one of a number of notices of motion for World Environment Day. It draws the Senate's attention to two particular issues: firstly, to the perilous state of many Australian native species, particularly mammals; and, secondly, to the outstanding work of Dr John Wamsley.

John Wamsley runs a wildlife sanctuary called Warrawong Sanctuary just outside Adelaide. As it turns out, he runs it so successfully that not only has he won a number of major tourism awards but also he has managed to make a considerable profit from it. He has put this profit into either Warrawong Sanctuary or Yookamurra Sanctuary, and will continue to reinvest in further endangered species projects.

John Wamsley's sanctuary is very different from other wildlife parks. Indeed, it is different from anything I have seen in either Australia or overseas. It is particularly different to those that are usually touted as tourist destinations. I stress three reasons as to why it is very different. Firstly, I refer to the layout. The animals are not penned up in small cages for people to file past on nicely cemented paths. The animals roam freely in revegetated areas around the sanctuary, in a reasonably natural state, left to their own devices. Visitors actually have to walk around the sanctuary to see the animals on their own terms, usually at night with a torch.

Secondly, the endangered species breed there freely; there is no controlled program. Indeed, Dr Wamsley actually displays many endangered species which are totally unknown to the vast majority of Australians. He does this rather than show off the more popular species such as the koala; in fact, that is the type of display on which many other parks concentrate.

Thirdly, and perhaps the most important reason that Dr Wamsley is very different, he does not in any way exploit the animals for profit to indulge himself. Instead, he uses the profits he generates to benefit Warrawong and now in order to establish the 1,100 hectare feral animal free Yookamurra Sanctuary. That is why he is so different from most other Australians. That is why he deserved special recognition on World Environment Day-and I hope he will get it today. This motion is about one man who is doing more than his fair share to protect Australia's heritage. I argue that the least this Parliament can do is to give formal recognition to his work.

There are three main reasons why Australians should protect their biodiversity and the species that make it up. Firstly, we have a moral obligation to share this planet with other creatures and to ensure that they survive for the benefit and future enjoyment of our children, our grandchildren and future generations. Secondly, it is environmentally sensible not to destroy the very processes on which mankind is dependent for its survival. Thirdly, we are the custodians of a natural heritage that is found nowhere else in the world.

The Government chose to oppose this motion when it was originally introduced, apparently because it believes that its research programs are the only way to save Australia's rare and endangered species and that people such as Dr Wamsley have no place in these programs.

I refer to the magnitude of the actual problem. In just over 200 years, we have destroyed forever 20 mammals which occurred nowhere else on earth. That represents a loss, on average, of one mammal every 10 years. What is worse is that in 1991 we now have another 30 mammals, 15 birds and over 200 plants which are in grave danger of becoming extinct. Many people believe that these mammal extinctions mainly occurred in the 1800s; that by the early 1900s it had basically all occurred. That is not correct. Unfortunately, species extinction has been occurring since then and is more likely than ever to continue to occur because of inaction by the current Government.

The Government has a reputable research program and, indeed, has allocated more funds to it in its current Budget. But there is little or no practical action. The mammals of Australian deserts were once more numerous and diverse than previously believed. In the last few decades they have suffered huge and sudden losses. In the words of Dr Andrew Burbridge:
So severe has this decimation been, that it has no parallel in any other relatively undisturbed region on earth.

In South Australia-the home State of both myself and Dr Wamsley-we have the worst record of any State, in a country which has the worst record of any country, for the extinction of mammals. Of an original 105 species of mammals, two monotremes, 65 marsupials, 17 rodents, one eutherian carnivore and 20 bats, 28 species are now extinct in South Australia. That is more than a quarter. Lost forever are 25 marsupials, two rodents and one bat species: they are now gone altogether from everywhere, totally wiped off the face of the earth. Another 39 are endangered, rare or vulnerable.

More than 60 per cent of our native mammals in South Australia are either extinct or under threat of extinction. We only need to lose one mammal in the next 10 years for us to retain the extinction rate that has, in the past, given us the worst mammal extinction rate of any society in the history of humans on this earth.

It is an outrage that a nation whose high standard of living is dependent almost entirely on the natural environmental assets of this continent can have such little regard for its continued health and show such indifference to the plight of many unique native species which share this continent with us.

Let me look specifically at John Wamsley's program. Wamsley's plan is based on the very simple observation that feral animals, particularly the cat and fox, are primary causes of the extinction of our native animals, especially mammals. It is implemented by a very simple solution-a fence. In 1991 the only guaranteed solution is to keep these animals apart-that is, the fox and the cat on one side and the native mammals and animals on the other.

To keep these feral animals out of native habitats, Dr Wamsley has constructed an ingenious fence. He proposes now to erect one at Yookamurra sanctuary-indeed, that one is now complete-and, hopefully, to move on to other sanctuaries. He is not able to fence all the land across this continent that is in urgent need of fencing. However, I do understand that he has now been called upon as a consultant to a project in Western Australia. The need for fencing is a lesson that has been hard learned in Australian biological circles. There have been a number of disastrous attempts at reintroducing native mammals into their former habitats; two in particular are the parma wallaby effort in New South Wales and the bilby story in the Northern Territory.

This afternoon I shall look at the parma wallaby reintroduction program. Seventeen years ago the parma wallaby was thought to be extinct in Australia. However, an isolated population-an introduced population-was found on an island off New Zealand and was brought back to Australia. An article in the Australian in July 1989 stated:
It had taken 17 years of careful planning, selective breeding and intensive scientific study, but finally the dream was realised: last year-
that is, 1988-
47 rare Parma wallabies were let out in an inaccessible gully in the Illawarra catchment area in NSW.

The aim was to reintroduce the tiny marsupials into the wild. Within eight weeks every one of them was dead-snapped in half by foxes. Those studying the Parma wallaby knew the foxes would be a problem. For six months they had laid poison baits and the fox problem in the area had been dramatically reduced. But for the foxes that were left, the Parma were such a delicacy that they completely ignored the baits until every wallaby had been stalked and killed.
In other words, we now have no other way in 1991 but to fence until other programs such as biological control are effective.

Warrawong-I shall just look at that area very briefly-was started in 1989 to demonstrate that the biggest problems our wildlife species face in Australia are the fox and the cat. Not only was this hypothesis proven, but it was also shown that fox and cat proof enclosures could be built and maintained relatively cheaply.

Following the success of Warrawong, in the mid-1980s Dr Wamsley purchased what is now Yookamurra sanctuary-1,100 hectares of land, 100 kilometres east of Adelaide. The property was virgin scrub land, except for minor areas which were either cut by woodcutters in the pre-war days or logged in the post-war period. Both of these smaller areas are now regrown mallee.

Mallee habitat once occupied one-fifth of the Australian continent. Most importantly, this particular piece of mallee has never been grazed. Therefore, it provides a unique and special opportunity to be restored to its former glory. No introduced hoofed animals such as sheep, cattle or goats have ever grazed that land and destroyed the very fragile thin layer of lichens that cover the ancient soil protecting it from erosion. Unlike the evolution of animals on other continents, native animals in Australia have evolved with soft, padded feet which do not destroy our delicate topsoils.

In late 1990 Yookamurra was fenced for its entire 14-kilometre perimeter with a fox, cat, rabbit, dog, goat and pig proof fence. This fence cost Dr Wamsley approximately half a million dollars. It is 1.8 metres high, incorporates a skirt to stop animals digging under it and it is electrified with five wires which are all powered using solar electricity. The property became a sanctuary when the last gate was closed in October 1990. This was done by Sir Mark Oliphant, the former Governor-General of South Australia. There was a ceremony held at that stage attended by a number of people, including politicians such as Dr John Coulter of the Australian Democrats and Peter Lewis, the Liberal member for the MurrayMallee. In closing the fence, Sir Mark stated:
South Australia, all Australia, the whole world, will be richer because of the existence of this great fauna reserve.

Through the late 1990s and early into 1991, an extensive program of feral animal eradication took place and was completed when the last rabbit was destroyed. All this was done from profits generated from Warrawong sanctuary and with support, but without one cent of monetary assistance, from State and Federal governments.

Yookamurra sanctuary has been completely funded from the earnings of Warrawong and from private investment. It owes no money to anyone. The main aim of Yookamurra is to reintroduce the animals which once lived there and to allow them to live in balance with as little human interference as possible. Eventually, like its predecessor in the Mount Lofty Ranges, it will be open to the public for education and research. It will show Australians what our country used to be like before its present near destruction, particularly by the feral animal invasion.

The reintroduction of native animals is being supported with the cooperation of the National Parks and Wildlife Service in South Australia. It has an approved management plan. All animals inside the sanctuary will remain the property of the Crown-and I must stress that. The management plan for Yookamurra sanctuary lists 26 mammals which used to live in the Murray-Mallee. Some are still common in South Australia: the hairy-nosed wombat, the echidna, the western grey kangaroo and the red kangaroo. Some are now rare in South Australia: the western pygmy-possum, the brush-tailed phascogale, the common dunnart, the southern brown bandicoot, Mitchell's hopping mouse and the plains rat.

Some are endangered in South Australia, including the feathertail glider and the greater stick-nest rat. The last group is extinct in South Australia but, fortunately, has survived elsewhere. It comprises the western quoll, the spotted-tail quoll, the eastern quoll, the red-tailed phascogale, the fat-tailed dunnart, the burrowing bettong, the brush-tailed bettong, the bridled nailtail wallaby, the numbat, the western barred bandicoot, the eastern barred bandicoot, the common ringtail possum, the common brushtail possum and the bilby.

Of these 26 original inhabitants, Dr Wamsley hopes to introduce at least 23 and would introduce others except that six are now extinct, not just in South Australia but extinct-gone forever more. They are the crescent nailtail wallaby, the pig-footed bandicoot, the white-footed rabbit-rat, the lesser stick-nest rat, the eastern hare-wallaby and the toolache wallaby. In addition to these mammals, it is also proposed to introduce bird species such as the southern stone curlew, the mallee fowl and the bustard, which no longer exist in the area because they are particularly susceptible to predation by foxes and cats. How many honourable senators could actually describe any of these animals? How many have ever heard of them?

Very soon honourable senators will have the opportunity to visit Yookamurra sanctuary. Thanks to several State governments which are cooperating with John Wamsley, the species acquisition program is now under way. In May 1991 the first animals were introduced. They were the very small native rodents known as pseudomys australis. They were released in the presence of the Australian Director of the World Wide Fund for Nature, Mr Don Henry. In July 1991 the second introduction occurred with the release of the brushtailed bettong from a population bred by the South Australian Museum. Numbers in the wild have decreased to about 200. This is the first time since early this century that these small marsupials have inhabited that land. They once ranged widely across the continent. I must add that they and many of the other browsing animals kept the risk of wildfire low because they grazed on the undergrowth.

Dr Wamsley anticipates releasing mallee fowl, stone curlews, bustards, stick-nest rats and Mitchell's hopping mice within two months and plans to release red-tailed phascogales, burrowing bettongs, numbats, western barred bandicoots, western quoll, banded hare-wallabies, bilbies and bridled nailtail wallabies next year-that is, in 1992. Dr Wamsley's company, Earth Sanctuaries, spent over $1m on conservation projects in South Australia last year. This extraordinary series of projects has been implemented by an extraordinarily determined individual. Few people would have dared to take on such an unusual project on this vast scale. It is this vision and determination that have led to my motion.

Some honourable senators may not see any great merit in Dr Wamsley's acts, but I believe that history will remember this man fondly. I ask Government senators in particular how they can possibly object to a motion that congratulates the efforts of a committed individual. This motion does not in any way make specific criticisms of the Government. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, recently visited Warrawong. I am not sure if the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, has-I know that a number of other senators, including Senator Olsen and Senator Coulter, have, as I have-visited Warrawong. Indeed, I understand that Senator Coulter has also visited Yookamurra.

I do not see the passing of this motion today as the end of the story by any means. We now need to use the knowledge gained from what John Wamsley has done in other parts of Australia. He cannot do it all on his own. The valuable research that has already been done through the Government's endangered species project should now be put into positive action, should be translated into concrete efforts, because we cannot simply keep on researching. We will research the animals to death. We need now to take some positive steps: to select carefully, using all the research and information we have, at least two national parks or fauna reserves in every State and to begin immediately a fencing program.

The endangered species program of the Government has been increased, but I stress again that, as John Wamsley says, we have done enough research. We know that the primary problem is foxes and cats. I understand that in Tasmania feral dogs are a problem as well. I quote John Wamsley:

Governments find it easy to ``solve'' the problem by allocating research money. Research workers are happy to guarantee to solve the problem. This symbiotic relationship produces some remarkable results. In South Australia, $350,000 has been spent developing management plans for the Yellow-footed Rock-wallabies over the last twenty years. Not one cent has ever been spent on implementing one recommendation from any of these plans.

I urge the Government to support this motion today, to congratulate John Wamsley and to recognise his efforts and successes. I also urge the Government to now fund fencing programs for at least two national parks or fauna reserves in each State. John Wamsley is committed to saving species and he has shown others how to do it. I ask the Senate to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise-much as I did the last time I was on my feet, which was about half an hour ago-to say that we agree with the sentiments of the motion but that we are not going to support it. I will come to the detail of why we take that position in a moment. It is not to object to any of the words in the motion, going as it does to noting World Environment Day, its importance and the contribution of Dr John Wamsley. For the record, I am another South Australian senator who has visited Warrawong. I think Senator Lees knew that but thought that I would be unkind about Dr Wamsley, so she did not mention it. Senator Less is quite right: I am about to be a little unkind about Dr Wamsley.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been to Warrawong. It is an absolutely ace place. I did not go at night with a torch. I went up there at 6 o'clock in the morning. One can watch bettongs head butting. They both arrived in the one place at the one time and knocked each other unconscious. They are very sweet, delightful little animals. They scurry and scuttle around in the black water pond that Dr Wamsley has established. In the same pond the platypuses swim around doing wheelies, back flips and other such creative things.

One also notes that Dr Wamsley encourages the animals to come out for us to see them by taking bits of wheat around in his hand. I am not quite sure where that fits in the natural scheme of things, but I was very happy to see the animals and I was very pleased to be up there. But, as I said to Senator Lees, we have to be fairly creative and brave to go to Warrawong because we have to listen to Dr Wamsley telling us about our faults and those of everybody else in the world, saying that we do not love furry creatures enough. We need to be strong to go to Warrawong and cop the abuse that Dr Wamsley gives us about issues in general. That is because Dr Wamsley believes in such issues passionately.

I would hate my remarks to be taken negatively against what he has done. His work is fantastic. It is an absolute delight to go to Warrawong. It is also fantastic to discover that on a quarter-acre block enough wood can be grown, if planted properly, to keep oneself in timber for the rest of one's life. We should just get those trees growing; plant them year by year; chop them down in a controlled way; and burn them in a slow combustion stove. Much can be learnt from Dr Wamsley and Warrawong. As I say, it is a delightful place to which to go.

Dr Wamsley has a particular style of tackling the world that may discommode people. The vehemence and commitment of his words may set them right back in their chairs or push them into the next paddock. That is a pity because the message needs to be told very strongly. Maybe we have to be outrageous, fierce and very single minded, but the time has come for Dr Wamsley to know that his message is well enough understood, that his support in the community is large enough, for that vehemence and single mindedness not to be so much of a necessary characteristic. I do not mean that he should wander away from his message, but I do not believe that he needs to maintain his manner in order to persuade us.

I also understand that Dr Wamsley has been invited to assist with a project with the Pitjantjatjara people in far north South Australia. It is very much a dry lands area-much drier than Yookamurra. I am not sure whether that project is still in the planning stage or whether it will be implemented very soon.

The words that Senator Lees used to describe the difference between cloven-hoofed animals and the padded feet of animals of this country and the importance of those different designs of feet on our native vegetation reminded me of a chapter in a book I certainly commend to anybody in this place and to all Australians. The book is by Jill Ker Conway and is called The Road from Cooraine. It is an utterly delightful read. The first chapter in that book contains probably the most evocative description-it is a sympathetic and beautiful description-of the far western New South Wales country that I have ever read. In large part, it is very evocative of Australia in general, though it is focused on the country she knows best from growing up in far western New South Wales.

It is also a particularly tragic book, although not apropos of this motion. Jill Ker Conway eventually rose to take out the university medal in the University of Sydney. She applied to join the foreign service but in those days-not too long ago-they did not take women; they took men. So she left the shores of Australia and now lives in America. What a great lady; a wonderful writer of Australia. I commend the book to all honourable senators.

The Government is not supporting this motion because it suggests-Senator Lees touched on this-that the only person who is seriously addressing the problem of endangered species is Dr Wamsley. That is a very insufficient appreciation of the truth. Indeed, the Government has a very good record of commitment to assistance with endangered species. I think the motion is lacking in that it highlights the efforts of one and overlooks the efforts of, firstly, the Government and, secondly, many other people who have been so committed to contributing to the maintenance of our endangered species.

The Prime Minister launched the Commonwealth's endangered species program, curiously known as ESP, in 1989. That 10-year program was given $2m in funding for each of the 1989-90 and 1990-91 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many species has it saved?

—It is also interesting to note that the funding has been increased from $2m per annum to $5m for 1991-92. Senator Coulter asks how many species the program has saved. Let me come to some of the things it has done, and he may find that what we should have is cooperation between the public and private sector in this area and not a war.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Government's contribution-particularly in the area of research, which Dr Wamsley is so disparaging of-earns its merit badges. This country probably has not had adequate research done on plants, vegetation and animals since the white man came here and started to disrupt everything. I do not suppose we have ever thought to ask about the research or knowledge of the black people who lived here for so long-or we are just beginning to do that now. We cannot overlook the contribution of the public sector dollar investment in this area. I seek leave to incorporate a list of the projects funded by the endangered species program 1990-91.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The endangered species program does have an impressive record. It is funding programs which contribute to the conservation of a number of plants and animals in this country. Senator Lees suggested that our country has witnessed the extinction of more mammals than many other countries. I suggest caution in accepting that assessment. We are perhaps one of the few countries that at least knows the names of the lost species. I do not know how many mammals were wandering around in southern Europe circa 500BC, but I suggest that Australia is not the only country that has seen the extinction of mammals. What we do have, is a piece of history and an effort is being made to try to document that so that we know what has happened and what has been lost, and can try to prevent any further extinction of species if we possibly can.

SPEECH.PARA: I will list some of the things which show the breadth of conservation subjects covered by the endangered species program. It addresses such things as environmental weeds and feral animals; major research into fox control by CALM and CSIRO; action plans to identify conservation status and management priorities for birds, bats, rodents, fish, reptiles, amphibians and invertebrates; a national education program to improve public support for recovery of endangered species and communities; and the preparation of recovery plans for more than 50 species.

Another thing about the endangered species program which needs to be noted is its concern to involve the community at the grass roots level in education about national threatened species. It tries to ensure that, when a government or individuals raise the importance of endangered species and the threat of extinction, the community is aware, informed and sympathetic.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned earlier in here today the Landcare program and the importance of looking after soil in this country. We have seen some of the initiatives of Minister Peter Cook and our State colleagues over the last few years. I have to admit that we have taken a long time to realise the importance of caring for our land-our soil-as well as our plants and animals.

It is fair to say that the Government is more than aware of, and is on the record as being fully involved in, saving endangered species. That work is dispersed around the country. I cannot insist that Dr Wamsley is the only person doing these things and that nobody else is. Within the zoos of Australia and within a number of the research institutions-the forest, soil conservation and plant conservation places-the species are not becoming extinct as they might have been if this work was not being done.

I utterly agree with Senator Lees about the significance of Dr Wamsley's work. One of the things that particularly struck me is the fence that he has constructed. I would be interested to see whether it does hold up against rabbits. I understand that he claims it does. I can see that it has worked very well in keeping out feral cats and foxes. The design of Dr Wamsley's fence is interesting. I think he is particularly interested in it and excited to draw it to people's attention when they visit the sanctuary. It is not an outrageously expensive construction. If it does work against rabbits, I think it will be as great a contribution in this area as the saving of a species.

Another thing that is particularly attractive is that Dr Wamsley has not only saved species-or at least released them into an environment that is acceptable to them-but also he has recreated, as much as he can, some of the original hill space in South Australia. That has its own attraction too; it is a very nice place to visit. When he first started to do that, and was cutting down trees that were non-native and not indigenous to that area, he had some very significant run-ins with the local community and, I believe, the Premier of the day, Don Dunstan. Through it all, Dr Wamsley has kept on with his project. I strongly endorse the sentiments of the motion that congratulate Dr Wamsley but the importance of the Government's contribution towards the protection of endangered species should not be overlooked.

For the reasons I have outlined, we will not be supporting this motion because it fails to acknowledge people other than Dr Wamsley working in this country, and their great contribution to addressing this difficult and frightening challenge that has been so well outlined by Senator Lees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is disposed to support Senator Lees's motion, not necessarily because we agree with the self flagellation in points (ii) and (iii) of note (a), but because we find that notes (b) and (c) merit support. We certainly feel that Dr Wamsley should be commended for his activities. It may well be that the opposition that we have heard from the Government today rests heavily on the fact that Dr Wamsley has managed to do all of his hard work without the support of the Government. That perhaps dramatises to the Government that there are various matters in which its incompetence can be a dead hand. The absence of that dead hand does, in fact, at times provide opportunities to people who are dedicated to performing very well indeed in an area where there is a tendency for Government support and help to be demanded on all occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether or not it is the view of the Government that Dr Wamsley is overcommitted, that his message is a bit raucous, overvehement and so on, to our mind-even if it is true-is of no consequence. The issue is whether or not Dr Wamsley has done a good job and whether his activities are for the net benefit of Australians. Nothing that we have heard from the Government today detracts from that.

As a result, I am surprised to learn that the Government is not of a mind to support this motion, I understand on the grounds that perhaps Dr Wamsley is not a person the Government feels it wants to support in public. To my mind there was no other explanation, although in passing a point was made, which I must say I tend to agree with, about the earlier part of the motion. But as the thrust of the motion appears to relate to Dr Wamsley, I do not want to quibble about the earlier bits that, quite frankly, for those who like flagellation seem to be a bit of self-indulgence.
I should make a couple of points about the first bit of the motion. The assertions made are subjective. It is asserted that:

(ii) the current human-induced rate of species and habitat loss is greater than at any other time in the history of the earth, and that this cannot continue for very much longer without dramatic consequences for global ecological systems and human welfare.

One of the real problems that that kind of assertion generates is a question about what has really changed. Has it been our capacity to measure change or has it been the change itself? It seems to me that in many instances our capacity to measure the change has improved immensely and, as a result, we are more concerned about the evident change. I find it very hard to accept that view, just as I find it very hard to accept the view in the third paragraph that Australia's record is one of the poorest in the world and is continuing at an alarming rate.

I have been under the impression that there was a much greater awareness and concern for these issues now that the methods of measurement have been dramatising to us what is happening. In passing, I would just say that the status quo is a concept that is basically unheard of in ecological development. There is no such thing as the status quo, and to revere it because it is the status quo seems to me to miss the whole point of evolution. That is by no means a justification for wiping out species.

All I am saying is that through the history of the world there has been change: some of it induced by rival species such as man, some induced by glaciers-some would say acts of God. I am quite happy that I do not face the prospect of meeting an unfriendly pterodactyl on the way home. I cannot pretend the absence of that pterodactyl has somehow destroyed my capacity to enjoy life or has done infinite damage to the world itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing is that you will never know.
—I will never know and I will die happy that I do not know. It does not bother me, whether it is a brontosaurus or any other saurus. The only one I am happy to meet on the way home is a thesaurus.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no great feeling of commitment to the status quo in ecology. I do not think anyone alive should be overwhelmed by the necessity to maintain the status quo. However, the extinction of a species is a matter of concern. I express some uneasiness about the way we tend to define some species as `good' species-not everyone, but there are some people who make value judgments between species, which I find rather quaint, when protecting one species from extermination by another species.

With the reservation that the Opposition is not terribly attracted to the early parts of this motion, we are supporting the motion because of the bottom part of it. We do not want to amend it because, frankly, it would become too complicated. As long as it is on the record that we are supporting the bottom part of the motion, that will do. I conclude simply by saying that I am intrigued by the Government's lack of support for the motion, but in view of the sort of bureaucratic advice the Government was given against a man who is not only a non-bureaucrat but also an anti-bureaucrat, I am not at all surprised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to make a couple of points. I am pleased the Opposition is supporting the motion moved by Senator Lees. I assume that it was the private nature of Dr Wamsley's conservation work which appealed so much to the Opposition. As Senator Lees pointed out, it is true that John Wamsley took over an old and run-down dairy farm and for a time tried to grow beef cattle. I happened to have a small farm not far from Dr Wamsley's. At the time when beef prices fell, he turned his mind to other things and developed the Warrawong Sanctuary.

SPEECH.PARA: Without a shadow of a doubt, Dr Wamsley has proved that protecting native animals from the onslaught of the introduced predator types which were not originally present in Australia, particularly the cat and the fox, will allow native animals to continue to evolve and to do their thing, as it were, into the indefinite future. Dr Wamsley accomplished that initially with his own sweat and tears by building the first fence around Warrawong. Then, through taking people through for a charge, he managed to build up a successful company and from that expanded into a much bigger venture at Yookamurra. The Opposition is quite right in supporting Dr Wamsley for those reasons.

However, I would like to make a few other remarks in relation to what both Senator Michael Baume and Senator Crowley had to say. First of all, there is no doubt that statement (ii) under (a) is absolutely correct. The geological record shows that perhaps in the very distant past, perhaps at the time of the extinction of the dinosaurs, there was a mass extinction of species which was certainly not caused by humans because humans were not around at that time. We have some information from that geological record as to what in fact happened to life on earth at that time. It went through a very difficult time.

Since that time, in more recent history-the last few hundred million years-the rate of species extinction has certainly been greater than at any time during that period. That is quite clear from the record. It is not a matter simply that we are better able to measure change because the change is there in the record. It can be seen in the rate of species loss and habitat loss, which are indeed enormous.

Senator Baume is also correct when he says we should not simply be attempting to preserve the status quo. Slow, ponderous evolution has gone on throughout 4,000 million years. There has been continuous change. It is the rate of change and its causation which is of concern now. Conservation has been defined as the attitude which causes humans to stand back from their intrusion into that evolutionary process to allow those ponderous processes of evolution to resume their course as they were before the interruption of those processes by humanity. That is what conservation is about. It does not mean that we attempt to freeze evolution in a moment of time. It means that we allow that slow and ponderous-and I stress those words-process of evolution to go on without the massive intrusion of human demands on the environment.

As Senator Baume pointed out, it is incredibly precious of Senator Crowley not to support this motion simply because it does not praise the Government. My God, if we were not to pass anything in this place because it did not praise the Government we would not get very far at the present time, especially in view of the Budget.

Moreover, if we did not pass anything simply because it was not completely comprehensive and did not mention everything that might be in the remotest way related to the thing before us again, we would not pass very much. It is appropriate to put these words down and to speak of the human induced rate of species extinction, about which there is no doubt, and to commend Dr Wamsley for his work.

Senator Crowley mentioned that when one goes to Warrawong, Dr Wamsley may use some strong words about his concern for the extinction of many species of animals in Australia and about the failure not only of this Government but also of successive governments to do anything about it other than study the process while animals slowly became rarer and rarer and then disappear forever.

He is absolutely and entirely justified in abusing his fellow Australians for allowing that process to continue when they do not and have not done anything about it. He is entirely justified. Those of us who feel very deeply about the protection of Australia's indigenous and unique flora and fauna do not feel that as abuse. We entirely agree with Dr Wamsley. Those who have not done enough to protect that flora and fauna may feel abused. So they might, because they deserve to be abused.

Senator Crowley also mentioned, and she sought leave to table, the list of the research which has been done under the Hawke Government. She specifically mentioned the preparation of recovery plans for threatened species. That precisely is the point that Senator Lees made. We can have all the plans in the world. We can study species as they become rarer and rarer. We can know more and more about them until the last animal disappears. Unless, at the same time, we do something to save those species so that they remain around for future generations and for their own ongoing evolution then all the studies in the world come to nought. They will be stuffed specimens in a museum slowly moulding away, and by another two or three generations even those will have gone.

Important as the research is, it is not saving species, and that is the essential contribution which Dr Wamsley has made. He has shown conclusively that, at the very least with respect to those species that he has at Warrawong, by fencing an area against the intrusion of feral predatory animals, especially the fox and the cat, one can re-introduce native animals to an area from which they have been extinct for a long time. One can have them flourish, breed and perform exactly as they were before European human beings came to Australia 200 years ago. That demonstration is extremely valuable.

Only a couple of weeks ago I saw a television program which dealt with one of the large national parks in the Broken Hill region. It dealt with the plight of the yellow footed rock wallaby and mentioned that area was absolutely infested with goats. The program said that in the previous five months 14,000 goats had been shot using rifles mounted in helicopters. Yet at the time the film was shot there were still 14,000 goats there.

There remained in that national park-a national park set aside largely to protect the yellow footed rock wallaby-some 40 yellow footed rock wallabies compared with 14,000 goats. Surely, with the ongoing attempt to control the goat problem by shooting-which clearly had to be repeated over and over again, and we were still not protecting the very species for which the park had been set aside-we should be looking to the sort of solution that Dr Wamsley has demonstrated works. We should be looking to fence those areas off against goats, excluding them altogether so there would be an area where the yellow footed rock wallaby was not competing with an animal which was totally destroying its habitat.

I am very pleased that the Opposition supports the motion. I am deeply disappointed that the Government finds itself so precious, so hurt, that somebody else might be doing something effective in wildlife protection that it feels itself unable to support this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 August, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the Senate:

(a) deplores the violence, loss of life and destruction of property that has taken place in Slovenia and Croatia, where more than 300 civilians are reported to have been killed, largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist led Federal Army and attacks by the Army itself;
(b) notes the potential for further conflict if aspirations for self-determination expressed through democratic plebiscites in the Yugoslav Republics are confronted by military force;
(c) welcomes the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator to prevent further conflict;

(d) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav Republics, which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence the people of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities; and

(e) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the motion. A week is a long time in politics. It is certainly a long time considering what has happened in the Soviet Union since I almost completed my speech on the motion last week. It is interesting to note that some of the commentators are now talking-and even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has hinted-of recognising the Baltic states.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel most strongly that we should recognise Croatia and Slovenia. When I say that, I do so for a very good reason. Australia could take the lead-and hopefully other countries would fall in behind us-to condemn these Serbian communists who at this point in time seem to be causing most of the trouble and the deaths.

When I last spoke on the motion I quoted from a press clipping which said that more than 300 people had been killed in Croatia. I repeat: from the information I have received, I believe that the figure could be as much as 10 times higher. When I last spoke, AAP issued a press article which noted that Croatian exiles-some from Australia-were taking part in a frantic effort to train the Croatian defence force. That article states:
`The best way to stop the war is to recognise Croatian independence,' said Joe, who returned to Trstenik from the United States to help train a national guard force.
`Then, the federal army will not destroy our villages or kill people as it's doing at the moment,' the 25-year-old said.

I think that sums up the situation. These two independent states have chosen to take the route of democracy. Their people have voted to do that, they want independence, they have said they want it, and I believe that Australia should recognise those states and that they should be allowed to have their independence. I know that many other honourable senators wish to take part in this debate and therefore shall conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I wish to support the terms of this motion. It captures the sentiment that we all feel about the very unhappy situation in Yugoslavia, and expresses in a positive way-which we in the Government accept-the need for us to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement, which will avoid conflict and meet the aspirations of the constituent units of the republic for independence. Those aspirations are real; they have been manifested by democratic process and should be respected.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a difficulty in terms of the international community in general, or Australia in particular, in moving from that set of perceptions to a ready acknowledgment or recognition of statehood. There are criteria that need to be satisfied, which I spelt out in detail in answer to a question by Senator Harradine the other day, before countries externally can confidently go down the path of recognition without getting caught up in terrible inconsistencies in the way in which we deal with these situations generally.

The criterion in particular of all of them that matters most is that of demonstrable control of the territory in question by the entity in question. The big difficulty so far as Croatia is concerned is in demonstrating in present circumstances that degree of control. Accordingly, it is a situation that cries out for a negotiated peaceful solution, one that will satisfy the aspirations of the people in the way that the international community can respond to.

There are some grounds for optimism that a peaceful solution might be possible. A meeting between the federal collective presidency and the presidents of the six Yugoslav republics was held on 20 August, a couple of days ago, to try to reinstitute the cease-fire. That meeting succeeded in agreeing a four-point plan involving recognition of the right of every people to self-determination, including cessation; secondly, respect for the democratically expressed will of all peoples; thirdly, equal treatment of all political options without the use of force; and, finally, legal implementation of the accord.

The difficulty is, as we all know, that the recent trend of events in Yugoslavia has, unfortunately, seen the action on the ground pursued, regardless of the various political arrangements and promises that have been made or put in place. Press reports this morning indicate that fighting is, regrettably, still continuing and that the Yugoslav national army has been accused of taking sides in the conflict and supporting Serbian irregular forces in their capture of Croatian territory.

The European Community has faced up to its responsibility to take the leading role in bringing the Yugoslav parties to the negotiating table. The Australian Government lends its full support to these efforts, including the efforts to implement the Brioni agreement, which was broken by the EC on 7 July.

I take this opportunity to renew the call of the Australian Government to all the Yugoslav parties to heed the lessons of the failed coup in Moscow, and to show the courage and leadership that are necessary to resolve the crisis in their country by peaceful means.

I am instructing the Australian Ambassador in Belgrade to bring this call to the attention of the federal and republican leaders in Yugoslavia. I can repeat the undertaking that has been previously given that once Croatia and Slovenia meet the criteria for statehood under international law Australia will be among the first to extend recognition to them.

I fully sympathise, as does the Australian Government, with the anxiety that many Australians with links to Yugoslavia are feeling at this time. I take this opportunity again to ask them to continue the commendable restraint that they have shown thus far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the contribution by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), I would like to say that I am sure that many senators around this chamber, people outside who are of Croatian or Slovenian extraction and, indeed, all other Australians will welcome the comments of Senator Evans committing the Government to support this motion. As the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, said on the last occasion on which this matter was discussed, this motion is the result of discussions that took place with a number of senators, including myself. I believe that in all its elements it is a worthwhile motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The violence, loss of life and destruction of property in Slovenia and Croatia-particularly in Croatia-are still continuing. As the motion says, this is largely as a result of the attacks by terrorists supplied by the communist-led federal army and attacks by the army itself. Freedom loving people, people who by democratic will have expressed their desire for independence, deserve to be supported by independently minded and democratic people such as Australians and the Australian Parliament.

I would like to rehearse many of the events that have taken place, but time does not permit me to do so. Suffice it to say that I have just come from a meeting of parliamentarians for Croatia and Slovenia, which was convened by Mr Paul Filing, the Federal member for Moore. I had the honour of being elected Vice-President of that body, the President being Dr Theophanous. Therefore, there is a broad range of opinion that is supporting the democratically expressed determination of the peoples of Slovenia and Croatia. I commend this motion to the Senate.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 6.28 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two directions that this country can take: either it can continue to drift under Labor or it can embrace the program of radical reform which we offer. We recognise that it is never easy to face up to major change but, in our view, at the present time there is no choice. Labor is now locked in. The Keating challenge and the pre-eminence of the Left leave the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) totally shackled. But even he has abandoned any semblance of significant reform. Clearly, the Labor Party is only interested in attacking us and trying to build an atmosphere of fear-fear of change. What a tragedy that must be for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal tonight with one aspect of our reform program and that is tax reform. I will put it in context, because we offer many others-labour market reform, reform of protection policies, privatisation, infrastructure improvement and others. All of those reforms are designed to contribute to building a more competitive, outward looking economy. That is the key to rebuilding Australia.

To embrace our package will be a challenge for all Australians. It might have been easier to allow government simply to fall into our lap. In fact, some commentators have suggested that that is what we should have done. But that would be abdicating our responsibility to enunciate a better alternative and, in government, to be prepared to implement it.

Australians will be prepared to accept our challenge. They are indicating it in the polls. There is now a 16.5 per cent gap between the two alternative governments. People know that Australia must now radically change. It is a hard, cruel, competitive world out there. Australia can no longer insulate or isolate itself from it. We must compete within it. The Government must ensure that the wealth creators in our society are not inhibited by outdated structures.

It is no good saying that our wharves are more efficient than they were last year. The question is whether our wharves are more efficient than those with which we compete. That is what this Government does not face up to. The cost of this drift, as demonstrated in this Budget, is misery to the hundreds of thousands of Australians who are now out of work. They are out of work, make no mistake, because of the appalling economic judgments of the Hawke-Keating Government. They were warned of the consequences of high interest rates. For months they were warned of high interest rates crushing Australian business, but they refused to listen.

Why did they refuse to listen? They refused to listen because they had no alternative. They were locked in by vested interests. They were locked into the accord by the union movement. There were no other alternatives for them to take. They were not able to make the major structural changes that are necessary for this country. They had no alternative but to stick with cripplingly high interest rates for far too long and we all now know the consequences of that.

For the same reason, the Government still cannot act. That was demonstrated yet again in this Budget. It was a Budget that gave no hope. I suggest that the Government lost the right to say again, `Trust us, it will all work out'. It is what government members have been saying over the last few days. We have heard it in this chamber- `It will work out; there will be a recovery'. Australians no longer believe it. There is 28 per cent youth unemployment in this country. What a disgrace. What will the figure be next year? The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) does not know. All we know is that it will be higher.

Could there be a greater indictment of a government than to have somewhere between a quarter and a third of its young people out of work? We were told today that 770,000 would be the average number of people on unemployment benefits in this country next year. How appalling. What is it expected to go up to? Over 900,000. What is the real unemployment rate? Those who are on unemployment benefits or the alternative to unemployment benefits probably account for well over one million people. There are a million people out of work in this country because this Government got it wrong. The government of the worker, its members say to us.

What do we get from this Budget? We get a Budget which is uninspiring, unimaginative and which has no solution. The Left is upset. Business is appalled. The Treasurer (Mr Kerin) is already, interestingly, distancing himself from the Budget, the parameters of which had been set before he came into the job. That is not leadership. A family allowance supplement package does not give jobs back to people. It gives only temporary relief to arrest the poverty created by Labor in the recession we had to have.

In his address, the Treasurer referred to last year as `a disappointing year for all Australians; a year of lost jobs, squeezed profits and dashed hopes'. When I first read that I could not believe it. I re-read it. Mr Kerin in his Budget Speech described last year as `a disappointing year for all Australians; a year of lost jobs, squeezed profits and dashed hopes'. That is the view of this Government. The Treasurer is right; he is dead right. What he did not say was that, with his Budget, the position would get worse. It was a presentation of a Budget that was designed to anticipate greater misery for the millions of Australians who are directly or indirectly suffering as a result of this Government's incompetence.

The Budget needed to deliver many things and it failed on all counts. The Australian economy should show vitality and strength. There is no reason why it should not. But where are the measures to restore the vitality that has been decimated in the last eight years? Economic growth must be boosted and our international competitiveness enhanced. But the Government has not initiated any process to address these shortcomings in its current policies. Quite the contrary. What will be the cost to jobs when the Lodge initiated compulsory superannuation deal flows through? What government in its right mind, in the deepest recession that this country has faced since the 1930s, would apply this extra impost to employment? Only a government which is required to do so by a union movement. What does that say about today's union movement? It says that the union movement has abdicated its responsibility to the workers as well.

We would like to see more Australians with superannuation. We would like to see more workers with the capacity to save for their retirement. We would like to see more employers able to contribute to their workers' superannuation. But in a deep recession, to apply a formula in which one person's superannuation may well be the last straw that breaks another person's job is unbelievable, and this from a Labor government which claims to be the workers' government. No wonder that the Left is mad. If Senator Bolkus and his colleagues from the Left spent more time looking after the workers' interests rather than trying to abolish basic freedoms, we would all be better off.

There we are. We have a Budget that will not restore business investment or jobs; a Budget deficit that is likely to be well over the $4.7 billion predicted; and a Budget which sees Labor again ripping off ordinary Australians' savings. What did we hear from the previous Treasurer about ripping off the savings of ordinary Australians? Here it is again-a Budget which offers no relief to the near record high real interest rates, so often forgotten by this Government. Those interest rates are still at a near record high level. What a dismal effort.

I turn to the question of tax reform, because what people will always find from the coalition on this side of the chamber is a well-thought through, constructive alternative. I will explain why tax reform is so critical to the economic recovery of Australia. Perhaps if this Government had grasped the nettle on reform years ago Australia would not be paying such a high price now.

A tax system that is manifestly inefficient, unfair and inequitable condemns this nation to second-rate status. Australia finds itself in the position of being one of only two OECD nations that have a wholesale sales tax. Switzerland, which is one of the two, also has a retail sales tax. It means that, unlike our competitors, we are afflicted with a wholesale sales tax levied indiscriminately at three different rates-10, 20 and 30 per cent.

In the last two decades, 18 OECD countries have moved towards some form of broad-based consumption tax. They have done it because they could see that they can produce a better, more competitive taxation system as a result. In total, 21 of the 23 OECD economies have a goods and services tax. As I said, the resulting tax mix for those countries means less reliance on income tax and a more efficient, simple rationalisation of the indirect tax base. Labor knows it, and it knew it in 1985. The difference is that it was not prepared to do it and it is still not prepared to do it. It is not a satisfactory response for Australia merely to broaden its existing wholesale sales tax base. The result would only be a more complicated, haphazard confusion which would impact adversely on both the consumer and business. The current tax mix in Australia comprises a high level of income tax which, combined with the effects of inflation, has led many taxpayers to be pushed into high tax brackets.
