Any incentive to work more and earn more is then crushed by the application of those high marginal tax rates.

Our existing wholesale sales tax system was designed over 50 years ago in a totally different world. Moreover, it was designed and intended to apply only to luxury items. Yet this Government, having made only minor alterations, purports that it is a satisfactory method of taxation in today's world. Its inequitable application means that currently 20 per cent wholesale sales tax is paid on items such as toothpaste and deodorant but that there is no wholesale sales tax on antiques, artworks or imported clothes.

What is the justification for this approach in the well-earned tests of tax such as equity, simplicity and efficiency? It fails on all counts. The wholesale sales tax raised $3.5 billion in 1982-83, a take that has now increased to over $10.7 billion in 1990-91. Ironically, it is the same level that we estimate may well be the Budget deficit. There has been an increase in sales tax receipts in real terms of 53 per cent per adult since this Government came to power. It is a system which is inefficient, expensive and complex to administer and which delivers no benefits to our taxation system.

Most importantly, however, the wholesale sales tax is a concealed, obscure, indirect tax of which the consumer is often unaware. It is a clear example of tax by stealth, which the coalition will abolish completely. That abolition will be in favour of tax reform which, with income tax reductions and cuts in government spending, will impose a single rate, broad-based goods and services tax which is clearly visible to the consumer, taxing goods and services equally. Consumers will know for the first time what tax they are paying and at what rate, and they will know the cost price on which it is applied.

I have spoken before, and again tonight, of the need for Australia to be internationally competitive. As the situation stands currently, inputs into our export products are subject to this hidden tax. This represents a cost of about $1 billion a year to exporters. In the current international market, exporters cannot pass on the costs of that burden. The coalition's tax reforms will ensure that exports are zero rated, with any goods and services tax paid on inputs being fully rebated.

The wholesale sales tax also fails in another important area: it does not catch tax cheats and does not include transactions in the black economy. Individuals who persist in operating within the black economy under our alternative will not be able to avoid paying tax on their purchases of goods and services with that black cash. It is time that this country realised that the average taxpayer should not have to foot the bill for tax avoiders and black marketeers.

The Government has been spreading misinformation about this proposal, particularly as to how it might affect low and mixed income earners. We are prepared to face those arguments. We want to debate the issue and we want it on the table, because Australians will realise that, as part of a tax reform package, it is in their best interests. It is not correct to say, for example, that superannuants cannot be compensated for a goods and services tax. Pensioners, full or part, can have any additional costs offset through an increase in the pension. Those on full super who do not receive the pension and still pay some income tax and the Medicare levy will benefit as income tax rates are adjusted to take into account the introduction of a goods and services tax.

In addressing the need for reform of the tax system, the coalition is acknowledging the current inequities that have imposed an unfair burden on many taxpayers for too long. Our package will ensure that families with children receive significant benefits from income tax cuts, thus providing greater spending power. Those families who have a fixed income, such as those relying on a pension or other type of benefit, will have any additional costs offset through the social security system.

The abolition of the wholesale sales tax and its replacement with a goods and services tax will also serve other groups of Australians. Rural Australians are so often forgotten by this particular Government. I expect we will hear much more about them from my colleague Senator Boswell later tonight. Residents of rural Australia who struggle under the policies of this Government will benefit. In addition to the abolition of sales tax on their purchases, farmers who make a massive contribution to our export sector will gain from the coalition's proposal that all exports be zero rated. The GST that they pay on inputs to export products will also be refunded. This will be particularly important with regard to fuel costs, which present such a high cost to the farming community.

It is also well recognised that one of our most important industries, tourism, provides free use of many of our facilities and services and untaxed goods to international tourists. The WST does not have a major impact on this sector; there is not a lot of wholesale sales tax paid in this sector. The application of a goods and services tax would mean that foreign tourists would contribute to the maintenance of the services they enjoy in Australia. We do not see anything wrong with that.

I wish also briefly to refer to the public support that is being received for tax reform in Australia because it is demonstrating a lesson to this Government, which is too afraid to act in this important area. Last week a committee of prominent dedicated Australians launched an organisation called Australians for Tax Reform. There is in the community, and it shows, a serious realisation that this nation cannot continue to ignore the need for an economy which is strong and vital, industry which is internationally competitive and a growing economy which will not tolerate the spectre of unemployment at the level of 10.5 per cent. The statement of the committee in launching its organisation was a telling one:

Australians for Tax Reform is a group of leading Australians in their fields who come from a range of backgrounds but have a common belief-that Australia's tax system should be reformed to become fairer, more efficient and more competitive with tax systems in other countries.

It is timely indeed to raise again this reform in light of the Government having presented to the people of Australia a nothing Budget: one designed to get it through the next few weeks; it is not one for the next decade. It is now clear to all that this is a government bereft of leadership and vision. This Budget should have faced the difficult major reform decisions and, particularly, it should have recognised the need for the fundamental reform of our taxation system. A broad based goods and services tax, cuts in personal income tax, and the abolition of the wholesale sales tax will be, when they are introduced by us, major steps towards achieving that goal.

I suggest that never before has the contrast been so clear: a do nothing government more concerned with its own survival; or an alternative government which will take the obvious, but hard, decisions which will give real hope to Australians for the future. Whether it is Mr Hawke or Mr Keating, it is the same. They have both failed Australia and the sooner they are gone the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1991 Budget has been brought down by a tired government: a government that has run out of vision; a government that is bereft of ideas; and one that is slowly ebbing out of office. After the Government had bludgeoned one million people onto the dole queues and thus reduced inflation, this Budget should have provided a golden opportunity to encourage investment and incentive. But instead the Government has chosen to recognise the productive sectors of the economy by hitting them with further costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In times when the Government is predicting unemployment at 10 3/4 per cent, these extra costs to the productive sector can only see more jobs being lost. What sort of Labor Government is it that actually budgets for more than one million unemployed people? It is a disgraceful government that would even contemplate such a figure. It is no wonder that every Labor Premier in Australia has turned his or her back on this Government and walked away from it as though it were well and truly on the nose.

The figures presented by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) only confirm that the Australian economy is truly in a desperate state. The Budget has now gone into deficit. The official Government figure is $4.7 billion. In reality, the actual Budget deficit is close to $10.7 billion, when the real factors of asset sales, debt transfers to the States, superannuation transfers and dividend increases from the Commonwealth and Reserve banks are taken into account.

Budget outlays are up by 2.6 per cent in real terms, taxation revenue is down 2.1 per cent, and Commonwealth spending is up 4.9 per cent. The Treasurer has predicted an economic recovery in the second half of this year, but I really believe Senator Walsh's statement that `Only a fool or a fraud would try to predict the timing of an economic recovery'. Senator Walsh did not want to have a bar of this Government and that is why he refused to serve on the front bench. He knew that this Government was finished and he did not want to be in the ship when it went down.

Based on the current economic climate, can we have any faith that the prediction of a $4.7 billion deficit will not go the way of last year's predictions-the $9 billion surplus which fell to a $1.8 billion surplus? Australia desperately needed a Budget that would return confidence in the future and lead to increased investment. Instead, business has been targeted for a new tax in order to pay for a Government promise on superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the Ministers?

—I can understand the Government Ministers' embarrassment and I can understand why they could not bear to hear this. Businesses with a payroll of $500,000 are to pay 5 per cent superannuation and all other businesses are to pay 3 per cent, rising to 5 per cent by 1995; all with the certainty that it is planned to rise to 9 per cent by the year 2000-and, if Mr Keating reaches ascendancy again, he has promised 12 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when corporate profits are at their lowest level for 25 years, when bankruptcies are increasing at a rate of over 50 per cent per year, this is not the time to impose an employment tax of 3 to 5 per cent. The Government has once again shown that it is the captive of the ACTU. That is its real master. We are told that Keating had promised legislated superannuation to the ACTU and that Hawke had to deliver it to keep the support of the unions in order to maintain his numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the Ministers?

—The Ministers cannot take it; they have just run away. The ACTU was not happy with the last national wage case, disagreeing with accord mark VI which granted an extra 3 per cent superannuation, taking it to 6 per cent. In the last few months we have seen the ACTU trying to get around the umpire's decision, which it did not like. With the Government's help, it got the accord mark VI benefit of a further 3 per cent superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Now the Government has gone the whole hog and handed it back to the ACTU on a plate, with the backing of legislation. If only some of the genuine needs of the productive sector, the business sector and the farming sector, could be given the same amount of ear time as the ACTU. It is certainly the body preferred by this Government.

Small business received nothing from this Budget-that is, nothing except the extra costs of compulsory superannuation. The legislated superannuation will be a big burden on small business, not only in the cost of an extra 3 per cent that has to be found, but also administration will be time consuming by nature of the employees-many being transient, part time or casual. This represents an extra burden in difficult times.

Leaking the Budget has become the Government's practice. Small business was given the impression and the expectation that a capital gains tax roll-over would be provided by this Budget. Small business needs this relief of retaining its capital in order to expand and develop. Yet this was not forthcoming. Its expectations were rocked.

At the same time, during the term of the Hawke Government, labour costs for small business have increased enormously. Overall high interest rate policies have crippled many businesses, but under the Hawke Government labour costs have increased in the vicinity of 25 per cent between the mark IV and the mark V accord. New taxes on business have been introduced which have all imposed costs at a time when businesses are struggling through the recession we had to have.

The series of accord agreements negotiated between the ACTU and the Government have seen the introduction of many new costs. There has been the training guarantee levy, increased costs associated with the 38-hour week, superannuation, costs arising from award restructuring, paternity and maternity leave, annual leave, sick and travelling leave, and the new apprenticeship fees. As former Whitlam Government Minister Frank Crean once said, `One man's pay rise is another man's job'. This Budget should have done something for the 26.5 per cent of young people without jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-eight.

—I have been corrected-it is 28.5 per cent. That is a national tragedy and a national disgrace. The Budget did not give any of those young people any hope for the future. Three hundred thousand jobs were lost last year and this Budget sets an increase of $2.3 billion to cover the extra people who will be on the dole queue. That is first aid money; that is not what people are looking for. That mentality shows the basic difference between the thought processes of the Opposition and the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of addressing measures to encourage growth, development, business confidence and investment, the Government only addresses the welfare payments that have to pick up the pieces after Government policies have swirled through the economy like a hurricane, leaving destruction and broken pieces in their wake. No doubt farmers appreciate the extra family support that this Budget gives them; but they do not appreciate the Government's destructive high interest rate policy that has put them in a position where they have to be recipients of the social welfare program.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) has acknowledged that over 50 per cent of farming families will have incomes less than $10,000 a year. In times of drastically falling prices in most commodities, many farming families will have negative incomes, with average farm incomes having fallen by a massive 80 per cent this year. I know that Senator Panizza and Senator Crane are very worried by those figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all are.

—So is every other coalition senator. This year farm export prices fell by 15 per cent and farm product prices fell by 26 per cent, while farm output increased by 10 per cent. Farmers faced increases in costs of 15.7 per cent in fuel prices, 8.2 per cent in maintenance, 6.8 per cent in contracts, 8.8 per cent in rates and taxes, and 4.6 per cent in labour costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget special consideration has been given to the farmer in relation to the new assets test of $600,000 for the family allowance. This relief, which is available for only two years, suspends the assets test if farmers have a taxable income of less than $13,000 and liquid assets of less than $10,000.

Also welcome to the struggling farmers will be the concessions on Austudy and the isolated children's scheme where the assets test of $695,000 will not apply if the student's parents are receiving a pension or are being assisted out of farming under the rural assistance scheme-but that is very few people. This does not help very many people at all. This does not help the farmers who continue to battle on on the land, nor their children who are being deprived of the right to an education because they are asset rich and income desperate.

At the same time, farmers have had to bear the brunt of Government policy of 100 per cent cost recovery for the inspection and export charges, and the Government will not reform the service that the farmer has to pay for. This is an increase of 34 per cent. Such a service is the meat inspection service paid for by the beef industry. From 1 January this year, the beef industry has been required to pay 100 per cent of its meat inspection services. In just one year, this has imposed an extra cost of $71m on the industry. In one year, the costs have gone from $33m to $104m. At the same time, Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service charges are $67,000 for each inspector. This is an example of much needed efficiency reforms that the Government refuses to address. Primary industry is burdened with such inefficiencies.

I refer to the plight of persons living in rural Australia and what they will get from the Budget. Like all Australians, there is the increase in Medicare payments to $3.50, rising to $5 by November next year. If their children are fortunate enough to be receiving a tertiary education, there is the increase of $144 a year, taking the higher education contribution to $2,250.

Roads, which are vital to rural communities, have had a funding cut of 22 per cent in real terms. Superannuation payments of 3 per cent to 5 per cent will have to be paid to all employees and to all processing industries, and will flow through to the farmer.

The relief provided by Austudy and the isolated children's scheme will assist only those on the way out of the industry or those on a pension. At the same time, the debt ridden farmer will not be getting any reduction in interest rates on any long term basis. Government spending has been increased for dubious reasons.

The environment budget has increased by 30 per cent. A national conservation protection agency is to be set up. We are to give $20m to international environmental assistance. Cities are to receive $56m this year and $860m over the next five years.

It is hard to avoid the conclusion that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has given undue attention to the two vital sectors of his support base: the Greens and the Left. At the same time, the Government is happy to impose on rural industries policies such as 100 per cent cost recovery on inspection charges and to hinder their efficiency because reform in transport and on the waterfront is taking place at a snail's pace.

Many industries are at crisis point. The background to this year is a decline in crop prices of 14.9 per cent and livestock prices of 11.8 per cent. According to the latest ABARE figures, prices for wheat declined by 33.6 per cent, barley by 24 per cent, sugar by 9.2 per cent and vegetables by 27.7 per cent. Similarly, with livestock, prices for wool fell by 27.5 per cent, sheep by 65 per cent, milk by 12.8 per cent, sheep for export by 41.5 per cent and cattle by 2 per cent.

Despite this, the agricultural sector still contributes a massive amount to this economy and it prevents the bottom falling out of the Australian economy. Under all of these difficult circumstances, the agricultural sector has boosted productivity by nearly 9 per cent and increased export volumes, despite a contracting international market and prices and the corruption of world commodity prices.

Prices paid to farmers last year rose by only 0.9 per cent, the lowest since 1969-70. For example, the point has been reached where vegetable growers selling their produce on the domestic market are often sent a bill rather than a cheque. In turn, our processors are suffering and the existence of some of the value adding industries, such as the pineapple and vegetable processors, are under the very threat of survival from the flood of highly subsidised imports.

In many cases, the importer is getting the advantage of cheap labour costs and is really a multinational company relocated in Asia solely for the purpose of the cheap production costs. To make matters worse, it receives a 5 per cent tariff reduction on goods coming into Australia on developing country preference.

In other cases, the massive subsidies in the EEC and the United States are destroying our rural industries. We have had the recent example of the Saudi wheat imported into New Zealand receiving a subsidy of between $600 and $1,000 a tonne, where our growers are netting something like $68 a tonne. Reforms to the common agricultural policy in the European Community will still result in an increase in the subsidy bill by $5.5 billion from this year's level to $58 billion in 1997. This is the trading situation that Australian farmers now face, both domestically and internationally. Our efficient farmers can only compete if their costs are reduced.

This Budget does not address reducing these costs and reforming input costs which are the real factors causing inefficiencies. The Budget has not addressed the real issues that need to be dealt with immediately. Our massive foreign debt of $170 billion and current account deficit of $15 billion can be reined in only if our export industries are boosted and not burdened. Reform in transport, handling, shipping and the waterfront must occur immediately, not over a multi-year program. This Government must stop imposing more costs on all business because it has to dance to the tune of the ACTU and the Green movement.

The Budget is a disappointment. Not only was it a lost opportunity to alleviate costs on our productive sector, but it was shamefully used to impose further crippling costs on business and our productive sectors and it can only add to our appalling level of unemployment.

This Budget is not a people's Budget in that it does not provide opportunities for investment, growth and employment. Instead, it limits the hope and chances of all Australians and denies all Australians the hope and chance to get in there and to do their bit to lift Australia's performance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a degree of sadness that the Australian Democrats respond to the Government's 1991-92 Budget. On the announcement of the appointment of Mr Kerin to the office of Treasurer, I issued a statement saying that this was an opportunity for the Government to change direction in economic policy. Indeed, Mr Kerin made some statements which indicated he was prepared to intervene in this economy to boost employment; however, this Budget proves that this was a forlorn hope. It is a Budget of no hope for 28.5 per cent-more than one in four-of our young people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Financial Review led with the headline `Budget 1991: Conservative parcel with a jobless sting'. There is no doubt that the statement is absolutely accurate. The appalling feature of the community's response to the Budget is that we are so used to the Labor Government implementing coalition policies that the news is greeted with little more than embarrassed resignation by Caucus members.

I was, therefore, heartened by reports that the more independent members of the supposed Labor Government are beginning to speak out against the `appease the market' philosophy which still dominates the policy formulation of the Budget process. I was pleased to hear Mr Langmore today speaking openly of the need for a subsequent mini-Budget to address properly the scandal of continued high unemployment.

The Australian Democrats completely agree with those sentiments, particularly since Mr Kerin was compelled to deliver what must be largely a Keating Budget. How can an estimated rate of unemployment of 10.5 per cent be tolerated in the Government's major economic statement of the year? At what level of unemployment will the Government change its stated policy of reducing inflation first, no matter what the social cost? Indeed, what is the role of the Government if it is not to attempt to change an economic direction which is bringing misery to millions of Australians, particularly since a large amount of the current unemployment has been intentionally engineered by the Government?

I would now like to consider the economic climate which is predicted for the current financial year. The outlook cannot be described as anything other than bleak. For the last year we have had various Ministers proclaiming the myth that recovery is just around the corner. However, every few months the commencement of that recovery suffers a delay. The increase in unemployment which will peak at a full percentage point above the current level in this year shows how hollow that prediction is.

The Government predicts a total collapse in private investment in the current year, yet it refuses to increase public investment to fill the gap. General business investment is predicted to decline by 10.5 per cent, non-dwelling construction by 15.25 per cent and plant and equipment by 8 per cent. This can hardly be termed economic recovery. If it were not for a 5 per cent increase in private dwelling investment, the total predicted reduction of 6 per cent in private investment would be even worse.

Further bad news awaits when one examines the expected household savings behaviour this year. The annual rate is predicted to fall further than in 1990-91. This, of course, means that the fall in investment will not even flow through into a substantial reduction in the current account deficit. Prior to the golden age of deregulation and free market ideology, this type of economic outlook would have been met with shame and it would have led to an increase in outlays to attempt to reduce the suffering. But, instead, the Budget Speech informs us:
As a share of the economy, outlays will be slightly higher than last year, but this increase is more than accounted for by the increase in outlays associated with the slowdown in economic activity.

In the worst recession in 60 years, which Mr Kerin, perhaps ominously, referred to as a depression, we have the Treasurer announcing a steady-as-she-goes policy in relation to outlays. This is a disgrace-particularly since we are aware of the creative accounting used to reduce outlays, especially the devolution of State debt financing. Clearly, the dominant economic philosophy in the Treasury is that public spending is always too high, even in times of economic catastrophe. The Australian Democrats completely reject this ideologically driven position.

Before examining the spending proposals announced by Mr Kerin, another aspect of the Budget which must be viewed with cynicism is the level of dividends and income being derived from the government financial institutions; that is, the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Bank. At the time of the rescue of the State Bank of Victoria by its incorporation into the Commonwealth Bank, the Democrats suggested that no private equity was necessary because the funds-some $1.6 billion-could be found by a combination of, firstly, the surplus which was returned to the Commonwealth Bank from the Commonwealth Bank Officers Superannuation Corporation; secondly, the dividend from the 1991 earnings of the Commonwealth Bank; and, thirdly, transfers from the hollow log reserves of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

At the time, we were told that such a proposition was ridiculous. In this Budget the Commonwealth expects that it will receive a total of $450m from the Commonwealth Bank this year and over $1.5 billion in earnings from the Reserve Bank. Clearly, the State Bank could have been bought without privatising the Commonwealth Bank. This course of action was not only possible but also entirely feasible and proves yet again that the real motivation for the partial privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank was to ensure that the other parts of the deregulation agenda-Australian Airlines, Qantas, ANL, Telecom Australia and others-were passed through the Australian Labor Party organisation with as little trouble as possible.

I now turn to social security, community services and health. This Budget does very little for those Australians who have been most affected by the recession. It is a niggardly Budget: it gives a little with one hand and takes a lot with the other and, in the end, those people who have borne the brunt of the recession come out of this Budget with no improvement in their situation. I will cover only a few of the key issues, but I am sure that my colleague Senator Lees will be picking up on these and many other issues during the weeks to come.

Some Opposition senators had great fun with their claims that the family allowance expenditure in the Democrats' alternative budget had been understated by $2 billion. As Senator Lees has now put on the public record, the mistake was one of wording: weekly should have been fortnightly, the basis on which the figures were computed having been correctly computed. This paltry exercise shows up the Opposition's desperate attempts to cover up its lack of any credible alternative; in fact, any alternative at all-any measures, any figures, not even on its regressive and already discredited consumption tax.

I refer to Medicare. The Australian Democrats will be opposing the introduction of a patient charge for bulk billed medical services. The proposed charge of $3.50 which will increase to $5 in November 1992 represents a serious retreat from the principle of universal health care and it will not be welcomed by the 70 per cent of Australians who support and approve of the universal character of Medicare.

The fee ignores the findings of the recent report of the Government's own national health strategy, which concluded that charges were `unlikely to play a significant role in solving any of the major problems facing the health sector'. Make no mistake, Madam Acting Deputy President: this fee marks the first nail in the Medicare coffin. It demonstrates this Government's inability to understand that Medicare is not about welfare; rather, it is an effective means of containing medical costs and delivering a good standard of health care to the Australian community.

The Government has been trumpeting that it has done something for farming families, but that package is mere tokenism. The three so-called hardship measures the Government is trumpeting will benefit very few families. In essence, the Government is saying to farmers, `If you are a farming family earning $14,000 a year, you are not poor'. The Government has failed to come to grips with the fact that land and tools of trade assets are virtually worthless unless they are realisable or are generating an income. The plight of farmers will not be alleviated unless and until the valuation of their assets is changed to a realistic basis that entitles them to the assistance they should get. Even then, it will be a fraction of what French and German farmers receive from their governments.

In the area of social security, one can only say that if we had not been through a year of slash and burn in the social security budget we might be able to say that this Budget contained some small goodies. There is to be an increase in the family allowance supplement threshold from next April of $2.15 per week in child disability allowances; there are reforms in child-related payments to pensioners and beneficiaries; the young homeless allowance is to be made available on a weekly basis; and there are a number of other reforms. But the social security measures in this Budget are at the end of a long line of cost-cutting, and the Government has not loosened the screws at all on those people who are unemployed through no fault of their own.

The Government could have done so much more for these people in this Budget. I give just two examples that the Democrats have been pushing for some time. There could have been, firstly, a reversal of the Government's disastrous decision of two years ago to reduce the incomes of young people receiving social security payments, a material cause of the catastrophic youth homelessness identified by the Burdekin report; and, secondly, the reduction or elimination of the waiting periods for social security payments. This is universally acknowledged by welfare organisations to be the cause of increasing demand upon their services and increasing suffering for families. The Government's failure to move on these issues demonstrates that in social justice terms this Budget represents a government that is treading water while those around it drown.

I now turn to superannuation, the centrepiece of what has been described as a nothing Budget. It was the long awaited announcement on superannuation and what it will do for domestic savings in the next decade. However, it is not only unimpressive but perhaps the most disappointing feature of this Budget that these domestic savings are not being mobilised in a strategic manner to assist the Australian economy.

What could be more justified in the investment of superannuation funds than the placement of a proportion of these funds in government and public utilities which pay a reasonable rate of return and which are government guaranteed? Clearly, the use of superannuation funds in this way opens up the possibility of funding public infrastructure investment, freeing other funds for equity investment in the private sector. However, the Government has so far chosen not to respond to our calls for this strategic measure, which offers the key for a significant improvement in our economic strategy.

I now return to the actual provisions that the Government has announced. Apart from the compulsory minimum contribution proposals, which I will deal with later, two papers were distributed by the Treasurer dealing with various aspects of the regulation of superannuation. The first paper concerns the prudential supervision of the industry and the second paper deals with the disclosure of information to members of superannuation funds. Both of these matters are to be examined by the Select Committee on Superannuation, initiated by the Democrats, which became necessary due to the lack of progress by the Government in these important areas.

The paper dealing with prudential controls borders on the pathetic. Firstly, we have the assertion in the accompanying press release that any direction of fund investment is not on the agenda. I have dealt with that before. It is perhaps the major disappointment of this Budget that the Government is not prepared to use this strategic measure to pull ourselves up by our own bootstraps. I quote from the paper:

The Government does not intend to specify where funds can invest, except to the extent necessary for prudential purposes, because this could inefficiently allocate resources, with consequential detrimental effects on members' entitlements and the economy generally.
Thus the complete hands-off approach to financial regulation is being perpetuated. Yet page 1 of Mr Kerin's Budget statement states:

There was an unprecedented and unsustainable boom in asset prices in the second half of the 1980s. Its subsequent unwinding pulled the rug out from under many speculative investments and business ventures.

This extremely inefficient allocation of resources, especially the oversupply of central business district property, can be traced directly to the deregulation of the financial system. We are now living through the recession which had to follow the naive deregulation of the financial system.

With 10 per cent unemployment, we are still being told that we cannot interfere with the market. Why can our productive small businesses not have access to appropriate amounts of development capital? Why is it more efficient to have invention after invention developed in foreign factories, creating foreign jobs, because we lack the patient capital and the acumen to do it ourselves?

Indeed, the former Treasurer, the architect of deregulation, has noted that he did not want to see a boom in Sydney and Melbourne real estate to be the only result of the engineered shift in the savings mix to superannuation. Senator Button, to his credit, has long acknowledged the need for long term development funds. He tried to establish a $1 billion fund to fill this market failure, but was stymied by the short-sighted failure of the life insurance companies to make a contribution to Australia's future. Tragically, he has now abandoned that course of action.

There are no prudential standard proposals in the paper other than the possibility of requiring trustees of funds of an unspecified size to be corporations. We are also told that some additional, but again unspecified, solvency and prudential requirements `possibly along the lines of the requirements of the Life Insurance Act' are being considered. Given that the Government has been reviewing the Life Insurance Act for years and that some decisions have had to be taken because of the Regal-Occidental scandal, the failure to provide a lead on the vital question of prudential standards is indicative of the Government's cavalier attitude to Australian investors.

There are serious structural problems with the newly established dispute resolution mechanisms in respect of life insurance and general insurance, despite the appointment of some excellent people to those bodies. This occurred because of inadequate consumer involvement in the initial establishment consultations. This mistake must not be repeated in the case of superannuation, yet we have a failure to specify adequate prudential requirements.

One other point needs to be made on this paper. The Treasurer stated quite clearly that the Government will not guarantee superannuation funds, adding that the final risk must lie with the investor. This statement has been made in the very week when legislation has been introduced into this chamber which proposes to impose a levy on life insurance policy holders because of a financial scandal and huge losses incurred within the industry.

The second paper released by Mr Kerin deals with the disclosure of information to members of superannuation funds. This document is superior to Budget Paper No. 1, as it actually announces measures to be implemented such as additional information to be provided to members at entry and exit, additional information relating to master trust and similar arrangements, and information to be provided to members in advance of a repatriation of a surplus.

I will now turn to the major proposal of this Budget. The Government-after much indecision which culminated in an eleventh hour kitchen cabinet meeting at the Lodge-has announced what is undoubtedly an historic proposal to create a universal superannuation contribution regime which will provide adequate retirement income for Australia's work force for the next century and beyond. Compulsory employer contributions will rise to 9 per cent by the year 2000 and a further 3 per cent will be announced in the future which will arise from a cut in income tax or some sort of wage-tax trade-off. The scheme will be based on the training guarantee scheme model and will be known as the superannuation guarantee levy. As long as the minimum contribution has been made by the employer, there will be no liability on the employer under the levy.

Small business, which is defined as those employers with a payroll of less than $0.5m per annum, will be liable to a slower phase-in of the levy, with the liability for 1992-93 to be at the rate of 3 per cent instead of the big business rate of 5 per cent. This means that those small businesses already paying the minimum 3 per cent award superannuation-which is the vast majority-will be completely unaffected by this proposal until at least 1993-94.

However, apart from the contribution schedule, the details provided are totally inadequate. There are also anomalies in the information provided in the Budget Papers which prevent serious consideration of these proposals at this stage. For example, we are not told how the proposals will apply to the public sector with its current huge unfunded liability. Secondly, the Budget Papers state:

To meet the prescribed standard, the prescribed level of employer superannuation support will be required to vest immediately and will be fully preserved. Employers will be able to provide such support through any complying superannuation scheme.

This statement assumes that all complying superannuation funds are currently required to fully vest all employer contributions in respect of members. However, this is not the case at all. Either the Government has secretly decided on a complete change in the vesting and preservation rules without specifically stating its intentions, or it has got it wrong in the document released on Tuesday.

Under existing arrangements, the only employer contributions that must be immediately vested and fully preserved are those arising from 3 per cent award agreements. New or improved employer financed benefits after 22 December 1986 are required to be fully preserved only to the extent that they are vested, which is contingent on the provisions of the relevant trust deed. All other employer financed benefits-which constitute the vast majority-are not currently subject to any vesting or preservation requirements, although the Government has announced its intention to introduce a 10-year vesting and preservation scale to commence on 1 July 1995. As presented here, many existing employer contributions would not qualify as contributions under the levy and will make a vast difference to the liability of employers who have played the game so far by complying with superannuation requirements.

I now turn to the environment. The Treasurer's announcement of a 30 per cent increase in spending on the environment is put into its shabby perspective when one realises that this apparently impressive increase lifts this expenditure to a paltry $143m. This Budget makes no mention of the urgent need to place the economy on an ecologically sustainable footing, nor does it fund measures which could achieve that goal. The extra spending is a fragment of pale green tinsel trying to conceal a large dark brown package.

This is despite the fact that the Australian economy is faced with the great challenge of reducing its greenhouse gas emissions, reversing the degradation of our agricultural soils and marine resources, and reducing industrial pollution-this latter item given new meaning by the recent chemical fire disaster in Melbourne. Despite some promising measures scattered throughout the Budget, the environment area remains seriously under-funded.

I now turn to education. Higher education continues to be under stress while students are asked to pay more. The Federal Government has broken its promise that tertiary fees will not be increased, while failing to address the increase in student enrolments in response to the Prime Minister's call for a clever country. There is some improvement in capital funding, but recurrent funding remains insufficient to cope with over-crowding in higher education.

In 1991, universities enrolled an extra 45,000 students, including about 18,000 unfunded students. Funding has declined by 12 per cent per full time student. At 8.1 per cent, there has been no increase in the education share of total Budget outlays. In tertiary education, the real increase in funding is half the increase of the previous financial year. Surely that is an indictment of a country which the Government has the objective to turn into a clever country. The Democrats are also concerned about moves towards privatisation of higher education with provision for shared funding of 600 new places in 1992.

Of course, to prove how much tougher it is, the Opposition has stated that there should have been an additional $3 billion in spending cuts. This highlights the ridiculous nature of the public spending debate in Australia. No matter how low the level of public spending is, it is always too high for the Opposition. Just as predictably, the call for cuts is never specific.

To counter this empty rhetoric, the Budget Papers-specifically table 10 on page 22 of statement 3 of Budget Paper No. 1-contain estimates of the effect that a 1 per cent cut in outlays would have on all other programs given that public debt interest, defence, all personal benefit payments and financial assistance grants to the States cannot be cut. That table shows that a reduction of 2.7 per cent would be needed in all other programs.

Since the Opposition wishes to reduce outlays by $3 billion, it will have to reduce all other programs by 8 per cent. That is, 8 per cent less for disadvantaged schools, 8 per cent less for our chronically crowded universities, 8 per cent less for beneficiaries of the rural adjustment scheme, 8 per cent less on scientific and general research, 8 per cent less funds for roads and, indeed, 8 per cent less resources for the Senate, the Parliamentary Library and every other program funded by the Commonwealth.

There is one other item that I would like to mention briefly before I turn to revenue measures, and that is the ABC. When we look at the figures in this particular Budget, we see that they continue the history of this Government which has never, in its whole existence, given a real increase in funding to the ABC. So much for its commitment to unbiased information. The only thing that one can say is that, yet again, we face an area where the two old parties agree because, clearly, the Opposition would cut the Budget of the ABC even further.

I now turn to revenue measures. There are certain revenue measures which are welcome, such as the removal of the anomaly which limited income tax deductibility of personal superannuation contributions to $3,000 if any amount of award superannuation were earned during the year. We welcome this measure. Other major decisions concern the belated plugging of some tax avoidance loopholes such as the introduction of a foreign investment funds regime, and technical changes to the imputation regime including the alignment of treatment of registered organisations with that of mutual life assurance companies.

Other measures include a proposal to tax some lottery earnings, greater compliance initiatives in the area of employment declaration forms, and some restatement of prior announcements such as provisional tax exemption for pensioners and the proposed insurance policy holders protection levy.

There is also the adoption of the Democrats alternative Budget policy which is to increase the rate of fringe benefits tax by the Medicare levy to align the rate with the top marginal income tax liability. Obviously this is a welcome, if minor, move. The only sales tax measure is a proposal to limit the sales tax exemption on motor vehicles for people with disabilities to non-luxury vehicles. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Before the dinner break I spoke on the subject of Senator Hill's motion on Yugoslavia and expressed support for that motion. I did so in the belief that I was speaking to General Business motion No. 317. In fact, it appears that the motion before the Senate was General Business order of the day No. 120 which was, for all practical purposes, identical with motion 317 but for an additional paragraph which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (e) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic assistance.

Whatever else I might do as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, I do not think it is appropriate that I should ever get up in this place and support a motion for the recall of an ambassador in circumstances, so far as Government policy is concerned, where it is manifestly inappropriate to do so.

This was an error which arose as the result of a failure of communication between the office of the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and my own office. I regret that the mistake occurred. I do not have any difficulty with paragraphs (a) to (d) of General Business order of the day No. 120, that is, the motion we are in fact debating but, for very obvious reasons, I do have some difficulty with paragraph (e). Accordingly, I would take this opportunity both to explain that to the Senate and also to move by way of amendment:
That paragraph (e) be deleted from this motion.

I do so because it is not, in our judgment, appropriate as a routine matter-or even these days as an exceptional matter-to recall ambassadors as a gesture of disapproval. That may have been familiar diplomatic practice once upon a time but it is not the practice that in this day and age we regard as especially sensible. Almost invariably, if past practice were to be followed, the situations in which one does recall an ambassador are those situations where one most needs the ambassador on the ground to maintain a high level of representation and quality of reporting because the situation is fast moving, difficult, sensitive or whatever.

That is exactly the situation in Yugoslavia at the moment. It does not make sense in my judgment to recall the Ambassador for this or any other purpose. If one wants to make a gesture of disapproval of a regime-and that is perfectly understandable in the present circumstances-there are other ways in which one can do that, that is, by explicit public statement or some other appropriate measure. I say this particularly in the context of current diplomatic practice where we do not recognise or derecognise governments depending on how we feel about them-as I explained to Senator Harradine in answer to a question the other day-but operate on the principle of establishing diplomatic relations on the basis of our recognition of states and using other methods to demonstrate approval or disapproval, as the case may be.

I hope that has clarified the matter for the record. I also hope that, in the interests of getting a unanimous resolution of this Senate on a matter that is of significance internationally and one where a unanimous resolution would be appropriate, it might be possible in the spirit of this place for Senator Hill to accept that particular amendment. I ask him accordingly to do so. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up too much time of the Senate at this stage, but I do want to speak very strongly in support of the motion that was moved by my colleague Senator Hill in the Senate last week. This motion replaced an earlier motion that had been moved by him. The motion was strengthened by adding various parts and amending three-not one-of the four paragraphs in the original motion. We were greatly assisted-if I may pay a tribute to the work of Senator Harradine-in the strengthening of that motion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very important motion for several reasons. The first reason is that it does give a message to the authorities in Belgrade that Australia views with the gravest concern and deplores the situation that has arisen in Slovenia and Croatia where more than 300 civilians are reported to have been killed largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist-led Federal Army and attacks by the Army itself. Since that motion was moved by Senator Hill last week, there have been further deaths and the situation grows graver by the day.

The motion is very important in conveying to the authorities in Belgrade the very firm views of the Australian people in deploring what is taking place there. It is also a very important motion because it gives a message to all Australians, particularly to those Australians whose country of origin is Croatia, Serbia, Slovenia, Bosnia or any of the other republics. The importance of this motion to those Australians, whose countries of origin is one of those to which I have just referred, is very considerable indeed.

I take this opportunity to pay a tribute to all those hundreds of thousands of people, whose country of origin is those nations, because the contribution they have all made to the Australian economy, Australian society, Australian culture and the Australian way of life has been enormous. I would also take this opportunity to congratulate all those people for the restraint that they have exercised here in Australia at this terribly difficult time with the events taking place in the Yugoslav republics.

I was going to welcome the support that Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, had given for the motion before the dinner break. I was going to say that it was a very significant advance on the part of the Government because it is very important to have a united approach if we are going to be able to make a contribution in our own way as a nation to help ease the tensions occurring in so many countries around the world, particularly in Yugoslavia. Hence, it was going to give me a great deal of pleasure to welcome the Government's support of that part of the motion which:

(e) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with the desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic assistance.

In expressing my delight that the Government was going to do that, I was also going to express some surprise, particularly as Senator Evans's colleague Senator Loosley, in the debate in this place only a week ago, amongst other things-and he was speaking on paragraph (e) of the motion that I have just read out-said:
That is why the Government will be unable to agree to the final point in Senator Hill's proposition . . .

That is what Senator Loosley said. I find it staggering that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, who is in the chamber and who has just made an extraordinary admission and had a change of heart in the last two hours, did not know that Senator Hill had replaced his original motion with another motion, to which he spoke at length this time last week, and that Senator Evans's own colleague had spoken to the correct motion and had put the Government's position. Tonight, Senator Evans comes in and supports a motion that he said he thought was the one that we were debating. Everyone else knew that motion had been replaced a week ago. It is absolutely staggering that the Minister did not know that.

I also draw to the attention of the Minister the fact that the replaced motion, or the motion that is now there, is not merely a change in the last paragraph. Three of the four paragraphs of Senator Hill's original motion were changed and strengthened. While I am dealing with that, Senator Loosley was incorrect when, on the last paragraph relating to the recall of the Ambassador, he said:
Withdrawing our ambassador at the current stage would be an act of futility.

The motion does not say that we are going to withdraw the Ambassador. All the motion says is that we call upon the Government to recall our Ambassador for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic assistance. We are not asking for the withdrawal of our Ambassador to Yugoslavia. We are asking the Government to bring the Ambassador back to have rational, meaningful consultations to achieve an end result that I thought that all Australians would have fully supported.

It is amazing that the governing party in this country is not prepared to recall its Ambassador for consultations that have one objective only, and that is building or preserving peace in a very troubled region of the world. Senator Loosley also went on to say that this act `would have nothing by way of diplomatic impact to recommend it'. That is not the purpose of that final paragraph of the motion. The purpose is to get the Ambassador back for meaningful consultations.

That is not unusual in any way; it is something that constantly happens. Why on earth do we have Australian representatives around the world if we cannot bring them back for consultations during times of acute crisis? The situation in Yugoslavia could be called nothing else than that. My earlier comments when preparing these remarks of welcoming the Government support, I am afraid, have fallen on barren ground. I very deeply regret that situation.

I will not go over all the points that Senator Hill made in his wide-ranging speech when he introduced the replaced motion last week. However, let me draw attention to a couple of the extremely important points. Senator Hill made the point that it is clear that Yugoslavia is breaking up; that it cannot be held together at the point of a gun; and that, in the opinion of the coalition, the international community should vigorously oppose any attempt to do so. He pointed to the referendums which have been held in Slovenia and in Croatia and which have been announced will be held in Macedonia and Bosnia.

Senator Hill pointed out that, overwhelmingly, the people of Slovenia and Croatia supported a move for independence. He made the point which the Opposition has made time and time again-we had a debate on the Baltic states at the same time last week where we all made the point-that if people strongly desire their freedom, independence and dignity they should be allowed to have it. Leaving aside the principles involved, it is a non-starter in this day and age for countries or groups of people to be held together, as Senator Hill said, at the point of a gun.

The significance of the points that Senator Hill made have been demonstrated even more clearly by the dramatic events that have occurred in the Soviet Union in the past four days. That coup, which thankfully has come to nought-put down in the space of 60 short but terribly tense, dramatic hours-in many ways was a cataclysmic episode. It could have been cataclysmic for the bad; it has turned out to be cataclysmic for the good because it has shown that the path on which the peoples of the Soviet Union have set themselves under President Gorbachev is now undoubtedly irreversible. However, it demonstrates the fragility of the situation in eastern Europe.

It also showed, through the actions of the Yugoslav army in the last three or four days, how unrest like that occurring in the Soviet Union can be used as a cloak by other nations to advance their own causes. We have seen a major advance in the activities of the Yugoslav army in recent days under that cloak of unrest in the Soviet Union.

Reports on tonight's television news that I heard suggest that the situation has worsened in the last 24 hours, despite what only a day ago seemed to be grounds for hope. Overnight, there were reports from Reuters in Belgrade saying that Yugoslavia's leaders had agreed on principles for the peaceful solution of the crisis and that the collective state presidency and presidents of the six republics worked out a four-point agreement on Tuesday-48 hours ago-to end hostilities `as violations of an August 7 cease-fire continued'. The report states:

The four points of the agreement were: recognition of the right of every people to self-determination, including secession; respect for the democratically expressed will of all peoples; equal treatment of all political options without the use of force; and the legal implementation of the accord.

The wire service also reported that all parties at that meeting had agreed that the essential condition for an agreement on the future of Yugoslavia was an immediate and unconditional cease-fire in the republic of Croatia. Sadly, to date, it appears that that has not occurred. One can only hope that that situation will change.

In my concluding remarks I want to make a couple of points about the motion that is before the House, and in particular the final paragraph which I have already read out but which bears repetition. Paragraph (e) reads:

further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving, independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic assistance.

That final phrase in the motion is a difficult and complex one. When is the right time for independence? Different people and different groups will have different views on that matter. Senator Hill, I and others have been involved in discussions with interested parties in the past 24 hours or so on that very point. We certainly recognise that it is a difficult decision that requires the most careful consideration.

Another point in relation to Senator Hill's motion is that we have related it to both Croatia and to Slovenia; we have given them equal treatment in the motion. The question has been raised whether the situations in Croatia and Slovenia are the same, or whether there are not grounds for saying that one republic rather than the other is near to meeting, or has met, the conditions that would be generally accepted for independence, whereas the other one may not have achieved quite the same advance. Again, that is a very important point that requires further consideration by us all.

It is also argued, and very persuasively by some, that recognition of, say, Slovenia's independence would assist the situation in Croatia and elsewhere in the republics. That again is a matter that requires careful consideration and it is one of the aspects that the wording of our motion, particularly the final part, will allow us further to consider.

For all those reasons, I wish strongly to support the motion moved on behalf of the coalition by my leader, Senator Hill, expressing very deep regret that the Government, after having given us hope, has now changed its position again. I deplore that and regret it very much indeed. I hope-although I know that it is a false hope-that having changed his view once Senator Evans, after a closer look at the final paragraph of our motion, which I think he has misinterpreted, will see whether the Government can join the Opposition in this motion. Unity and a united front on this matter would be of the greatest significance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the amendment which has been moved subsequent to my speaking previously to the motion, and I shall be brief.

SPEECH.PARA: In common with Senator Short, I am sorry that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, appears to have misinterpreted the burden of paragraph (e). There are quite a number of matters that need to be discussed on a face to face level with the Ambassador to Yugoslavia. There are reports, as this motion says, that more than 300 civilians have been killed, but other reports indicate, as Senator Calvert said, that some 4,000 people have been killed. Therefore, there need to be serious consultations with the Ambassador about the facts and politics of the situation, and about the statements made by the leaders that they intend to enforce certain measures to the detriment of the republics.

There are also other matters to be considered. Is the person who goes under the name of Captain Dragon an Australian citizen? If he is, is he not subject to the Crimes (Foreign Incursions) Act? These sorts of things need to be considered. As Senator Short pointed out, I believe the Government has misinterpreted the meaning of paragraph (e).

Nevertheless, I believe that if this is carried it will send a strong message to the Yugoslav Government which must have an effect on that Government and also on a number of countries in the European Community. If Australia does make this stand, it will be in support of the democratically expressed wishes of the republics of Croatia and Slovenia and of their people.
