SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is most appropriate on this day that I comment on this report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare because, officially, it is the last day that the Senate Select Committee is to be in existence. I know a lot of people might think that that is a good thing. I think that the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is probably the longest running select committee in the history of the Westminster system. This Committee has run for eight years. During that time many fine and honourable senators have been members of that Committee.
—You should have a reunion.

—Well, I doubt that some of them would be able to make it actually. I will refer to some. Probably the most famous of all the members is the original Chairman, Senator George Georges of Queensland. We have had Senator Ray Devlin, the most recent Chairman to retire; Senator Jack Evans from Western Australia; Senator Jean Hearne from Tasmania; and Senator John Morris from New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us would remember former Senator Norm Sanders from Tasmania, the Hon. Doug Scott from New South Wales and former Senator John Siddons from Victoria. It goes without saying that the longest serving member of the Committee has been Senator David Brownhill, who is still with us, thank heavens. Senator Cooney, of course, has also been a member for quite some time.

Three other reports have to be presented to the Senate. This report on the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory is a very important one. I note with some interest that there was a debate in the other place today about the effect of feral animals on the flora and fauna of Australia. I also note that the Australian Democrats felt sufficiently concerned to move a motion along similar lines and to debate the matter earlier today.

This Committee has presented a number of reports over the years. The first report concerned the exportation of live sheep from Australia. That is still a very contentious issue. There was also a report on dolphins and whales in captivity. I remember that Senator Brownhill had quite a deal to do with that report. Madam Acting Deputy President, it is interesting that it took five years to put the kangaroo report together. It was presented in 1988 and, would you believe, three years later we still have not received a response from the Government.

Animal experimentation was probably the best report that this Committee put forward-it was excellent. I was involved in the investigations for that report. I was very interested in this matter because the use of animals in experiments was, and still is, very contentious. While we were conducting our investigations we discovered that this report had the effect of provoking most teaching universities, and other establishments that used animals, voluntarily to set up ethics committees. If nothing else, in my opinion this inquiry had the effect of forcing those teaching institutions and other agencies that used animals in experiments to set up voluntary ethics committees which had a great effect on animal welfare in animal experimentation.

In 1989, the Committee presented the sheep husbandry report and, in 1990, the intensive livestock production report, which was welcomed by all those involved in intensive livestock production, except perhaps Pam Clarke in Tasmania. Nevertheless, I believe that we presented as balanced a report as we could. The recommendations from that report were quite significant.

An interim report was presented on the racing industry, and just today we finished the final report. Two other reports are to come before the Senate involving equine welfare and competitive events other than racing, and the transportation of livestock within Australia.

This report on feral animals highlights the concerns of many people, particularly conservation groups and all those in Australia who are concerned about our native flora and fauna. One of the conclusions we came to in this report was that feral animals pose a very major problem, particularly in the Northern Territory with the effects of horses, buffaloes and other large feral animals. The Committee believed that quantitative research should be undertaken on the agricultural and environmental damage that is being caused by individual species of feral animals. We went on to highlight what we saw as the major offenders-if one could call them that-in causing a lot of our native animals to become extinct.

From the evidence we have received, it seems that the major feral animals that are causing problems in northern Australia are horses, buffaloes and donkeys. One conclusion we reached was that not only must they be controlled but, ideally, also the total eradication of horses, buffaloes and donkeys would be the goal of those control programs. In this report, apart from some very fine photographs of the members of the Committee conducting their inquiries in Kakadu National Park and Alice Springs, we noted that even after eradication there still seems to be between 105,000 and 140,000 buffaloes in northern Australia. In 1985 it was estimated that there were some 340,000. The major reason why they have been reduced in number is the BTEC program that has been conducted.

Another concern which was raised with me and Senator Burns by politicians and others in Europe was the eradication of our wild horses such as brumbies and walers. It was estimated that somewhere between 300,000 and 600,000 feral horses existed in Australia. When one considers that the next largest population of wild horses is in North America, where there are only 40,000 to 80,000, one can understand just what huge numbers of wild horses we have.

Due to the eradication program, the number of horses around Alice Springs, for instance, has been reduced from 80,000 to 54,000. But evidence we received during the inquiry showed us that the effect that wild horses have had in that area has contributed to the reduction in numbers of a particularly fine little animal that was presented to us and tabled as evidence-the bilby. Wild horses are probably the major reason that these animals are reducing in number.

It has been estimated that around 14 species of native animals have become extinct because of the competition of feral animals in Australia. Many more are under threat. In fact, 42 per cent of all arid zone mammals are threatened by the existence of large feral animals in northern Australia. In the few seconds I have left, I will just say that another major problem we have is feral pigs. God knows how many of those there are in this country, but they are a major source of concern. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare on the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory is probably the only one with which I have only a little involvement. I believe that I have had a great deal of involvement with all the other reports; we will have done about 10 of them by the end of the next day or two. Much of the work for this report was done while I was away at the United Nations last year, although a considerable amount of evidence was submitted much earlier than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject matter of this report, in some aspects, was similar to the issue that the Committee had to face with the mulesing of sheep. None of the alternatives was particularly palatable. I refer, of course, to the culling of horses in the Northern Territory. I do not intend to use my time tonight to defend the position that the Committee took on this matter. In my view, the report says it all. It provides a well written, well argued position. The Committee secretary, Neil Bessell, tells me that there has been an enormous demand for the report and that it has been extremely well received.

I wonder whether this report has been as well received as it has because of some of the photographs in the report which Senator Calvert talked about. I must admit that other inquiry reports I have been involved with have not had so many photographs, with people being idolised in them. But I really think the photograph of Senator Calvert in the report is among the best that I have seen included in any report since we started producing them.

On a more serious note, the credit for this report lies, in large part, with the secretariat. I am quite sure that Senator Burns, the Chairman of this Committee, would agree with me-and I am sure he will say something about this later. I say that, notwithstanding the work done by my colleagues-in fact, my friends-who served on the Committee. I would not have made the remark about the photographs if I did not believe that my colleague Senator Calvert is also a good friend.

I am sure that all involved with this Committee would agree that this inquiry has been a most harmonious one. I greatly enjoyed all the hearings that we sat in on together. It has been a great Committee. I would like to say thank you to Neil Bessell and his staff-Peter Short, Max Lane, Michael Game and Chris Migus-for a job well done in the time that we have been together. As Senator Calvert has already said, we have issued 10 reports. In the last three weeks, three reports have been put through their final draft. I believe that is a feat in itself, and one not matched by many other committees in this place.

Obviously Senator Cooney will say something about this Committee, because Senator Cooney and I both joined the Committee at the same time; we were the old people on that Committee. Senator Cooney and I can well remember that when we first joined the Committee Senator George Georges was the Chairman. He chaired the Committee in a most able way, as has Senator Burns in the time that he has been the Chairman of the Committee. In fact, I have been a member of this Committee for my entire Senate life, having taken over from Senator Scott when he relinquished that position on leaving the Senate. I am quite sure that he would like to be identified with the remarks tonight concerning the success of this Committee.

I have been with the Committee through thick and thin times-the thin times, when everyone in the community hated us and wanted us disbanded to where we are today with honourable senators from all parties being urged to support the continuation of this Committee. It has provided enormous interest and pleasure for me. I have met wonderful people and seen some alarming, amazing and interesting things. Actually, I am the only member of parliament who has visited every live sheep export centre. I have been on a transport ship, visited the feedlots, and been right through the whole process. I believe I am also the only senator in this place to visit every dolphinarium in Australia, which I did when one report was being put together.

TALK.START.PARA: —We went to the Melbourne Cup.

—I have been through abattoirs-apparently one abattoir too many for the Committee Secretary. As Senator Calvert has said, during the racing inquiry we went to the Melbourne Cup and looked at how animal welfare was associated with that event. It was a very interesting Melbourne Cup because it was the one at which Cole Diesel was swabbed and another horse completed an extra round of the track and collapsed at the end of the race. We spent a lot of time with the Chief Veterinary Steward, Dr Bourke. He was an example of the sort of people we have met during the hearings we have held.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not the end of the animal welfare reports because we will be talking about other reports when the Government responds to them. This Committee has allowed me to address seminars and conferences and submit papers to people here and in the United States. There has been widespread interest in animal welfare all over the world and this interest will continue.

I am saddened that we are now winding up this Committee but, hopefully, everyone will support the rural affairs committee when it comes to the Senate on Wednesday week. I think we should carry on the good work of this Committee and expand its reference so that it can look at other things associated with rural and primary industry areas.

A very important area that I do not think we have looked at is the companion animal industry. I believe that is an area we will want to look at closely in the future because it is an area where animal welfare practices are not as good as they should be. I believe the animal welfare issue is vital for rural Australia and for the entire community. As I said before, I am saddened at this Committee's passing, but I look forward to its continuing in another guise.

I know that some of my colleagues are very worried about the fact that I am not addressing myself to this report. Obviously, Senator Patterson wants to talk about something else. But I believe this report is a good report. I congratulate my colleagues on the job that they have done as members of this Committee: for example, the hard work that they put in all through the Northern Territory when we were investigating the welfare and the culling of large feral animals. I know that Senator Collins will be very happy with this report, and I am quite sure that this report will receive favourable comment from the Government as well as from the people in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very proud of the report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare on the culling of large feral animals in the Northern Territory, in the knowledge that there are various points of view as to how we should go about doing that. The Committee, under its reference and its title-animal welfare-really should not have been concerned about economics. When I say `economics' I mean in terms of the pastoral industry where one might use the store of feral animals to make a profit. Our concern was animal welfare, but of course in the process of discussing our report economics did come into it.

SPEECH.PARA: Along with Senator Brownhill, I am very much appreciative of the role of the staff in this inquiry. They organised visits, public hearings and gave the Committee certain research work which enabled it to perform fairly well. I also pay tribute to the fact that the members of the Committee did not operate on the basis of party politics. We looked at the issues and we were fairly objective in our views. I can assure the Senate that they were not always at one-and this report shows that, just as other reports will. However, I think the staff and the Committee operated fairly well and gave to the Senate and to the nation a report which has been fairly well received.

The witnesses, also, had great convictions and beliefs about what should be done about animal welfare. There were those who felt that animal welfare was already well served. While there was a difference of opinion about where we should go, the conviction and the preparation of witnesses when they came to the Committee to answer questions was fairly obvious. I would also like to thank those people.

The culling of feral animals has a worldwide application. There are people in Europe who are very concerned about shooting wild horses from helicopters. They have long held the belief that it was based on rich sportsmen who went out just to shoot horses for sport. They did not understand that it was about the elimination of those animals which were destroying the environment and which, quite often, died very painful deaths in times of drought. I believe that the decision of the Government to circulate this document worldwide to our various embassies to make that information available is a very important and very sensible approach.

There are people who would say that we should keep a depository of feral animals because they are useful for hunting by people who like to shoot off guns at anything that moves, and there are people who believe that there is some economic gain to be had. I make it very clear, as Chairman of the Committee, that we should eliminate every feral animal in this country. We would then do away with the animal welfare problem, the problem of the destruction of the environment and all of those adverse effects on people on the land who find themselves with problems because of feral animals destroying their livelihood. There are people who believe that we should keep those animals in our community. That is fine, but let them manage the animals and not let them become feral, running wild and destroying the environment.

After this session tonight the Committee will no longer exist. I think it is useful for me to comment on a few things. Next week, when I present to the President reports on equine welfare, transport of livestock and racing, the work of the long running Select Committee on Animal Welfare will be completed.

As the current Chairman of the Committee, it is appropriate to take this opportunity to comment on the contribution that the Committee has made over the last eight years. Honourable senators will be aware that in November 1983 the Senate established this Select Committee to inquire into and report on animal welfare in Australia. During the life of this Committee more than 700 submissions have been lodged by organisations and individuals, more than 150 volumes of oral and documentary evidence have been published and, I dare say, hundreds of public hearings have been held throughout the country and thousands of witnesses have been called and examined. I suppose that there are other committees in the Senate that have similar records, but I do not think they would be select committees, they would be standing committees.

I understand that the Committee began its program of public hearings in May 1984. Those hearings covered a range of topics allowing members to gain a better appreciation of the issues involved in the animal welfare debate. At that time, the Committee decided to concentrate on three topical issues: the live sheep export trade, whales and dolphins in captivity and kangaroos. Reports on these matters were tabled in 1985, 1986 and 1988 respectively.

In 1987 the Committee commenced a series of hearings. These hearings resulted in the reports on animal experimentation, tabled in 1989; sheep husbandry, also tabled in 1989; and intensive livestock, tabled in 1990.

As Chairman of the Committee, I am particularly proud that, as a result of the work over the last 10 months, the current Committee will add a further three reports to this list. These reports address issues relating to the culling of large feral animals, the transport of livestock within Australia and equine welfare. The Committee also hopes to report on evidence presented in 1988 and 1989 on the racing industry.

I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate with a review of all of the reports tabled and Government responses to them. I would, however, like to make some observations about the role and the contribution of this Committee. It is my view that over the last eight years the Select Committee has provided a very valuable forum for the review of topical and sometimes emotive issues relating to animal welfare.

It is interesting to note that the debate on animal welfare issues in other countries has been volatile and, in some instances, violent. Generally, this has not been the case in Australia. Several commentators, and even overseas visitors, have recognised that the Select Committee has played a constructive role in fostering a rational and considered debate in this country.

In this regard I would like to quote from correspondence recently lodged with the Committee. It is one thing to make a statement, but it is another to have it backed up by clear evidence of the views of others. First, I wish to quote from a primary industry association. The association states:

The Committee has seen fit at times to criticise some animal welfare matters within the industry. This has been a small price to pay to gain access to an independent, objective forum where claims about the industry can be examined and responded to.
Secondly, I quote from an animal welfare group. It states:

The work of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare has been of great importance in providing a forum, leading the way to improved welfare of all animals whose lives are influenced by people. The continuing debate on welfare has been stimulated and guided by a series of public hearings and subsequent reports of the Committee. All views on animal welfare have been heard and considered and a wealth of information has been collected and documented.
It is a credit to the 14 honourable senators who have served on the Committee that a Select Committee has established this profile and prestige.

I am sure that all of those who have served on the Select Committee will join with me in paying a particular tribute to former Senator George Georges, Chairman of the Committee from 1983 to 1987, and to Senator David Brownhill who has been a member and Deputy Chairman of the Committee since 1985.

Finally, this Select Committee has demonstrated that, although reports and recommendations to Government are important, maintaining a dialogue and establishing a conduit between concerned citizens and the Parliament are also most productive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think much of what I wanted to say has been said.
—Well, sit down.

—The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is a remarkable Committee. In this Committee we would not, at any stage, have somebody shouting at us to sit down. It is not that sort of Committee at all-quite the contrary. It is, at times, very hurtful that people for whom I have nothing but the greatest respect shout at me across the floor as was done on this occasion. It is certainly something that would never come from your lips, Madam Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: I sincerely say that this is a good Committee-it is a great Committee-and I think the atmosphere here tonight shows that. What struck me is that a senator whose office is near Lygon Street, Melbourne, does not look out upon the animal kingdom. On the other hand, I got from the people whom I associated with on the Committee a feeling of the love of animals that they really have. I did not realise that Senator Burns has had a lot to do with horses. Senator Brownhill-and I hope he is listening to this, because it is said sincerely-has shown to me just what love for animals is. I say the same for Senator Bell, Senator Calvert and Senator Sherry.

Senator Calvert, along with Senator Brownhill, introduced a very sensible and rational approach to this aspect. It is an area where great emotions can, at times, run a little astray. On that topic-and I simply want to use this as an illustration-I refer to shooting from helicopters. I think it would be fair to say, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to both Senator Burns and Senator Calvert that this had us worried, but when we saw what damage was being done by feral animals, and that this was the only way of controlling them, we recommended that it continue. Helicopter shooting was very dangerous to the people in the helicopter at times, and the concern that they showed was quite amazing.

I also pay tribute to our Committee Secretary, Neil Bessell. I think everybody would agree that he has been an outstanding Secretary. This Committee has been under the Chairmanship of Senator Burns, Senator Morris and Senator George Georges- whose praises have been greatly sung tonight.

This Committee has done great work because we have introduced into the community a concept of animal welfare that was not there before. Senator Brownhill would agree that we have done that quite magnificently. It is also an exciting committee because, in contrast to other committees, it is devoted to that hymn of life. I say in all sincerity that one feels closer to God and closer to nature as a member of this Committee than as a member of any other committee that I have been on. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill will amend several Acts within the Attorney-General's portfolio.
The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature or which correct existing legislation. None of the amendments concern major new policy proposals or sensitive policy issues.
The proposed amendments will not have a significant financial impact. The proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977 are expected to lead to savings of the order of $15,000 per year.
The amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will permit the Trade Practices Commission to charge for material published by it. It is estimated this will result in revenue of $33,000 per annum.
The proposed amendments are explained in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill. I intend to confine my comments to the more noteworthy amendments.

A provision is to be inserted into the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 to provide that, where a State or Territory law alters the name of a body or of an office, a reference in a Commonwealth Act to the body or office under the old name shall be construed as a reference to the body or office under the new name. The amendment will overcome difficulties which recently arose where the name of a State Crime Commission referred to in a Commonwealth Act, was altered by State legislation.

An amendment will also be made to allow a board member of a statutory body to participate at board meetings by telephone, closed-circuit television and other modern electronic means of communication. Several Acts already make provision for this form of participation. The amendment will remove the need to enact such provisions in individual Acts, and overcome the problems which arise if members are precluded from participating in board meetings unless physically present.

The Bill will repeal provisions in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 requiring estimates of receipts and expenditure to be approved by the Attorney-General before monies appropriated can be spent. These provisions are not necessary, as the Tribunal and courts operate under the Department of Finance Ledger System whereby the funds appropriated are controlled and released by the Department of Finance in accordance with validated claims submitted by each agency. Such claims must be in accordance with Finance Regulations and Directions. The issue of funds is also in accordance with the running cost splits separately identified in the Budget papers.

The amendment of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933 will clarify the current provision dealing with proceedings related to the winding-up of companies. The revised provisions will make it clear that the powers given to the Master and the Registrar in relation to winding-up proceedings may be exercised interchangeably between the Master and the Registrar.

The amendments to the ASIO Act will bring procedures for the handling of warrants relating to postal articles into conformity with the procedures for the handling of warrants relating to telecommunications and will place the Australian Capital Territory in the same position as the States and the Northern Territory so far as the performance by ASIO of its functions is concerned. The Bill also includes other amendments of a consequential nature.

The amendment to the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 will remove the provision for adding three extra days, known as `days of grace', to the maturity date of bills of exchange that are not payable on demand. This practice, which allows extra time for payment of a bill of exchange or promissory note, is out of step with general international practice. The proposed amendment will bring Australian law into line with similar provisions under United Kingdom and New Zealand law.

The amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977 have a two-fold purpose. First, to abolish the National Legal Aid Representative Council, and second, to amend the Act to enable a further member to be appointed to the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee (NLAAC).

The Council, a twenty-member body, was established administratively in September 1987, and given a statutory basis by the Commonwealth Legal Aid Amendment Act 1988. The Council is one of two advisory bodies established by the Act, the other being the NLAAC, a 7 member body of persons possessing particular expertise relevant to legal aid policies and programs. The Council was created to give representatives of major legal aid providers and consumers a forum for discussion and to enable them to provide advice to the responsible Minister.
Over the past 3 years, both bodies have been responsible for advising the Minister on legal aid matters. However, while the NLAAC meets about 5 times a year, the Council only meets once a year.

The three occasions on which the Council has met have shown that it is not an effective body. Its continued operation, at a cost of approximately $20,000 per year, is an unjustified duplication of effort given the role of the NLAAC. In July 1990, the NLAAC presented a detailed report on a 2-year review it had conducted of legal aid programs and policies.

In its Report, the NLAAC has recommended that there be regular national and international legal aid conferences at which a wide range of interested organizations, groups and individuals could discuss legal aid issues. Such conferences would provide a more effective forum for exchanging ideas and developing new policy proposals than the Council.
The other amendment will expand the NLAAC to 8 members, thereby broadening the relevant expertise and experience of its members.

The proposed amendments to the Statutory Declarations Act 1959 will simplify the processes for witnessing statutory declarations and provide a more accessible service to members of the public and business community by broadening the categories of persons able to witness statutory declarations. The amendments will also remove the requirement for the Attorney-General, or his delegate, to make appointments as a Commissioner for Declarations.

The amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will authorise the Trade Practices Commission to make charges and impose fees in certain areas of its activities, thereby improving the Commission's revenue base and providing a means for the utilisation of the user pays principle in relation to some of the Commission's activities.
The amendments will authorise the Commission to make charges in relation to the supply of material it publishes in the course of carrying out its functions or exercising its powers.

The amendments will also enable regulations to be made permitting the Commission to make charges or impose fees in relation to a person's attendance at or participation in an activity arranged by or on behalf of the Commission, such as a seminar, the provision of prescribed discretionary services by the Commission, such as providing a speaker at conferences, and the making of an application for an authorisation or the giving of a notification to the Commission.

The proposed amendments to the Law Officers Act are to ensure that a pension will be payable to a Solicitor-General who has served in that office for at least 7 years. The Act currently provides that a pension is only payable to a Solicitor-General who has served at least 7 years and who has not been reappointed at the end of his or her term of office.
I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliament House: Industrial Action-Sporting Links with South Africa

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two matters on the adjournment. The first relates to comments that I did not wish to make while the blockade of Parliament House was in progress. Now that it has finished I would like to make some remarks about that blockade, picket line, or whatever one wants to call it. In particular I want to deal with the role of former Senator John Morris in this matter. When Senator John Morris was here he was renowned for indolence. I might say that he is much more energetic outside this Parliament than he ever was inside it.
—A low blow.

—Yes, but an accurate one. I raise former Senator Morris's role in this matter because he was the key union organiser of the picket. It was he who was continually misleading his unionist colleagues about the nature of the industrial dispute. I regret that John Morris took the view that it was worth while misleading his union members largely in order to run a `get square' campaign against his former colleagues inside-and I refer in particular to the Presiding Officers.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Senate are aware of the fact that both Presiding Officers are members of the right wing of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. I think both Senator Sibraa and Mr McLeay were assistant secretaries of the Labor Party at one stage- Senator McMullan nods in acknowledgment-and apparatchiks within that organisation.

John Morris received his comfortable ride into the Senate on the basis of a deal done with the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales under which he guaranteed his support for the Federal Executive of the Party in exchange for being endorsed on the Senate ticket. He agreed to support the right wing at the Federal Executive. There was a pay-off, and I understand part of that pay-off was that he would get endorsement and lead the Senate ticket in the 1990 election.

In fact, that almost came to pass. He was preselected to lead the ticket; I will not say preselected by the normal methods but, nonetheless, he was to lead the ticket for the 1990 election until the Labor Party became aware, as a result of some comments that I made in the Parliament, just how little Senator Morris had done to earn his money-at least, how little he had done in the chamber to earn his money as a senator. I think I established that Senator Morris's activities here cost the Australian taxpayer about $72 a word. He had made two speeches, totalling 4,200 words, in four years as a senator when I raised the matter again in June 1989.

I have gone into this background to dramatise that former Senator Morris then got dumped from the Labor Party ticket and was replaced by Senator Loosley. It was clearly not in the Opposition's best interests to have generated that change. Senator Loosley is a far more effective senator than John Morris could ever have hoped to be. But the point is that former Senator Morris did get dumped. It seems to me totally inappropriate for former Senator Morris then to generate the sort of hostility towards this place among former employees of the catering service, who were members of his union, such that they felt they should picket Parliament House.

Former Senator Morris generated and encouraged that dispute for the purpose of personal satisfaction, I suppose one could call it. It was a `get square', in crude political terms, bought at the cost of some of his union supporters. After listening to what the President has had to say in this chamber about that dispute, there is no doubt that there was an enormous gap between the `facts' that the unionists were being told by John Morris and the facts as we understood them in this chamber.

I have been advised by many of the people working in the privatised dining room that the issue, as it was put to them, was not basically about the redundancy package or retraining requirements of only about 20 or so of the people involved. It was basically a dispute, in Morris's view, as expressed to them, over the issue of privatisation. He was seeking to reverse the decision that the Presiding Officers had taken, which saved something like one and a quarter million dollars a year of taxpayers' money. The disputation was over privatisation. Morris described those people who continued to work for us and with us-people who are our friends, who have worked for us for so many years and with whom most of us have very friendly and happy relationships in the dining room-as scabs because they had ratted on his opposition to privatisation.

I am saying all this after the event because I did not want to worsen the dispute. The dispute is now over, but I find it intolerable that a person like Morris-who certainly did not distinguish himself in this chamber and who certainly was not a person that this chamber or any member of this chamber would be proud to be associated with-should have played such a role in trying to disrupt the operations of the Parliament and to incite the people working for us in the dining room, with whom most of us had a very good personal, friendly relationship, into such action. That he should have taken such a position is intolerable. That was only one of the points I wanted to make. I have very little regard for former Senator Morris who, I should add in passing, is now facing fraud charges in New South Wales.

The next thing I want to deal with is a matter of much more significance. I am most concerned about what the Government is up to in its dealings with South Africa on sport. I was under the impression that the Government was prepared to agree that, where criteria set down by the ANC-dominated organisations of South Africa were met, there was no real problem in allowing the resumption of sporting links with South Africa.

For example, the Australian Cricket Board announced last week that a South African team could be included in the 1992 World Cup to be hosted jointly by Australia and New Zealand in February and March because, apart from anything else, there was no ground swell of public opinion against the South African cricketers and they had met the necessary criteria. On top of that, a spokesman for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, also said that there should be no impediment to South African cricketers playing internationally because the International Cricket Council had readmitted South Africa as it met the criteria.

If that is supposed to be the situation, why did the Australian Government frustrate, delay and ultimately prevent a group of South African water-skiing officials from coming to the Australian water-skiing championships, which have taken place in Darwin over the past week? Apparently, there has been no policy statement from the Government saying that they must not come. It was simply done by the devious process of bureaucratic delay. It may well be that it is simply incompetence, in which case my conspiracy theory may fall apart. I hope that the Australian Government's people in South Africa do not have the level of incompetence that would be required to have made such a mess of this. If not, it was a specific, deliberate and determined effort of governmental frustration.

The facts are as follows: the criteria appear to have been met. I have a letter from the National Olympic Committee of South Africa, that is, NOCSA, whose Chairman is Ramsamy. This body is the new integrated head of sport in South Africa, and it appears to relate even to non-Olympic sports, such as water-skiing. It adopted on 30 June 1991 a resolution which says:

Recognising the positive role played, until recently, by sports sanctions in isolating racist sport, and acknowledging the need for adapting our approach to the changed internal and external environment INOCSA (now NOCSA) decides to maintain the sports moratorium in its undated form whereby outside coaches, trainers and administrators be allowed into the country and to reserve the option to selectively exclude from such sanctions those sports meeting the following conditions . . .

The resolution goes on. One condition is to the effect of having been accepted by INOCSA after fulfilling the conditions listed. Water-skiing appears to have met that criterion. Instead of, in this case, outside coaches and trainers going to South Africa, the object of this exercise was for the administrators, for officials of the South African Waterski Association, to go to a world championship to see how it is done, to increase the capacity of that sport in South Africa to be administered. In other words, it basically met the requirements of NOCSA. It did more than that. I understand from correspondence that, when the Australian Government refused to act on the request for visas for these officials on the basis that they needed approval from NOCSA, the officials involved from the South African Waterski Association contacted Mr Ramsamy of NOCSA and wrote the following letter:
I refer to our telephone conversation this morning at 10:00 local time and enclose documentation for your information.
I also contacted Mr Harvey Redman, Chairman of the Ski Racing Association.
Mr Ramsamy contacted me on 14 August and said that he had no problem with visa applications-
that is for the water-ski officials-
and that we should continue with our arrangements; he is just waiting for Mr Tim Yeend of the Australian Embassy to phone him back.
He is probably still waiting. This letter was dated 16 August, by the way. It continues:
We were unsuccessful in contacting Mr Tim Yeend, he wasn't available.
We are proceeding with the applications, although Mr Yeend initially told us that it would take 4 weeks. Application as sports administrators and not tourists were made on 2 August `91.

It seems then that Mr Ramsamy was on side; in other words, the criteria had been met. There was no evident reason for obstruction and there was no doubt that the water-ski people were certainly welcome guests in Australia as far as the Australian organisation was concerned, because it had in fact invited them to attend.
It seems extraordinary that Mr Yeend told the South African water-skiers that they could not come, in these terms:

Further to your contact with the Embassy, we have received advice that no visas will be issued for the Water Ski Racing Championships in Darwin from 14-26 August. We would only be prepared to consider further applications linked with the sport when it has received affiliation to the National and Olympic Committee of South Africa.

As I said, the National and Olympic Committee is in fact a national olympic committee, and water-skiing is not an olympic sport. Mr Yeend seems to have confused whatever the organisation is. There was an attempt to contact Mr Yeend; he was not available. All I am saying is, for heaven's sake, what is the Government up to? Why is it putting obstacles in the way of resuming sporting links with South Africa when the criteria appear to have been properly met?

It seems to me that it may have had something to do with the fact that, coincidentally, Mr Sisulu was visiting Australia and maybe the Government did not want this sort of thing to happen while he was here. In other words, there was some pretty poor petty politics being played because Mr Sisulu had taken a contrary view about whether we should remove our sporting bans with South Africa.

Mr Sisulu disagreed with Professor Ross Garnaut, a former Prime Minister's adviser, who believes that sanctions against South Africa are no longer helpful to the cause of dismantling apartheid. He believes that we should resume our links, both commercial and sporting, with South Africa. However, when Mr Sisulu was here, at the same time as all this was going on, he called on Australians to stop the South African cricket team from playing in next year's cricket world cup because he did not think it was the right time for Australia to resume sporting links with South Africa.

My further concern about this matter is that other groups in Australia, frankly, have been dealt with pretty roughly by the Australian Government. In July, a South African women's netball group were in Australia on tourist visas and were approached by the media for interviews. This was during the world cup. They were not playing; they were observing. They were visited by immigration officials who told them that if they talked to the press they would be deported. What sort of a nation are we here at the moment?

It is interesting that in the run-up to the foreign Ministers' meeting in New Delhi the Australian Government appears to be behaving not like the sovereign government of an independent people but like the toadies of people who seem to be controlling its activities from outside. I find that a very unattractive way for this Government to behave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words tonight about National Child Protection Week, which started last Sunday and finishes on 24 August, and about its organisers, NAPCAN, which is the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect.

SPEECH.PARA: Children, of course, are people. As they are our most precious resource, we need to listen to them. Looking after them is not enough; we must nurture them to ensure their lives are safe and happy. We must realise that neglecting them is actually a form of child abuse. We often hear horrendous stories of physical and sexual child abuse, but how often do we pay attention to the other forms of child abuse, which are neglect and emotional abuse? If we are unable to listen to our children or to desperate parents' cries for help, we as individuals are contributing to such abuse.

NAPCAN, which is an organisation that needs a lot of recognition, was established in 1987. It is the first national organisation of its kind in Australia working to promote effective care and protection of children. In my motion this morning, I mentioned Rosemary Sinclair, a foundation member of NAPCAN. She was its first president and this year she is the national coordinator. I congratulate all the people of Tamworth who were mentioned in the motion which was declared formal this morning.

I would like to quote a poem that was written by one of the young children for the celebrations of the National Child Protection Week in my home city of Tamworth last Sunday, to which I was asked to go as representing the Federal and State governments. The poem was written by an 11-year-old girl called Katrina Ward. It goes like this:
Will you listen to me I roared at my mother
Not now not now I am talking to your brother
Go and talk to your father he'll listen to you
So I went to Dad and what does he do
Please listen Katrina not right now
I'm watching the football here and now
I stormed to my room angry and fried
Flung myself onto the bed and cried
Heard a knock on the door and in came my brothers
They teased and tormented something different from the others
In came Dad to save the day
I'll watch the football on replay.

I think there is a message in that for all the people in this chamber and for people in the community about neglect of our children when we do not listen to them when they want to be listened to. The theme of the National Child Protection Week was `Listen to the Children'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to read a statement by Senator Bell, Senator Bourne, Senator McLean, Senator Coulter, Senator Kernot and Senator Lees. In the light of widespread misinterpretation of statements made on our behalf in recent days in connection with the leadership of the Australian Democrats, I make this following statement: We became aware several weeks ago that there had been exorbitant claims for overtime by one of Senator Janet Powell's staff, Mr Bill Scetrine. We now know that Senator Powell was aware of these payments by at least April 1991 and took no action to dismiss Mr Scetrine, nor did she consult with her deputy or any of the senators making this statement.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence we have received tonight reinforces our conviction that the hours claimed by Mr Scetrine were well in excess of the hours worked, the claim being $59,000 over the nine months from 1 July 1990 to 28 March 1991, that amount being over and above his base salary.

The Senate Hansard of 21 December 1990 shows that Mr Scetrine's base salary was between $30,370 and $31,150. We are convinced that Senator Powell either did know or should have known that these claims were excessive and that her failure to take decisive action constituted gross mismanagement. This conviction was central to our reasons for expressing the lack of confidence in Senator Powell last Monday. We dissociate ourselves from Mr Scetrine's claims and Senator Powell's response to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a short statement to clarify the situation as put forward by Senator Coulter. When I became Leader of the Australian Democrats, Mr Bill Scetrine was placed on the APS grade two staff position, having been moved from my electorate staff to assume the job of Press Secretary to the Leader. He was also briefed to coordinate media work of all senators. In late April, I was formally notified by the Department of Administrative Services that overtime payments were accumulating at a very high level. I immediately took action to move Mr Scetrine to a private secretary position which attracts a set ministerial staff allowance rather than overtime.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, on 7 May 1991, the Assistant General Manager of the Department of Administrative Services wrote to me saying that he had carried out a review, that the amount of overtime claimed `must be regarded as excessive', and acknowledged my remedial action. This is the first time that a leader of the Australian Democrats has used a full time press secretary. It is now obvious, given the heavy demand on time, that the private secretary position is the appropriate one for such a staff member. I acknowledge my lack of oversight and I believe that a review of the situation around the end of last year, after all the other positions on leader staff had been filled, might have been wise. However, once I was alerted to the situation I took prompt action and this was acknowledged by the Department of Administrative Services.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.52 p.m.
